fields.headline: Only the democrats will survive
fields.standfirst: Web-based companies may find the Seventies idea of worker participation is vital for success, argues  Enid Mumford
fields.trailText: Web-based companies may find the Seventies idea of worker participation is vital for success, argues Enid Mumford
fields.body:
'Participation' was a popular concept in the US and Europe during the Seventies and Eighties. Using the ideas of bodies such as the Tavistock Institute of Human Relations, firms including ICI and Shell eagerly adopted the practices of teamwork, multiskilling and shopfloor decision making, partly because they wanted a more flexible labour force but also as a way of increasing workplace democracy.

More conservative companies, faced with recruiting difficulties, thought that offering interesting and challenging work would attract more and better staff.

In the Nineties, these ideas were abandoned as recession set in and share price became the principal management motivator. Aided by technology, companies bent on chopping costs indulged in successive waves of downsizing.

Now the situation is changing dramatically again. Glob alisation and its consequences rule. As individuals we are urged to forget careers and job security and sell our skills in short-term contracts. The day of the self-sufficient, self-motivated and sometimes reluctantly self-employed individual has, it seems, arrived.

The organisations we sell our skills to are changing, too. We are seeing, or so it is predicted, the universe of companies dividing into two: small, dynamic, entrepreneurial new-technology firms, which must continually innovate to survive, and large, multinational, multibusiness corporations, which rove around the world in search of low wages and scarce skills.

What both these types have in common is their expected dependence for success on 'groupwork' - coalitions of small groups working together positively and democratically to further the inter ests of their employing company. Thus, in Enter-prise.com , Lotus chief executive Jeff Papows maintains that all companies will in future be characterised by flatter organisation structures, communication that is more horizontal than vertical, and the removal of barriers between functions such as sales, marketing and customer service. Most decisions will, he says, be made by collaborative groups.

For this to work, a major cultural jump would appear to be needed from today's hierarchical bureaucracies to tomorrow's people networks. There also seems to be a conflict here: how will the self-motivated individual looking after his or her personal interests fit into a flatter, group-based, entrepreneurial company that requires total employee commitment and dedication.

Which is where we come back to participation. Briefly defined, participation is a process that allows employees to influence both the work they do and the conditions under which they do it.

The concept is usually supported by three broad arguments: humanistic (it is right), power sharing (it is fair), and organisational efficiency (it increases profits). The belief is that participation will ensure flexibility and commitment in the new technology-driven firms.

Participation has had a chequered history, with both management and unions on occasions railing against the concept. But even today, when the share price rules much of company behaviour, there are outstanding suc cesses. The Basque Mondragon Company, which is worker owned and managed, employs 27,000 people. In the UK the John Lewis Partnership has considerable employee involvement and profit-sharing schemes. The Scandinavian countries have always recognised participation as an important employ ment asset, and industrial relations in these countries work smoothly.

In a recent book, (Organisational Participation: Myth and Reality, by Frank Heller, Eugen Pusic, George Strauss and Bernard Wilpert, Oxford University Press) the Tavistock's Frank Heller says participation requires certain conditions for it to succeed.

For example, there must be motivation to participate, there must be trust and confidence between all parties, and participants must have the competence and knowledge to make a useful contribution to decision-making. It is most needed when flexibility, creativity and commitment are at a premium - all factors that will be vital in the new, integrated, companies of the future.

But when these factors are absent, the chances of success are low. In low-trust situations, groups may not share their employers' interests, and may even choose to fight management. Greater autonomy gives them the power to do this.

As it is, little if any attention is given to how people will work together happily and productively in the new economy. There seems to be an unstated assumption that in the technical paradise that lies ahead of us, all will be sweetness and light. We seem to view the future in terms of Voltaire's 'all is for the best in the best of all possible worlds'.

But companies should start thinking now about these human issues and how to address them. They are not new concerns, and the problems that can be anticipated seem unlikely to differ greatly from those experienced in the past, although the context will be very different.

The new web-based enterprises may find that successful participation between employees, customers, suppliers and other influential and relevant groups is a critical success factor, perhaps the most critical success factor, in the future.

 Enid Mumford, Emeritus Professor at Manchester University, is author of Dangerous Decisions: Problem Solving in Tomorrow's World (Kluwer, 1999)

fields.headline: The pits
fields.standfirst: Our top 10 traps and golden rules for your money
fields.trailText: Our top 10 traps and golden rules for your money.
fields.body:
Mortgages that tie you down

From fixed rates to capped and discounted rates, most attractive deals come with a price: you cannot ditch them in the first year or two without paying a hefty penalty.

It may be reasonable to expect borrowers to be committed to a deal for as long as the favourable initial rate holds, but one that has you in chains for years after the offer finishes is a bad idea.

The rate you have to pay after the honeymoon could well be 2 per cent higher than discounted deals then available. On a £60,000 loan, this adds up to an extra £1,200 a year in interest.

Poor-value annuities

If you save in a personal pension, your provider will, when you retire, offer you an annuity - an income for life, that you buy with your fund.

But independent financial advisers (IFAs) say this is unlikely to be the best value available. You have the right to shop around.

Dan Kemp of IFA Holden Meehan says: 'The difference between the lowest rate and the highest is huge.'

Miserly current accounts

Most traditional high street banks pay a pittance in interest on current account credit balances, even if they average more than £1,500. Lloyds TSB and Barclays pay only 0.1 per cent, even on more than £5,000.

Internet users should consider switching to a web-based bank, such as Smile or Cahoot. These pay 4.85 per cent and 3 per cent respectively on current account balances from only £1. Or you could use your present balance to save interest on your home loan by taking a current account mortgage, such as Virgin One.

Endowment mortgages

These loans - now fading in popularity - use endowment policies to repay the loan, rather than the traditional repayment method.

Endowments are inflexible and often perform poorly as investments. Many homebuyers taking endowment mortgage have recently been told that their investment may not pay off the amount they have borrowed. They have to make up the shortfall another way.

Philippa Gee of independent financial adviser Gee and Company says: 'If you want to be sure your mortgage will be paid off at the end of the term, choose a repayment mortgage.'

Expensive store cards

Department store account cards are tempting when you are paying for a big purchase. By opening one you often get a discount on that day's shopping bill. But if you go on using the card and pay off what you owe gradually, you will be charged very high interest rates.

Annual rates for cards at Monsoon, Russell & Bromley and Country Casuals are 30.7 per cent after 56 interest-free days.

Using a lower-interest credit card is better. Egg, for example, charges 13.2 per cent, and the rate with Smile is 12.9 per cent. Better still, settle your balance monthly.

National Savings

Savers pay for the rock-like safety of Government-backed National Savings products by accepting uncompetitive interest rates.

Money in a National Savings Ordinary account, earns only 1.75 per cent. Legal & General Bank pays 6.28 per cent on £1 or more in its Tracker account.

Obsolete accounts

For every new account paying interest of more than 6 per cent, there are others yielding less than 2 per cent, and occasionally half of that.

In many cases these are obsolete accounts, which banks or building societies no longer offer to new customers. NatWest pays just 2.6 per cent on balances of less than £10,000 in its First Reserve instant access account. Barclays' Instant Savings account pays as little as 1.25 per cent.

Make regular checks on the interest paid on your savings, and change accounts if it falls significantly below the competition.

Unnecessary insurance

Salesmen play on our fears, such as our children being left penniless if we died. People often succumb and buy insurance they do not need.

Anyone who is single and has no one who would lose financially if they died is not likely to need life insurance. Yet a 19-year-old receptionist who was single and had no dependants was sold a policy when her main need was for a savings account.

The Personal Investment Authority Ombudsman's office said: 'The initial sum insured of over £12,000 was excessive...' It was supposed to pay possible funeral expenses set higher than even 'the wildest assumptions about inflation'.

The watchdog ruled that her premiums should be returned with interest, plus £100 for distress and inconvenience.

Bank staff, too, are now keen to sell their customers insurance. Remember, they are salespeople, and most no longer fit the old image of the paternalistic bank manager.

High-start pension fees

Most personal pension firms are anticipating the launch next year of the Government-backed stakeholder schemes by offering similar plans themselves. Broadly, this means flexibility and charges no higher than 1 per cent a year. (See Money Writes, page 18).

But many schemes still levy high charges in the early years. Ask what the transfer value of your pension would be in the first five years, and compare this with what you would have paid in contributions. If it is less, be cautious.

Notice accounts

Savings accounts that tie up your money for a set period don't always pay extra.

Fierce competition among instant access accounts means that some of the best rates are paid on accounts where you can get at your cash quickly.

Financial database Moneyfacts says Bristol & West pays 7.05 per cent on balances of more than £10,000 in its 'save.it' internet account.

This week, the best rate for the same amount in a notice account is also 7.05 per cent, with Scarborough building society. And for that you have to give 90 days' notice to get at your money.

Golden rules for your money

 Avoid high street banks; they rarely offer the best deals for current accounts, credit cards, savings or investments. The best current accounts are from converted building societies and new internet banks

 Consider switching at least some of your borrowing and saving to a building society. These are generally better than the high street banks.

 Keep investments separate from other financial needs. Products such as endowment mortgages - mixing investment with borrowing - are usually bettered by alternatives such as a cheap mortgage plus an Isa.

 Borrow as sparingly as possible on credit cards. Sign up for a card with a low rate and pay it off as quickly as you can. Try not to run up a bill on the card again

 Don't keep large amounts on deposit if you also have debts. You get high risk-free returns from paying off mortgage and credit card debt. Most people will need some money in a savings account, but it does not pay to keep accumulating cash deposits while you have debt. If you don't expect to have to touch your savings for five years, look at investing in the stock market through - in this order - Isas, unit or investment trusts, and shares.

 Check in the financial press occasionally that your current account, credit cards and savings are competitive.

 Get alternative quotes when renewing house and car insurance. Motor premiums are rising sharply, but the AA says it should still be possible to reduce premiums 30 per cent or so by shopping around. It may also be worth checking for a better deal on life insurance: premiums have dropped sharply in recent years; a contract taken out some time ago may now be expensive. Don't cancel a policy before confirming cover with a new insurer.

 Be wary of products demanding long-term commitment. This may be a mortgage with redemption penalties that last beyond the discount or fixed rate, or a personal loan with repayment penalties. Endowment savings plans - similar to those used for mortgages but usually sold on a 10-year term - carry early cash-in penalties. You may not get back as much as you paid in the early years.

 Beware borrowing to pay off debt. This can work if you are careful: a cheap introductory rate on a credit card to clear short-term debt, or a personal loan to cut the cost of assorted debts. But it can be a disaster if you add to the debt you have consolidated. Look first at whether you can budget your way out of debt.

 If you are tempted by a new product aiming to revolutionise the way your organise your finances, ask yourself whether you could achieve the same result by taking a DIY approach.

 Remember that you can't have your cake and eat it. For example, investment products that aim to give a stock market-linked return, but guarantee to pay back your original investment may work out a worse deal than if you simply kept some money on deposit and invested separately in shares.

webTitle: Taking the pith out of expenses

fields.headline: Taking the pith out of expenses
fields.standfirst: Alexander Garrett  on a new approach to keeping staff happy - and a lid on what they spend
fields.trailText: Alexander Garrett on a new approach to keeping staff happy - and a lid on what they spend
fields.body:
If Lord Levy gets fed up with the furore about his claiming £36,000 business expenses in a year when he paid only £5,000 in tax, he could always point the finger at the spectacular gravy train enjoyed by Members of the European Parliament. MEPs are entitled to a generous 'attendance' allowance of £142 a day; a handy £2,337 a month to cover general expenses such as pens and paper clips; a secretarial allowance (£6,743 a month); and a travel allowance based on miles travelled which can produce a profit of several hundred pounds every time the MEP boards a plane to Brussels. Little wonder they are being asked to vote in favour of a less extravagant package.

Business expenses should be a means of recovering money you have spent in the course of your work, so you are not subsidising your employer. In the case of the self-employed, expenses should be costs incurred by the business, which can be deducted from your turnover to reduce the profits on which your tax is calculated. In practice, however, it is common to regard expenses as a perk, or a means to subsidise your lifestyle.

According to the Inland Revenue's definition, a genuine expense must be incurred 'wholly, exclusively and necessarily' in the performance of your duties. If you fail that test you may find you have an unwelcome tax liability.

According to American Express, expenses for travel and entertainment are the third biggest cost in large companies, behind payroll and data processing. Expenses account for 7 per cent of operating costs among the companies surveyed by Amex; it estimates that in the UK the total value of travel and entertainment expenses has grown from $30 billion in 1994 to $40bn this year.

With costs rising at such an alarming rate, the answer for many companies is to introduce a written policy setting out which expenses employees are allowed to claim, and how much. According to Mike Platt, managing director of travel management company BTI UK Hogg Robinson, many companies are adopting a single policy that dictates everything from the airline you are allowed to travel with to the way that you present your expenses.

'It will usually state when you are allowed to use business class travel, and set a spending limit for meals and entertainment, down to whether you are allowed a half or a full bottle of wine,' he says.

Anyone who disregards the policy does so at their peril. The main sanction is that expenses will not be reimbursed. That is easier now that many companies are replacing corporate credit cards with 'self-settling' cards paid off by the employee. 'You also have to get your expenses in on time in order to get the money back, which exerts an administrative discipline,' adds Platt.

Companies such as Hogg Robinson operate increasingly sophisticated systems which not only alert managements to 'exceptions' - such as somebody who opts for a flight that is not the cheapest - but can even pass judgment on somebody's need to travel.

One development that many would regard as positive is that the generosity of expenses - for example first-class rail or business-class air travel - is becoming less dependent on the status of the employee, and more on the length or frequency of the journey, or their need to be able to work during or after the trip.

Matthew Davis, manager of consulting services in Europe for Amex, says: 'If a director travels once a year, he may be expected to go economy, but if an employee travels four times a month, it may be accepted that they need the extra comfort of business class.'

Many companies allow busi ness class to be used if the journey is more than six hours - crossing the Atlantic, for example.

For companies, the sheer cost of processing expenses can be draining. One way to cut it is to pay fixed allowances, rather than reimbursing bills. Such allowances, sometimes known as a 'per diem', can cover meals and overnight stays, and are used by many big companies, including BT.

But according to David Wreford, a senior consultant with remuneration specialist William Mercer, that provides an incentive - perfectly legitimate - for the employee to keep spending to a minimum and pocket the balance. 'I've known people come on training courses with hypothermia because they had pocketed the allowance and spent the night in a bivvy bag in a field,' he says.

Fiddling expenses - often described as the middle-class equivalent of benefits fraud - is taken very seriously by most companies, he says. You may receive an automatic final warning, or even be dismissed, if caught out.

Phil Vickery, celebrity chef of Ready Steady Cook , was dismissed from the Castle Hotel in Taunton after claiming £1,444 expenses for a three-day trip to Venice with his girlfriend, which she later described as a 'birthday treat'. An employment tribunal ruled that he had not deliberately deceived the hotel and that his dismissal was unfair.

According to Amex, most companies check claims to see if they are supported by receipts and added up correctly - and to judge whether they are reasonable. But it says that rather than checking every single claim, as more than half of all companies do, they should take a sample, or target claims that are exceptional or from past offenders.

Davis says: 'I know of at least one significant multinational which figured out that there would always be a few people who fiddled their expenses, but that checking them would cost more than the amount cheated. So they stopped checking altogether.'

Fraud aside, most companies recognise that there is a risk attached to tightening up on expenses, whether it be stamping on big lunch bills or forcing travellers on to Easyjet.

Platt says: 'I believe most people see expenses as a justifiable reward for the fact that they have to leave their loved ones behind, and they feel they should damned well be allowed to do it in comfort. We have seen people who used to fly Club Class and have been downgraded to economy no longer heading straight back to the office when they get off their flight.

'At the end of the day, a happy traveller is a productive traveller.'

Legitimate exes, not wild excesses

1: Get hold of the company policy. Although most companies have a policy on travel arrangements and expenses, staff are often not aware of these guidelines.

2: Keep all receipts. It sounds obvious, but many people fail to collect receipts, especially for smaller items such as bar bills. Without receipts your employer has an excuse not to reimburse you, and the Inland Revenue may judge that your claim is not exempt from tax.

3: Put your expenses in on time. In a well-run organisation, every department has a budget, and up-to-date management information is at a premium. You will not only put yourself in bad odour by claiming late, your claim may even be refused - especially if you have missed the end of one tax year.

4: Don't put personal spending on the company credit card. Although some companies don't outwardly discourage this practice, it simply muddies the waters about what is a legitimate business expense and what is not, and again may be frowned upon by the Revenue.

5: When in doubt, memo your manager. If you have any worry that your expenses won't be reimbursed, memo or email your manager beforehand. He or she may veto your lunch or your trip, but that's better than finding yourself seriously out of pocket.

6: Think what you would spend if it was your own money. If you're ever unsure what's an appropriate amount to be spending, imagine that you are on your own tab. Any wild excesses will soon disappear.

According to the Inland Revenue's definition, a genuine expense must be incurred 'wholly, exclusively and necessarily' in the performance of your duties. If you fail that test you may find you have an unwelcome tax liability. According to American Express, expenses for travel and entertainment are the third biggest cost in large companies, behind payroll and data processing. Expenses account for 7 per cent of operating costs among the companies surveyed by Amex; it estimates that in the UK the total value of travel and entertainment expenses has grown from $30 billion in 1994 to $40bn this year. With costs rising at such an alarming rate, the answer for many companies is to introduce a written policy setting out which expenses employees are allowed to claim, and how much. According to Mike Platt, managing director of travel management company BTI UK Hogg Robinson, many companies are adopting a single policy that dictates everything from the airline you are allowed to travel with to the way that you present your expenses. 'It will usually state when you are allowed to use business class travel, and set a spending limit for meals and entertainment, down to whether you are allowed a half or a full bottle of wine,' he says. Anyone who disregards the policy does so at their peril. The main sanction is that expenses will not be reimbursed. That is easier now that many companies are replacing corporate credit cards with 'self-settling' cards paid off by the employee. 'You also have to get your expenses in on time in order to get the money back, which exerts an administrative discipline,' adds Platt. Companies such as Hogg Robinson operate increasingly sophisticated systems which not only alert managements to 'exceptions' - such as somebody who opts for a flight that is not the cheapest - but can even pass judgment on somebody's need to travel. One development that many would regard as positive is that the generosity of expenses - for example first-class rail or business-class air travel - is becoming less dependent on the status of the employee, and more on the length or frequency of the journey, or their need to be able to work during or after the trip. Matthew Davis, manager of consulting services in Europe for Amex, says: 'If a director travels once a year, he may be expected to go economy, but if an employee travels four times a month, it may be accepted that they need the extra comfort of business class.' Many companies allow busi ness class to be used if the journey is more than six hours - crossing the Atlantic, for example. For companies, the sheer cost of processing expenses can be draining. One way to cut it is to pay fixed allowances, rather than reimbursing bills. Such allowances, sometimes known as a 'per diem', can cover meals and overnight stays, and are used by many big companies, including BT. But according to David Wreford, a senior consultant with remuneration specialist William Mercer, that provides an incentive - perfectly legitimate - for the employee to keep spending to a minimum and pocket the balance. 'I've known people come on training courses with hypothermia because they had pocketed the allowance and spent the night in a bivvy bag in a field,' he says. Fiddling expenses - often described as the middle-class equivalent of benefits fraud - is taken very seriously by most companies, he says. You may receive an automatic final warning, or even be dismissed, if caught out. Phil Vickery, celebrity chef of Ready Steady Cook , was dismissed from the Castle Hotel in Taunton after claiming £1,444 expenses for a three-day trip to Venice with his girlfriend, which she later described as a 'birthday treat'. An employment tribunal ruled that he had not deliberately deceived the hotel and that his dismissal was unfair. According to Amex, most companies check claims to see if they are supported by receipts and added up correctly - and to judge whether they are reasonable. But it says that rather than checking every single claim, as more than half of all companies do, they should take a sample, or target claims that are exceptional or from past offenders. Davis says: 'I know of at least one significant multinational which figured out that there would always be a few people who fiddled their expenses, but that checking them would cost more than the amount cheated. So they stopped checking altogether.' Fraud aside, most companies recognise that there is a risk attached to tightening up on expenses, whether it be stamping on big lunch bills or forcing travellers on to Easyjet. Platt says: 'I believe most people see expenses as a justifiable reward for the fact that they have to leave their loved ones behind, and they feel they should damned well be allowed to do it in comfort. We have seen people who used to fly Club Class and have been downgraded to economy no longer heading straight back to the office when they get off their flight. 'At the end of the day, a happy traveller is a productive traveller.' Legitimate exes, not wild excesses 1: Get hold of the company policy. Although most companies have a policy on travel arrangements and expenses, staff are often not aware of these guidelines. 2: Keep all receipts. It sounds obvious, but many people fail to collect receipts, especially for smaller items such as bar bills. Without receipts your employer has an excuse not to reimburse you, and the Inland Revenue may judge that your claim is not exempt from tax. 3: Put your expenses in on time. In a well-run organisation, every department has a budget, and up-to-date management information is at a premium. You will not only put yourself in bad odour by claiming late, your claim may even be refused - especially if you have missed the end of one tax year. 4: Don't put personal spending on the company credit card. Although some companies don't outwardly discourage this practice, it simply muddies the waters about what is a legitimate business expense and what is not, and again may be frowned upon by the Revenue. 5: When in doubt, memo your manager. If you have any worry that your expenses won't be reimbursed, memo or email your manager beforehand. He or she may veto your lunch or your trip, but that's better than finding yourself seriously out of pocket. 6: Think what you would spend if it was your own money. If you're ever unsure what's an appropriate amount to be spending, imagine that you are on your own tab. Any wild excesses will soon disappear.

webTitle: Cheap loans for the careful could cost dear

fields.headline: Cheap loans for the careful could cost dear
fields.trailText: Barclays Bank is joining the cherry pickers, a group peopled mainly by insurers, whose numbers could soon be swelled by lenders.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank is joining the cherry pickers, a group peopled mainly by insurers, whose numbers could soon be swelled by lenders.

Barclays is planning to charge for loans at rates geared to customers' credit ratings. Barclays says wealth is not the issue; it will price according to ability to manage money. A regularly over drawn tycoon will be rated down; a prudent pensioner would do well.

That may be the case, but once risk-rated financing takes off, other institutions are unlikely to be quite so circumspect. So there is a social exclusion issue here.

However, the outlook for so-called higher-risk borrowers may not be as grim as it appears. Barclays, like all traditional high street banks, is not renowned for competitive mortgages, loans or credit cards. Competition in the lending market is already fierce, and the internet is helping drive down costs. There must be a chance that those quoted high rates by Barclays will get a better deal elsewhere, even if it is not as low as that perhaps offered to their neighbour.

Is the Government so desperate for good press that it is exploiting the relative obscurity of pensions? Last week it spelt out its latest plan, the Individual Pension Account. Hidden in the press bumph is the fact that this is not a new pension at all, but that's too complicated a story to unravel here. Suffice it to state that the latest development - a technical change allowing unit trust and investment trust managers to market pensions- will further improve the options for retirement saving. But the hype has exposed the public to yet more pension confusion.

webTitle: Can I fight back over tribunal 'evidence'?

fields.headline: Can I fight back over tribunal 'evidence'?
fields.standfirst: I was summoned to appear before a disciplinary tribunal over allegations that I have failed to meet performance targets and am poor at timekeeping. My boss gave a list of dates on which I had been late. It was very difficult for me to respond on the spot, although I am sure that she has noted me down as late several times when I was in another department. I think the tribunal is going to make its decision without more evidence from me. Is this fair?
fields.trailText: I was summoned to appear before a disciplinary tribunal over allegations that I have failed to meet performance targets and am poor at timekeeping. My boss gave a list of dates on which I had been late. It was very difficult for me to respond on the spot, although I am sure that she has noted me down as late several times when I was in another department. I think the tribunal is going to make its decision without more evidence from me. Is this fair?
fields.body:
Their treatment does not seem fair. Employment tribunals frequently find against employers who have failed to run a fair disciplinary and hearings system. It needs to be able to get your considered opinion. Best practice would have been to have allowed you at least a couple of days to investigate what you were doing on those dates.Or it could have asked your boss to summarise her evidence - including the dates - and give you a copy a few days before the hearing.

You could write a memo to the person chairing the hearing asking for more time. The chair would be unwise to ignore your request. If you were fired, a tribunal could well be sympathetic to your views.

The taking of witness statements is becoming increasingly common among employers who discipline staff in this way.

 Legal advice from Keoghs

webTitle: The risk more people find acceptable

fields.headline: The risk more people find acceptable
fields.standfirst: With interest rates low, investment bonds gain favour, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: With interest rates low, investment bonds gain favour, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
If you are thinking of buying an investment bond, you are most certainly not alone. Nearly 2 million people say they may buy one of these products in the next 12 months, according to researcher Mintel.

You are likely to be over 45, and could well be newly retired, says Mintel in Bonds , a report published last week. You are probably a taxpayer, quite possibly at the higher rate. You have a lump sum to invest - perhaps redundancy money, an inheritance, or savings you want to work more effectively. You are prepared to take some risk with your investment return, but the security of your capital is very important to you.

You are also twice as likely - according to the consumer research - to be married or cohabiting than living alone.

Mintel believes demand for these bonds will grow as more people look for a relatively conservative investment vehicle combined with attractive tax benefits. Many people who buy them are transferring money from deposit accounts - tired of getting poor returns in our low interest-rate environment.

Charles Levett-Scrivener of financial adviser Towry Law is a fan of these bonds in the right conditions. 'They have wide investment powers, so you can get a good degree of diversification even if you are just investing £5,000. The companies also make it relatively easy for large investors to get enhanced terms, which is something you don't get on unit trusts, where the standard charges apply to everybody.'

But if there is a fly in your ointment, it is the difficulty many have in understanding exactly what an investment bond is and how it works.

Investment choices

The most popular type of investment bond invests in an insurance company's with-profits fund. Although this type of fund is vulnerable to the fluctuating values of the assets it invests in - principally in the stock, fixed-interest and property markets - it uses a smooth ing effect to protect investors from fluctuations. Each year, the amount of your investment is increased as you receive your 'annual bonus'.

A with-profits bond is safer than a unit-linked bond because you cannot lose the value of your annual bonus once it has been allocated to you.

A with-profits bond can only ever increase in value, while a unit-linked bond can go up and down depending on the daily valuations of the assets it is invested in.

Distribution bonds are aimed at cautious investors who want income on a regular basis. The insurers try hard to ensure that the capital value does not fall by taking a rather conservative investment strategy.

Investors who want a predetermined return may prefer a guaranteed bond - either guaranteed equity or guaranteed income. This type of bond will typically guarantee you a fixed return on your capital if UK or other European stock markets rise by a given amount, stated by the insurer. Guaranteed income bonds are higher-risk.

Tax

An important reason for buying investment bonds is the beneficial tax treatment. If you are a basic-rate taxpayer and your withdrawals are less than 5 per cent of your original capital investment each year, you do not have to pay any tax on that income. If you are a higher-rate taxpayer, income tax liability is capped at 18 per cent of the income - the difference between the 40 per cent higher rate and 22 per cent basic. This is because the insurance company is treated as the bond's owner, so it pays tax on income earned at the basic rate.

Similarly, there is usually no personal liability to capital gains tax since the insurance company is seen as the fund owner and so discharges any CGT debts. (In some cases, however, there can be CGT - particularly with guaranteed equity bonds. Product innovation and rapid responses by the Inland Revenue have created a cat-and-mouse game on some tax liabilities.)

Length of investment

This depends on the type of bond you have invested in. Guaranteed bonds usually have a fixed term - you will either face hefty penalties if you withdraw money early or will simply be unable to access your cash.

With all the other types of bond you should not consider investing unless you are prepared to leave your capital in place for at least five years, preferably longer. You may face exit penalties before the fifth anniversary.

With-profits bond investors may also be subject to a 'market value adjustor', a downwards valuation, if they withdraw money after or during a market crash.

 For a free copy of the 'Chartwell Guide to Distribution Bonds' phone 01225 321710 or write to Chartwell, 9 Kingsmead Square, Bath, BA1 2AB.

fields.headline: Is your money in danger?
fields.standfirst: You don't have to be a financial anorak to tell a goldmine from a landmine, writes  Rachel Fixsen
fields.trailText: Whether it's a credit card or life insurance, buying financial products can feel like walking through a minefield. Without becoming an anorak on the subject, how can you avoid landing on an investment product that will blow up in your face?
fields.body:
Whether it's a credit card or life insurance, buying financial products can feel like walking through a minefield. Without becoming an anorak on the subject, how can you avoid landing on an investment product that will blow up in your face?

Ideally you should research every deal on the market to make sure you choose the best value. But if you can't choose the best, you can at least avoid the worst. In the past 10 years the financial services industry has made great strides in giving customers better value, with new products such as current account mortgages which let you offset savings and current account balances against mortgage borrowing, potentially saving you thousands in interest. And fierce competition in the savings market has spawned accounts that pay so much interest the institutions lose money on the deal.

But venturing into an industry with a history of rip-offs and scandals is nerve-racking, and choosing a new mortgage or savings product lacks the excitement associated with buying a new car, CD player or wardrobe. If you do not want to adopt personal finance as a hobby, but have the uncomfortable feeling you could be doing better with your money, one way to approach the problem is to become aware of the types of products to avoid. You can also improve your prospects by occasionally checking that the financial products you have are still offering a reasonable deal. Financial institutions make millions through customer inertia. Once in an investment plan, or stuck in the slow process of paying off a mortgage, customers happily forget the whole thing.

Despite the emergence of competitive products, many old-fashioned low-interest and inflexible deposit accounts still lurk in the shadows. Some even pay interest at below inflation, so in real terms your money is shrinking. Halifax has two accounts paying pitifully low rates. Its Card Cash account pays just 0.25 per cent, while the questionably named Liquid Gold account pays a maximum of 2.2 per cent, according to financial data provider Moneyfacts. Who would let their cash languish in those accounts when at the same institution another instant access account pays 5 per cent?

You might. Once savings are tucked away in a deposit account, it's tempting to put the passbook in a drawer and forget about the account until the money is needed. To make the most of your money it is vital to keep an eye on the rate of interest your account pays. Once an institution stops actively marketing a certain type of account, it often lets the rate fall behind the competition; instead it showers rewards on its latest savings head-turner. Dan Kemp of independent financial adviser Holden Meehan says many homeowners spend years paying their mortgage lenders interest at the standard variable rate, even though competitors offer discounted rates way below this. 'People get attracted to the lenders because of the rates in the first two or three years, and then they just stick around,' he says. 'Whenever a deal ends, be it fixed or discounted, people should always look at what others are prepared to lend them.'

The perceived cost of shifting a mortgage to another lender might put you off, but a number of mortgage providers now offer to pay not only the legal expenses of the move but also the property valuation. This may mean no cost for you at all.

It can be equally damaging to your wallet to choose a good-value product which happens to be unsuitable for you. Many people are sold life insurance when they have no dependants or anyone else who would suffer financially if they died. Or a self-employed person may take out payment protection insurance with a personal loan, even though the policy may cover employees only.

Philippa Gee, independent financial adviser at Shrewsbury-based firm Gee & Company, says: 'For someone who is willing to sacrifice higher rates of interest for security of capital, National Savings may be a suitable product, but for someone willing to take a bit more risk, it may not. Everyone should look at their own requirements.'

Potential customers should treat all financial advertising with healthy dose of cynicism. 'Everyone says they have the best Isa,' says Ted Lake, author of a new book, The Bad Investment Guide. 'They can't all be the best, but they don't make comparisons. Investment is all about alternatives, and people should stop and look at the alternatives.'

Lack of knowledge can easily turn a basically sound investment into a money-loser. Lake says he is continually surprised at the number of poor investment decisions people make. These have included leaving large sums in low-earning accounts, or more than necessary on instant access, and failing to use available tax breaks.

'Even if you leave all your money in high-earning accounts, over a long period they are a financial graveyard, because there can be no real income growth, no capital growth and no tax breaks to speak of.' He says people should be looking at stock market-based investments wherever possible.

Simply taking advice is no guarantee that you will manage to avoid poor money deals. While a good independent financial adviser should always point you in the right direction, one who is too easily tempted by those products which pay high levels of commission to advisers may not.

And many advisers, most notably bank and building society employees, are tied agents. They can only talk about or recommend products from a particular provider. Since they cannot give you comparisons with any other insurance firms' products, for example, you have no way of knowing whether what they are offering is good value or the worst deal on the market. 'People taking tied advice should recognise it is tied,' says Lake.

webTitle: Diary of a nobody, part two

fields.headline: Diary of a nobody, part two
fields.standfirst: Julie Burchill  charts the moans and minutiae of Derek Jarman's journal, Smiling in Slow Motion
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill charts the moans and minutiae of Derek Jarman's journal, Smiling in Slow Motion
fields.body:
Smiling in Slow Motion
Derek Jarman
Century, £16.99, 288pp
Buy it at BOL

Why do visual artists believe they can write? I would not dream of downing typewriter, running off to make a daubing, and then touting it in a public place. Neither would I prance around wielding a camcorder and expect the BFI to fund me. The two types of creative endeavour have absolutely nothing in common; indeed, if you are good at one of them you are likely to be even worse than a non-artist at the other. I can barely draw an Oxo cube, for instance, and most visual people write as though English is their second language - an exception being Tracey Emin, who writes very well.

But if Trace is the exception, then Derek Jarman is the rule - a man with a cauliflower where his ear for language should have been. Undeterred, he churned the books out like a good 'un, this posthumous collection of diaries being his twelfth published book. And while completely without artistic merit, the book will appeal greatly to those of us who have never reconciled themselves to the fact that Diary Of A Nobody had no sequel. A combination of Pooter, Hyacinth Bucket and Victor Meldrew, these diaries do have immense, if unintentional, comic appeal.

Like Pooter, Jarman believes that nothing is so dull that it will not be improved by documentation: "Disturbed by a large owl. Polished the floors", "Shopping at Sainsbury's", "We are expecting rain. The garden could do with it", "Bought a pullover at M&S" and "Spent the afternoon sewing buttons on to shirts" are all worthy of the Grossmiths.

Then there are the exciting Epicurean experiments: "Very good lunch - chops, purple cabbage and semolina" and "I cooked an excellent picnic lunch - new potatoes, ham and salad." Though in his fifties at the time, Jarman exhibits all the blind dedication to his diary of a little girl of eight presented with her very first. At some points things get so desperate you almost expect him to write "wrote in diary" just to break the monotony.

He doesn't seem to like his fellow friends of Dorothy an awful lot. Simon Callow? "Bumbling old vulgarian." Ruldolf Nureyev? "A sad little man from Siberia." Oscar Wilde? "Infuriating - the life more interesting than the writing." I think we can best illustrate the accuracy of Jarman's judgments by quoting his opinion of Brighton: "It is often violent, and there are no queers there." Spot on, Del.

But the laffs end and the tedium increases as whole swathes of the planet are written off, and not even with originality or wit.

The Blimpishness that Jarman decried in others was well present and correct in himself; people "deserve to be shot" and, elsewhere, he congratulates himself on his "political incorrectness", the boast of the smug saloon-bar bore the world over. But to Jarman, heterosexuals are not quite human, and have no feelings to be hurt: "The onus is on heterosexuals to explain themselves, their behaviour and the evil they have brought us. They need to come out, not us, and face the prosecution. It's they who have warped sexuality, who have murdered and driven innocents to suicide, they who should ask for forgiveness." OK, Del, I admit it - it was me. I did that stuff. Can I go home now?

Londoners are "ever uglier", Germans "thieving sauerkrauts"; Vienna is "just a grand piano - places are no longer of interest to the sophisticated". Strangers on a train are "Thatcher's rat-faced mortgagees, not one brain cell amongst them." Here, if we needed it, is proof of Jarman's complete lack of sensibility: would any true artist, be they writer, painter or filmmaker, see in a rush-hour railway carriage this seething mass of loathsomeness rather than a group of individuals with their thwarted dreams and desires? Most of us are over this kind of cheap misanthropy by the time we're halfway through our teens.

At least they weren't children, who Jarman hates as fervently as any uptight old colonel: "I really do hate children on aeroplanes - they should be banned"; the East End is "full of gangs of sub-human children". Isn't tolerance a wonderful thing? And don't we all breathe a sigh of relief when we're back in the civilised company of Derek's friends, such as Karl, who for kicks - get this - goes around Hampstead Heath collecting used condoms AND EATING THEM! Only the wonderful Neil Tennant emerges with any glory, asking Jarman, who is about to visit Jimmy Somerville, if he can pass on a message. The message? "Piss off, Mary, I'm Head Fairy!" The Neil Tennant diaries - now they would be worth reading.

webTitle: Guardian review: Inside Stalin's Russia by Reader Bullard

fields.headline: In Stalin's shadow
fields.standfirst: Reader Bullard's diaries, Inside Stalin's Russia, show that he was not one of those taken in by the Soviet propaganda machine
fields.trailText: Reader Bullard's diaries, Inside Stalin's Russia, show that he was not one of those taken in by the Soviet propaganda machine
fields.body:
Inside Stalin's Russia: The Diaries of Reader Bullard 1930-1934
edited by Julian and Margaret Bullard
Day Books, £19.50, 320pp
Buy it at BOL

Soviet communism was an economic catastrophe right from the start. And despite the government's attempts to hide the truth, the squalor that followed poverty was too desperate to hide. In the summer of 1932, "Cairns, a Canadian, employed by the Empire Marketing Board... visited western Siberia, Kazakhstan, various places along the Volga, the Ukraine, Crimea and Northern Caucasus", and reported what he saw to Reader Bullard, the British consul general in Moscow.

"Everywhere large areas formerly cultivated were bare except for weeds." The results of "collectivisation" were visible at every railway station - "hundreds of people, many asleep, many begging, many just shivering in their rags". At Tatarskia, children "scrambled to lick the soup plates and eat the bones" after the workers had eaten their rations of "soup, two small slices of black bread and a small piece of fish".

Similar scenes could be observed all over the Soviet Union. While the kulaks - the small landowners who might have kept Russia fertile - were exiled to the mines (where "many hundreds died of exposure, typhus and smallpox"), the British ambassador "remarked that probably a couple of million people would die of hunger this winter, but the authorities would not mind that". Yet men and women of immense intellect and otherwise undoubted integrity visited Moscow and announced that they had witnessed the dawn of a new civilisation. Bernard Shaw said that communist propaganda in schools was no different from the religious instruction which was forced on British pupils. Beatrice Webb was shocked only by the authorities' failure to ban lipstick.

Bullard always recorded the visit of a "fair-minded" observer in his diary; Malcolm Muggeridge was particularly commended for filing "strong" articles to the Manchester Guardian. And his own daily entries were a model of careful, if occasionally regretful, objectivity. Bullard had gone to Moscow anxious "to judge for himself the success or failure of the socialist experiment... having started life as a poor boy in the East End of London, he felt instinctive sympathy" for the aims of the new regime.

However, he quickly found its tyranny and cruelty intolerable. When it became clear that the forced labour, suppression of free speech and bureaucratic corruption did not even produce the promised economic results, the disillusion was complete. But he retained both his sense of proportion and his charitable impulse. Bullard understood why Jews never spoke out against Soviet excesses. The tsars had kept them at the bottom of the heap; under communism, they were treated no worse than anyone else.

Bullard's diaries were composed with care for more than their objectivity. Knowing the penalty of attacking the communist leadership, he wrote his most startling revelations and stringent criticisms in code. It was cracked by his granddaughter, who thus opened the way for his son (Sir Julian Bullard, himself a distinguished diplomat) and daughter-in-law to edit this fascinating account of life under the commissars.

Although the Diaries cover only four years, they leave no doubt of the innate evil of Stalin's Soviet Union. The account of the 1931 beginning of the reign of terror, 1932 famine and 1933 prosecution of Metro-Vickers workers who were accused of spying will be of most value to historians. The journal is also a pleasure to read for anyone who appreciates straightforward English, and contains hilarious examples of the tribulations that are inseparable from the diplomatic life. Lady Muriel Paget, intent on doing good works, and her assistant Mrs Daunt are characters straight out of Anthony Powell.

No doubt Julian and Margaret Bullard were, at least in part, moved to edit the diaries because of their affection for a clearly remarkable man. But the result of their work, whatever it owes to filial piety, stands firmly on its own literary and historical merits. It is a savage condemnation of the inter-war Soviet Union. But it is also heartening proof that a clear head and hopeful heart can react to even the most hideous environment with clarity and courage.

fields.headline: Calcutta, Co. Armagh, Head over heels ( for C)  and Wedding the Locksmith's Daughter
fields.trailText:
Like candy-striped corner-store bags

caught in the trees or snagged in razor-wire,

the washed-out Union flags

tatter at every lamppost...
fields.body:
Calcutta, Co. Armagh

Like candy-striped corner-store bags
caught in the trees or snagged in razor-wire,
the washed-out Union flags
tatter at every lamppost.

Under closed-circuit cameras, holding crisps
and Cokes, in their uniform of bubble-perms
or gel, a street of raw faces stares up,
open-mouthed, at the bus.

Outside the black fort, April lays siege;
everything breaking out in green: a green
straked through with white bands of hawthorn
and the sharp, bright, mustard-gold of gorse.

Head over heels ( for C)

Holding hands on the big wheel
fifty feet above the Tuileries'
evening jasmine, I loved
your play at fear,
my brave stab at insouciance,
the way the bright circuitry of Paris
lay beneath us like the night sky,
like the plan of our lives.

Wedding the Locksmith's Daughter

The slow-grained slide to embed the blade
of the key is a sheathing,
a gliding on graphite, pushing inside
to find the ribs of the lock.
Sunk home, the true key slots to its matrix;
geared, tight-fitting, they turn
together, shooting the spring-lock,
throwing the bolt. Dactyls, iambics -
the clinch of words - the hidden couplings
in the cased machine. A chime of sound
on sound: the way the sung note snibs on meaning
and holds. The lines engage and marry now,
their bells are keeping time;
the church doors close and open underground.

webTitle: House of Leaves by Mark Z Danielewski review - genuinely exciting

fields.headline: House of Leaves by Mark Z Danielewski review - genuinely exciting
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole is intrigued by the warping of space in House of Leaves
fields.trailText: Steven Poole is intrigued by the warping of space in House of Leaves
fields.body:
House of Leaves
Mark Z Danielewski
Anchor, £13, 709pp
Buy it at BOL

Borges once explained in an interview that he often had ideas for esoteric books, which, however, he could not bring himself to write. Instead, he would pretend the books already existed, and write fictions around them. As a cunning footnoted allusion in this novel to Borges's story "Pierre Menard, Author of the Quixote" reveals, Mark Danielewski has stolen the idea and built an enormous, scholarly-gothic fiction around a non-existent film.

The film, The Navidson Record, is a documentary made by Will Navidson, a photojournalist who has forsaken war zones in order to repair his marriage. Together with his wife Karen and their two children, Navidson moves into a pretty house in the country and sets up Hi-8 cameras in every room, thinking to make a homely family record. But everything is not as it seems. While working on the house one day, Navidson discovers that it measures three quarters of an inch longer on the inside than on the outside.

Navidson calls friends and borrows tools to try to eliminate the illusion, but it persists. And then, between two adjoining rooms, there opens up an impossible 10-foot hallway, black and icy. There is something very wrong. The Navidson Record becomes a vérité horror film as Will and his friends try to explore the anomalous space, which rearranges itself periodically with a roar, and expands into terrifying volumes of darkness.

The main text of House of Leaves is written by an old man, Zampanò, who became obsessed with the film on its limited public release. As well as a long exegesis of the film's narrative, Zampanò conducts a thorough synthesis of the mountain of scholarly and critical material that has grown up around the film, making use of published interviews with the surviving protagonists and carefully considering feminist, post-structuralist, Freudian, Jungian, deconstructionist and purely cinéaste-aesthetic readings of The Navidson Record.

Danielewski thus weaves around his brutally efficient and genuinely chilling story a delightful and often very funny satire of academic criticism. In one way, and after the manner of Moby-Dick, the novel is its own Leviathan commentary (Danielewski even collects a Melvillean encyclopaedia of quotations about houses in one of the book's voluminous appendices). Every possible mythological and literary analysis of the story of Navidson's house is already provided in the text, but the house's impossibly vast, dark interior spaces, like the White Whale, finally shrug off all projected interpretation. Yet even that is not enough: Danielewski piles on even more narrative frames, ultimately to the novel's detriment.

Writing footnotes to Zampanò's footnotes is a young apprentice LA tattooist called Johnny Truant, who finds the old man's box of papers after he dies and decides to turn them into a publishable book (occasionally Truant's own words are mediated through a final scholarly lens, that of "The Editors"). Truant notes the baffling fact that since Zampanò (like Borges) was blind, he could never have seen The Navidson Record himself.

But Truant himself is an unlikeable, feckless character: he continually interrupts the text to harangue us about his mad mother, his cloying love for a stripper called Thumper, and, since he began work on Zampanò's papers, his increasing, disabling fear - all in such a raggedly purple style that he quickly becomes very annoying. He is in the end one narrator too many.

House of Leaves, even so, is a superbly inventive creation. It is not mere genre fiction, because the author so gleefully ignores the conventions of horror: no finally unmasked monster, no ghosts, no malign extraterrestrials. There is only the house. A diabolic architectural analogue of Borges's universal library, the house perturbs the reader's imagination because space - the dispensation of walls and floors, the certainty of relative topography - is normally the one thing we can rely on absolutely. The thousands of miles of pitchy corridors, vast vaulted caverns and spiral staircases opening up within the house are an affront not just to reason but to that pre-rational, hard-wired faith that enables us to move at all. Will Navidson eventually returns to the house because he has decided that it is God.

In its meditation on the fragility of space the novel includes its own textual layout. A labyrinthine chapter prints boxed paragraphs extruded from other paragraphs, lists running backwards or upside down; at other times, the reader finds a series of pages with just one or two lines on them, and turns rapidly; at yet others, one is made to slow down by rotating the whole book at an angle. Every derangement of the page-space deftly mimes the current derangement of the house-space in the narrative.

Further delicious textual mysteries include the fact that the word "house" itself, whether in English, German or French, is always printed in grey and baseline-shifted upwards, as if bashed out on a dodgy old typewriter; and that every reference to the myth of the Minotaur by Zampanò has been violently struck through.

It is not often that a reviewer devours a 700-page novel at one sitting; but I did, recklessly ignoring slimmer volumes that had more urgent claims upon my attention. House of Leaves is partly hobbled by the invasive, unconvincing voice of Johnny Truant, but it is nonetheless a rare debut: genuinely exciting in its technical and literary exuberance. If The Blair Witch Project were a true documentary, and there were a tireless new Borges around to analyse it, the result might be something like this deeply interesting book.

webTitle: Guardian review: Rebellion by Joseph Roth

fields.headline: In his own corner
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on Joseph Roth's dream-like tale of an idiot haunting Europe, Rebellion
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Joseph Roth's dream-like tale of an idiot haunting Europe, Rebellion
fields.body:
Rebellion
Joseph Roth, translated by Michael Hofmann
(Granta, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Congratulations to Granta, who have, with this, now made all Joseph Roth's completed novels available in English for the first time. Roth is one of those writers perhaps more heard of than read (his novel The Legend of the Holy Drinker was made into a fine film, starring Rutger Hauer, in 1988); now is your chance to catch up on him.

This isn't a representative Roth novel, it has to be said. Roth - alcoholic yet industrious; journalist and novelist; a pacifist with a military bearing - was a bundle of contradictions at the best of times, not that there were, for him, many good times at all. Growing up poor, with no father, he was intelligent enough to be sceptical about the Austro-Hungarian Empire that nurtured him, yet at the same time under no illusions about any of the political alternatives that came to be offered after the first world war.

As Michael Hofmann points out in his excellent introduction, he went to Soviet Russia in 1926 - two years after Rebellion - as an idealist and came back, as Walter Benjamin disappointedly noted, a royalist. He came to view the Empire with a strange, bleak kind of nostalgia, like someone who has lost his religion and then half-found it again.

And this is one of the interesting things about Roth: he seems to treat the State as if it were God, and God as if he were some kind of bureaucratic arm of the State. In Rebellion he writes: "The government is something that overlies man like the sky overlies the earth. What comes from it may be good or ill, but it cannot be other than great and all-powerful, unknowable and mysterious, even though on occasion it may be understood by an ordinary person."

Those, neatly ventriloquized, are the thoughts of the ordinary person at the heart and centre-stage of Rebellion: Andreas Pum, a war veteran who has lost a leg but has a permit to play the hurdy-gurdy on the street. Pum is, frankly, an idiot; and whether his government-worship is a function of his cretinism, or the other way round, is something that Roth leaves for us to decide for ourselves.

Pum thinks of criminals and malcontents as "heathens", until one day he falls foul of the law. Imprisoned for six weeks, he undergoes an overwhelming change of body and heart, and, reduced to both senility and the position of a lavatory attendant, becomes himself one of those malcontents he used to loathe.

Roth's tale has that very European, straightforward, fairy-tale logic that makes everything both inevitable yet strangely nightmarish. You wouldn't be far wrong to think of Roth as occupying the fourth corner of a square whose other apices are Kafka, Musil and Stefan Zweig. But Roth's position was mutable.

Here, in his second acknowledged novel (he disowned his first), he is still the angry left-winger, an almost didactic fabulist. You can already tell, though, that he's more than just a polemicist. At one or two points the novel leaps into strange, almost magical-realist territory; not a term I like much, but it suggests the sense of dreamlike dislocation you feel from time to time while reading. This portrait of one of the shards of a splintering society is deceptively simple, but will haunt you for a long time afterwards.

webTitle: Guardian review: Why Angels Fall by Victoria Clark

fields.headline: Clerics' crisis
fields.standfirst: Martin Woollacott  on Victoria Clark's survey of the religious dividing line in European war, Why Angels Fall
fields.trailText: Martin Woollacott on Victoria Clark's survey of the religious dividing line in European war, Why Angels Fall
fields.body:
Why Angels Fall: A Journey through Orthodox Europe from Byzantium to Kosovo
Victoria Clark
Macmillan, £18.99, 460pp
Buy it at BOL

When Kosovo and Serbia burned last year, the glare of war illuminated a division in our continent that we had almost forgotten - not the one between ex-communist and capitalist countries, but that between western Christendom and Orthodoxy. Poles and Hungarians tended to side with the Nato countries, while the sympathies of most people in Orthodox Europe were with Serbia, even where their governments cooperated with the Alliance.

Looking as if for the first time at this unfamiliar twin, the west saw anger, resentment, a sense of injustice, all the marks of a civilisation for which history has been a disappointment rather than a vindication. The Orthodox countries had followed the true faith and ought to have prospered, yet Orthodoxy had suffered terribly at the hands of both Muslims and western Christians. As some saw it in impoverished Russia, embattled Serbia or even culturally threatened Greece, this road to Calvary was far from over.

Victoria Clark's inspiration was to trace this alienation not in a general or analytical way, but through a secular pilgrimage to the holy places of Orthodoxy and through interview after dogged interview with Orthodox clergy.

She found well-fed bishops presiding over new or renovated churches and monasteries, for Orthodoxy's first act after the communist regimes fell was to recover and expand its real estate, and then to embark on a building programme of grandiose proportions. At the other extreme she also found vodka priests to rival any of Graham Greene's fallen men of the cloth, trying to do their best in hopeless, dirt-poor Russian towns. And she found, here and there on her long trail from freezing Solovetsky island in the White Sea to Kykko in the Troodos mountains above the Mediterranean, a few truly outstanding men - sensitive, far-seeing and generous souls.

But the physical resurgence of the Orthodox churches, she suggests, is not in general matched by real spiritual confidence, certainly if the main characteristic of such confidence is seen as tolerance. The Orthodox churches are intolerant of anyone who chooses a secular path, of other forms of Christianity - at best inferior, at worst heretical - and even of each other.

Serbian monks, for instance, have to change into civilian clothes when they travel through Macedonia, the independence of whose church they do not recognise and which therefore does not recognise them. Worse, the Orthodox churches shelter and nurture not only chauvinism of both the national and the male variety but anti-semitism, irrationalism and paranoia.

Many Russian Orthodox clergy have no doubt that the Russian royal family were killed by Jews, and many Greek priests are convinced that 666, the number of the beast, is to be inscribed on Greek identity cards as part of the Antichrist's campaign against true religion. Most Orthodox clergy everywhere believe that the Nato bombing of Kosovo was part of that same demonic plot. As the author again and again encounters such ideas and attitudes, the reader shares her disappointment, especially when a cleric had initially seemed engaging or impressive, or both.

And yet churches, like men, are not all of a piece. Archbishop Christodoulos of Greece, whose slogan is "Orthodoxy is cool", is presently wasting his prestige in a foolish campaign over the removal of religious affiliation from those same identity cards. By contrast, one of the author's favourites, Father Sava of Decani monastery in Kosovo, continues to plead for tolerance by both sides in that place and notes that Muslims visited Kosovo's ancient churches as often as Christians.

The Orthodox churches, like the societies they serve, are trying to pull themselves up by their bootstraps from a condition of political and economic underdevelopment. Their coexistence with democracy, in most cases, has only just begun, and their engagement with secular values has yet to acquire the complexity that marks Christian life and belief in the west.

One question that the nature of her journey does not allow Clark to explore is how influential the Orthodox churches and their clergy actually are in the different Orthodox countries. Are the people listening?

Orthodox worship, preaching and works in the religious sense, as she says, have always been different from their Catholic and Protestant equivalents. They may have less impact on political attitudes today, in any case, than they did in the past. Liberal ideas are also entrenched in east European societies, just as irrational and chauvinist ideas exist and sometimes prosper in western countries. In Bulgaria, for example, which was unfortunately not on her itinerary, the rescue and reinstatement of the Turkish Muslim minority was the first demand of the opposition which brought down the old regime.

The Orthodox countries may, in the end, be less different from western societies than a book that concentrates on the clerical calling may suggest. But this piece of fascinating reporting certainly raises the question of the nature and degree of that difference in a new and sharper form.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: The perfect fairy tale for grown-ups about to take their summer holidays, plus The Horizontal Instrument, The Requiem Shark and Girl With a Pearl Earring
fields.body:
Music & Silence
Rose Tremain
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Tremain's Whitbread prize-winner is the perfect fairy tale for grown-ups about to take their summer holidays. Courtly love, kings and queens and palace intrigue in watery Denmark make for the kind of luscious, swallow-in-one-sitting story you think disappeared with childhood. Peter Claire arrives with his lute and angelic blond locks at the court of Christian IV at the same time as a Jutland lady-in-waiting to the king's wife. The melancholic king and his lustful comic consort are out of love, but not so Peter and Emilia. Tremain treads lightly over the past, using it to transport the reader and letting us get on with researching Danish history ourselves.

The Horizontal Instrument
Christopher Wilkins
(Anchor, £5)
Buy it at BOL

You learn an awful lot about the history of watchmaking, and suffer Bergsonian meditations on time and memory, in Wilkins's debut novel. Its pre-millennial, post-Longtitude hardback appearance made me suspect a writer with an eye to marketability. But horology aside, the remaining third of the book, "dealing with watchmaker Robert Garrett's loss of his wife and his struggle to make the world's most accurate timepiece in her memory", has moments of aching tenderness. Once you grasp the fearsomely difficult mechanics of Garrett's task, you regret that his relationship with Elizabeth, the woman who occasions such labour, is not dealt with at greater length.

The Requiem Shark
Nicholas Griffin
(Abacus, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

As Patrick O'Brien proved countless times, maritime adventures are always a sure bet for landlubber readers. Griffin has taken an historical figure, "pirate captain Bartholomew Roberts", and given him a fictional chronicler, fellow Welshman William Williams, to narrate his voyages between the Guinea coast and the Americas. Alternating episodes of tars sodden with rum and swashbuckling bouts of battle are strung together by Roberts's great-white-whale quest for the gold-laden Juliette. Griffin provides vivid gore over the decks, upsets in the heads and much salty-sea lingo exchanged by excitable hands, but with hardly a woman on the horizon, The Requiem Shark is definitely a yarn for boys by the seaside.

Girl With a Pearl Earring
Tracy Chevalier
(Harper Collins, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

Poor Griet is burdened by more than having to scrub the Vermeer family smalls in this fictional biography of a painting. She is constructing a colour wheel from the ingredients of the family soup when she catches the attention of the man with the palette. Soon she is up in the studio mixing his paints and dreaming of becoming her master's muse. Happily, Chevalier's heroine does not do a crit, but unfortunately Griet, unlike a Vermeer, lacks a point of focus. Her observations on the Vermeers, the social mores of Delft circa 1665 and the lot of a servant are surface-deep and leave you wondering what the point was of placing Griet in this setting.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Deep background on Eastern Europe until Constantinople's fall in 1453, plus St Mark's Basilica
fields.body:
The Byzantine Commonwealth
Dimitri Obolensky
(Phoenix, £16.99)
Buy it at BOL

Deep background on Eastern Europe until Constantinople's fall in 1453. Great early chapters on very pushy economic migrants from the Eurasian steppes settling and unsettling the continent from the Baltic to the Bosphorus. The Turkic Bulgars defiantly flying their horsetail banners, the Rus river-dwellers of Kiev in the amber and timber trade with Vikings, the legendary Crimean Khazars, so determined to remain independent of both orthodox Byzantium and the Islam of their Baghdad-based enemies that they converted direct from shamanism to Judaism. And every capture of a city, every minuscule, Cyrillic letter reverberates still.

St Mark's Basilica
Ettore Vio
(Thames & Hudson, £16.95)

And here, in glimpses and gilt glints of Venice's core church, is what we have left of the island synthesis of Latin west and Greek east Rome. The bronze chariot horses from Byzantium's Hippodrome now pawing a museum's deadly safe air; the golden altarpiece of looted (just occasionally bought) Byzantine enamels, pebbled by unfaceted gems and with the holy halo'd in pearls; the domes' cladding fabulous with camels, peacocks and angels; the piteous fragment of women lamenting the dead Christ, wiping their weeping eyes with chador-wraps - exactly like a modern news photograph, but executed in rough mosaic circa AD 976.
