webTitle: Guardian review: A La Recherche du Temps Perdu by Craig Raine

fields.headline: Dismembering Kitty
fields.standfirst: Robert Potts cringes at Craig Raine's bathetic elegy, A La Recherche du Temps Perdu
fields.trailText: Robert Potts cringes at Craig Raine's bathetic elegy, A La Recherche du Temps Perdu
fields.body:
A La Recherche du Temps Perdu: A Poem
Craig Raine
Picador, £8, 41pp

It takes a formidable arrogance to publish a book of only 40 pages under the title A La Recherche du Temps Perdu, but Craig Raine has always displayed the necessary qualities for such a task. This slim volume, an elegy for a lover, Kitty Mrosovsky, who died of Aids, comes readily adorned with dust-jacket quotes suggesting that Raine can now be ranked alongside Auden, Berryman, Browning and Conrad.

Ian McEwan (himself, surely, mentioned in the text: "our mutual friends/ the Martins, Julians and Ians") provides one of them. Raine's poem cites Conrad's statement that the author should aim to "make you hear, to make you feel...// above all, to make you see". McEwan says that Raine has done this. So does Raine. And certainly, in what Talk magazine considers "one of the great long poems written in English this century", we do indeed see something; even if it is only that "all publishing was corrupt and nasty/ and I should know". The poem was, in fact, first published in Talk and republished in Arete, a magazine edited by... Craig Raine.

All this puff and fluff, though, is merely a welcome distraction from the work itself. Raine, grieving for his lover, and a little worried that she might have left him something more viral than memories, proceeds to reconstruct her in poetry. It's a traditional approach, and his chosen form (uneven and off-rhymed couplets) is not exactly innovative.

Raine has apparently remarked that his poem "remakes what the elegy might be in English". We can be charitable here, and assume that he is joking. There has been no shortage of elegy in contemporary poetry - Thom Gunn's The Man With Night Sweats and Paul Muldoon's "Incantata" stand out in recent years - and though the blurb-writers think reconstructing lost love is a novel manoeuvre, it is not.

Love and grief are obsessive states; writing is, inevitably, a therapeutic process for dealing with loss. The big question is always why the private process should be made public; traditionally, the answer has been that love and grief are such common states that readers will be able to match the poet's consolations with their own. Most poets now address these issues within their writing (Peter Reading: "others' bereavements don't marvel readers... and it's pathetic and mad to address yourself to the dead"; Stephen Romer: "Am I changed or not, if I tell this tale?"). Raine does at one point ask "What has all this to do with anyone else?/ Why all these intimate details?", but the question is rhetorical at best; there is no serious attempt to grapple with it thereafter.

Instead, after an itemisation, throughout the poem, of her body hair (20 chin hairs, nine around the nipples), breasts (large ones, "melons"), eyes (green), legs (shaven; "sleek and sexual as stripped twigs", which surely means not sexual at all), cheekbones ("high"), hair ("dark, brown, fine") and "bush" ("black, smoking"- smoking?), he concludes: "And now I have re-membered you." But poetically, he has precisely dismembered her in a series of synechdoches, the efficient and reductive trope of pornography.

What have been reconstructed are Raine's extremely mixed feelings about a woman whose work he seems not to have liked, whose musical ear was dodgy, who "fucked everyone", whose "cunt" and "arsehole" receive more attention in his poem than her face and who was - a breathtaking accusation from Raine - "a literary snob".

The rest of the poem comprises Raine's memories of the affair - times, places, restaurants, even his own witticisms ("you laughed at my joke", he recalls happily) - rendered in couplets which are occasionally vivid or clever, but more often descend into banality or bathos ("I can't accept you're dead./ You're still here, in my head"; "Had been taught Sidney (not Wyatt)/ by 'the writer, Antonia Byatt' ").

Half-rhymed irregular couplets can be a remarkably effective vehicle for combining narrative and reflection: Stephen Romer's Idols, about the process of grief and writing after a love affair, is a truly fine example of this, while its allusions to art and literature are worked into the architecture of the volume rather than merely furnishing it. Raine, a writer who first gained attention with the overtly contrived metaphors of A Martian Sends A Postcard Home, is surprisingly flat in this poem, which periodically seems to aspire to prose.

"Details that make the reader cringe /will make the reader see,/ see the self you showed to me", Raine writes. But it is not the details that make the reader cringe, so much as the execution. Poor Kitty Mrosovsky, hectored post mortem by a self-regarding Raine, unable to answer back; poor readers, witnessing this, lectured at obliquely. In his descriptions of what seems to have been, by and large, some less than excellent intercourse, he says "You taught me sex/ was conversation and not a speech". This, one suspects, is a lesson the implications of which Raine has not quite mastered yet.

Raine does at one point ask "What has all this to do with anyone else?/ Why all these intimate details?", but the question is rhetorical at best; there is no serious attempt to grapple with it thereafter. Instead, after an itemisation, throughout the poem, of her body hair (20 chin hairs, nine around the nipples), breasts (large ones, "melons"), eyes (green), legs (shaven; "sleek and sexual as stripped twigs", which surely means not sexual at all), cheekbones ("high"), hair ("dark, brown, fine") and "bush" ("black, smoking"- smoking?), he concludes: "And now I have re-membered you." But poetically, he has precisely dismembered her in a series of synechdoches, the efficient and reductive trope of pornography. What have been reconstructed are Raine's extremely mixed feelings about a woman whose work he seems not to have liked, whose musical ear was dodgy, who "fucked everyone", whose "cunt" and "arsehole" receive more attention in his poem than her face and who was - a breathtaking accusation from Raine - "a literary snob". The rest of the poem comprises Raine's memories of the affair - times, places, restaurants, even his own witticisms ("you laughed at my joke", he recalls happily) - rendered in couplets which are occasionally vivid or clever, but more often descend into banality or bathos ("I can't accept you're dead./ You're still here, in my head"; "Had been taught Sidney (not Wyatt)/ by 'the writer, Antonia Byatt' "). Half-rhymed irregular couplets can be a remarkably effective vehicle for combining narrative and reflection: Stephen Romer's Idols, about the process of grief and writing after a love affair, is a truly fine example of this, while its allusions to art and literature are worked into the architecture of the volume rather than merely furnishing it. Raine, a writer who first gained attention with the overtly contrived metaphors of A Martian Sends A Postcard Home, is surprisingly flat in this poem, which periodically seems to aspire to prose. "Details that make the reader cringe /will make the reader see,/ see the self you showed to me", Raine writes. But it is not the details that make the reader cringe, so much as the execution. Poor Kitty Mrosovsky, hectored post mortem by a self-regarding Raine, unable to answer back; poor readers, witnessing this, lectured at obliquely. In his descriptions of what seems to have been, by and large, some less than excellent intercourse, he says "You taught me sex/ was conversation and not a speech". This, one suspects, is a lesson the implications of which Raine has not quite mastered yet.

webTitle: Guardian review: A Heartbreaking Work... by Dave Eggers

fields.headline: Come to the cabaret
fields.standfirst: Failed at TV? Try writing.  Adam Begley  on Dave Eggers' disarming talent for self-publicity in A Heartbreaking Work...
fields.trailText: Failed at TV? Try writing. Adam Begley on Dave Eggers' disarming talent for self-publicity in A Heartbreaking Work...
fields.body:
A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
Dave Eggers
Picador, £9.99, 375pp
Buy it at BOL

What would Dave Eggers have done with his life had his parents not died of cancer, one after the other, in the space of 32 days, leaving him - a boyish 21-year-old - to care for his eight-year-old brother? Tragedy deprived him of his parents and made him his brother's keeper; it also gave him his story, the heartbreaking story that called forth his staggering genius. What would he have done without it?

The easy answer is that he would have done what he does now (now that he has turned 30 and published a bestselling memoir), which is to edit McSweeney's, a delightful and unclassifiable publication, supposedly quarterly, that has appeared four times since the fall of 1998.

Eggers has gathered a smart group of contributors, mostly young, a few known to the novel-reading public (David Foster Wallace, Rick Moody, Jonathan Lethem) and many of them living in Brooklyn, New York. Like filigree around the assembled short stories, essays, spoofs and prose experiments, Eggers editorialises in manic fine print. A maze of text and diagram, the magazine is witty, self-conscious, eclectic, casually postmodern, eager to please, not bothered about giving offence - and endlessly ironic.

If you want the flavour of McSweeney's, open A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius and take a look at the "Rules and Suggestions for Enjoyment of this Book" (in which he allows that the first 109 pages "are all some of you might want to bother with... The book thereafter is kind of uneven"), the "Preface to this Edition" ("For all the author's bluster elsewhere, this is not, actually, a work of pure non-fiction. Many parts have been fictionalised in varying degrees, for various purposes") and the "Acknowledgments" ("The author would like to acknowledge that he does not look good in red... Further, the author, and those behind the making of this book, would like to acknowledge that yes, there are perhaps too many memoir-sorts of books being written at this juncture") - in all, nearly 40 pages of clever throat-clearing before you get to chapter one, where the heartbreak begins.

Before McSweeney's there was Might, a satirical magazine for twentysomethings. Its motto was "Screw Those Idiots". The "kind of uneven" last two thirds of A Heartbreaking Work tell the story of how Eggers and a few friends launched, laboured over and eventually abandoned Might. But though Might had its moment and McSweeney's has acquired a chic cult following, editing quarterlies is a slow path to stardom, and Eggers craves fame. In the five months since the US publication of his Heartbreaking Work, following an avalanche of rave reviews, he has allowed his diva temperament to blossom.

I suspect he would have liked to be a pop star, or a professional athlete. After the trauma of his parents' death (the father's sudden, the mother's lingering, and achingly evoked), Eggers and his little brother, Toph, headed west from the posh Chicago suburb where they were raised; in California, driving to the beach, they sing. "There are times when I'm concerned about Toph's expression when I'm really singing, with vibrato and all, singing the guitar parts and everything - an expression that to the untrained eye might look like abject terror, or revulsion - but I know well enough that it is awe." It's an exhilarating scene, youth's escape from the sickroom, and when they reach the beach, there's more exhilaration. They play frisbee: "Oh, we are good. He's only eight but together we are spectacular."

Eggers tried hard to break into television - he wanted a part in MTV's Real World. He documents his audition and turns it into a postmodern commentary on his own self-conscious self-promotion. It's not normally a star-making profession, but Eggers could have become a book reviewer. I can't think of a single complaint about his book (and I have many, including sloppiness, solipsism and triteness) that the author hasn't already generously pointed out. "He too is well aware of all of the book's flaws and shortcomings, whatever you consider them to be, and... tips his hat to you for noticing them." Preempting criticism doesn't necessarily make it go away, but it does inhibit the poor critic.

Of course, without tragedy Eggers might have become a novelist. His prose is loose-jointed, colloquial, relaxed-looking but capable of piercing accuracy. When he drops the gimmicks, he can be hilarious and devastating - sometimes both at once. Of course, he knows this. He tells the MTV executive, "I can do it funny, or maudlin, or just straight, uninflected - anything. You tell me. I can do it sad, or inspirational, or angry."

The first chapter, about his parents' decline, is a kind of terminal-patient slapstick, a queasy, improbable routine that works: "You should see the area where her stomach was. It's grown like a pumpkin. Round, bloated. It's odd - they removed the stomach, and some of the surrounding area if I remember correctly, but even with the removal of so much thereabouts, she looks pregnant. You can see it, the bulge, even under the blanket. I'm assuming it's the cancer, but I haven't asked my mother... Was it the bloating of the starving child? I don't know. I don't ask questions. Before, when I said I asked questions, I lied."

Eggers has talent as a writer - but his true genius is for PR. He'd make a great circus barker. "I want everyone to witness my youth," he declares. "I am an orphan of America." His Heartbreaking Work is a mannerist flourish; it marks an especially self-conscious moment in the ongoing proliferation of those "memoir-sorts of books". Only sporadically is the reader wholly engaged as one is by an achieved work of art. Curious and at times compelling, this book is more like an artifact, a bright and blaring sign of the times.

 Adam Begley is books editor of The New York Observer.

fields.headline: Takeover shakedown
fields.trailText: Will Fourth Estate pass smoothly into the HarperCollins fold? Plus independent's day and the Forward Prize shortlist
fields.body:
 Anxious staff at Fourth Estate finally learned this week that they had been sold to HarperCollins. There were soothing words from boss Victoria Barnsley, elevated to the role of Chief Executive and Publisher of HC UK, but US head Jane Friedman is reported to be reflecting on the disparity of revenue and profitability between Fourth Estate and HC imprint Flamingo, which boasts considerably fewer staff. Add to that the unsurprising cancellation of Michael Crick's planned biography of Rupert Murdoch, and it seems certain that the takeover will not be as smooth as both parties might like.

 Meanwhile, as another UK independent disappears, a replacement arrives from the US. Grove/ Atlantic is setting up a London office, and has whisked Toby Mundy away from Weidenfeld and Nicolson to take charge. Lovers of chaos will be excited at the prospect of more visits from Grove's publisher, the fantastically named Morgan Entrekin, whose fondness for late-night fun might give one or two editors here a run for their money.

 News reaches us of the marriage of one of the literary world's most eligible spinsters. At the V&A, Amanda Foreman married a man whose nickname, apparently, is Reg, on account of the number of women who have given him the push (or "rejected" him, geddit?). We can only assume that this means an end to Ms Foreman's career as a nude model, and indeed to the devil-may-care approach that the Loafer detected when the historian was shortlisted for the Whitbread Prize. "Bill", as she is puzzlingly known, was overheard in the ladies uttering the terrifying phrase "Let's cruise!" to a chum.

 The nation's poets have momentarily taken their minds off free booze and comely young women to see if they have appeared on the shortlist for the Forward Prize. The lucky few in line for £10,000 include John Burnside, Michael Donaghy, Kathleen Jamie, Douglas Dunn and Matthew Sweeney. The winner is not announced until 4 October, to coincide with National Poetry Day, so the Loafer suggests a small digestif to calm the nerves.

webTitle: Guardian review: Words on Words by David and Hilary Crystal

fields.headline: Conversation pieces
fields.standfirst: David and Hilary Crystal try to get a hold of language in Words on Words
fields.trailText: David and Hilary Crystal try to get a hold of language in Words on Words
fields.body:
Words on Words: Quotations about Language and Languages
David and Hilary Crystal
Penguin, £18.99, 592pp
Buy it at BOL

I won't mince my words: a book more perfect in conception it is difficult to imagine. Words on Words, a book of words about words: there's probably a word for it. It's like licking your own tongue, or performing some feat of auto-eroticism.

Let's be honest, there are probably enough books now about language; enough books on creolistics, dialectology, socio-linguistics, pragmatics, conversation analysis; enough books even - surely - on punctuation. But there are still too few books about words. Too few books about the romance and history of certain nouns and verbs and prepositions - no History of I , for example, no Nay, But Me No Buts: But, Nevertheless, Yet, and However, A History (if you can persuade a publisher, I'll let you have the title for free).

So David and Hilary Crystal's Words on Words seems welcome. Until it betrays itself in its sub-title: "Quotations about Language and Languages". This is no book about words, then: it is another dratted book about language. And yet as books about language go - and they do go, on and on - it is elegant, readable, intelligent and, unexpectedly, fun.

It is so easy to use, it's as if it were equipped with the bouncing balls of an old-fashioned Disney singalong. The Crystals' balls skip and jump over 65 themes divided into seven topics. The usual tired old authorial arrangement is what makes most dictionaries of quotations so grey, and such a bore: you have to keep a pencil in the index in order to follow your word or theme, or train of thought. The Crystals' thematic approach, in contrast, and in vivid Technicolor, is a source of delight.

In the chapter on the art of conversation, for example, one finds oneself skidding from Aristotle's The Art of Rhetoric ("All men conduct their conversations in metaphors and pertinent and proper nouns") to Eldridge Cleaver's Soul on Ice ("Too much agreement kills a chat") and on to EM Delafield's The Diary of a Provincial Lady ("Is it possible to cultivate the art of conversation when living in the country all year round?"), much as one might do, say, in a conversation. And it is always a pleasure to find Proust on the same page as a Walloon proverb, or Mrs Thatcher - where she belongs - alongside Oscar Wilde.

This wonderful range, however, reveals a depressing fact. There is nothing to say about words, it seems, that has not already been said, several times, and better, before. Stephen Fry, for example, may be surprised to discover that he is neither as funny nor as clever when it comes to writing about clichés as Ambrose Bierce, Hazlitt or Miguel de Unamuno. The truly memorable, original and startling insights - such as Chomsky's paraphrase illustrating generative grammar, "Colorless green ideas sleep furiously" - are few and far between.

For a subject with no apparent beginning, no middle and no end, writing about language appears merely to repeat itself, with minor variations. This may be because language is a closed system: we can never quite say what we mean, or mean what we say, and so we circle, like flies around a rotting corpse. The most important times in our lives are in fact those when we break out of language - those moments when words are few: birth, sex, death, doing the washing-up. It's often silence that makes us beautiful, and words that make us sad. Indeed, words, one suspects, like people, hide a secret desire and sorrow: that they are not other words, or not words at all.

In their lovely, limpid, hopeful introduction, the Crystals invite proposals for inclusion in a possible second edition of the book. May I suggest two? From Victor Klemperer's LTI: The Language of the Third Reich: "Words can be like tiny doses of arsenic: they are swallowed unnoticed, appear to have no effect, and then after a little time the toxic reaction sets in after all." And, along the same lines, from Bart Simpson's blackboard: "Spitwads are not free speech." Like the rest of what we say about language, these truths are self-evident.

webTitle: Guardian review: Newton's Swing by Chris Paling

fields.headline: Wayne's world
fields.standfirst: An unreliable narrator called John Wayne? Chris Paling's latest, Newton's Swing, is no ordinary murder mystery
fields.trailText: An unreliable narrator called John Wayne? Chris Paling's latest, Newton's Swing, is no ordinary murder mystery
fields.body:
Newton's Swing
Chris Paling
Jonathan Cape, £10, 232pp
Buy it at BOL

The protagonist of Chris Paling's fifth novel is called John Wayne, and his world neatly divides into those who make a joke about it and those who don't. But instead of resenting his mischievous mother's baby-naming prank, he secretly relishes the advantage that he has over those who meet him for the first time. Is this Englishman living in New York really called John Wayne? Is it a peculiar joke? Or is he lying?

Whether or not John Wayne is lying to us about his wife's murder is one of Paling's pranks, in a story that has more of Raymond Chandler about it than it does of the wild west. First, there is the beautiful and enigmatic seductress - Susan Wayne - who is found in bed at 3am with an exit wound that makes it look "like a cone of her back had been pulled out like a plug". Then there is the shadowy decadence that surrounds her, the mysterious orgiastic parties thrown by Angel, John's advertising agency boss.

There is the drink, the world-weariness, the deadpan humour and the sense of concealed motives, unknown connections and brutal, ugly truths yet to be unearthed. And there is John Wayne, a modern Marlowe who is also victim, detective and, possibly, perpetrator.

Paling has always done a good line in jaded loners, intelligent men whose ability to see clearly is fatally compromised both by the pain that they have experienced and by the impossibility of articulating it. Their relationships with women fail, and they are at once guiltily implicated in that failure and paralysed by it. For John, failure has led to death, and the permanent retirement of his wife from the psychological war of attrition that characterised their marriage. Her final departure is the last in a long series of withdrawals and silences; all it leaves John with is the prospect of scanning the past for clues, for "a metaphysical reason" for her death.

Back in the non-metaphysical real world it also leaves him with their son, a 12-year-old whose response to his mother's death is to start grilling cockroaches on the stove until they explode. Another arena for failure, their relationship progresses haltingly through miserable stabs at recovery, their doomed attempts at communication setting them further apart from one another and from the rest of the world.

In Paling's world, intimacy carries with it an unmistakable menace, and throughout this novel, various couplings are revealed to have gone awry and bent lives out of shape. Despite an impressive ability to create and manage a range of atmospheres - the noir thriller, establishing itself in subterranean oyster bars and echoing apartments; the father-and-son drama, patiently unfolding in diners and on campsites; even the comic possibilities presented by a grief management workshop - Paling never quite succeeds in pulling all the elements of his novel together.

His narrative, which proceeds by flashback, digression, half-remembered incidents and meandering meditation, apes his hero's incoherence just that little bit too much to keep the reader involved. There is also the suspicion that the author couldn't quite decide exactly which story to tell, or how to tell it, the result being the same kind of half-satisfying blend that we got in Martin Amis's Night Train. Inexplicable tragedy is precisely that; but the novelist needs to go some way towards suggesting explanations, if only to reject them.

That said, Paling is a great thing among British writers: a largely unsung talent who keeps on experimenting and refuses to write an easy book. For my money, Newton's Swing is far from being his best work, but that, we hope, may be yet to come.

For John, failure has led to death, and the permanent retirement of his wife from the psychological war of attrition that characterised their marriage. Her final departure is the last in a long series of withdrawals and silences; all it leaves John with is the prospect of scanning the past for clues, for "a metaphysical reason" for her death. Back in the non-metaphysical real world it also leaves him with their son, a 12-year-old whose response to his mother's death is to start grilling cockroaches on the stove until they explode. Another arena for failure, their relationship progresses haltingly through miserable stabs at recovery, their doomed attempts at communication setting them further apart from one another and from the rest of the world. In Paling's world, intimacy carries with it an unmistakable menace, and throughout this novel, various couplings are revealed to have gone awry and bent lives out of shape. Despite an impressive ability to create and manage a range of atmospheres - the noir thriller, establishing itself in subterranean oyster bars and echoing apartments; the father-and-son drama, patiently unfolding in diners and on campsites; even the comic possibilities presented by a grief management workshop - Paling never quite succeeds in pulling all the elements of his novel together. His narrative, which proceeds by flashback, digression, half-remembered incidents and meandering meditation, apes his hero's incoherence just that little bit too much to keep the reader involved. There is also the suspicion that the author couldn't quite decide exactly which story to tell, or how to tell it, the result being the same kind of half-satisfying blend that we got in Martin Amis's Night Train. Inexplicable tragedy is precisely that; but the novelist needs to go some way towards suggesting explanations, if only to reject them. That said, Paling is a great thing among British writers: a largely unsung talent who keeps on experimenting and refuses to write an easy book. For my money, Newton's Swing is far from being his best work, but that, we hope, may be yet to come.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Government's Annual Report

fields.headline: Give it to us straight
fields.standfirst: Fiction? Propaganda?  Giles Foden  finds much of interest in The Government's Annual Report
fields.trailText: Fiction? Propaganda? Giles Foden finds much of interest in The Government's Annual Report
fields.body:
The Government's Annual Report
The Stationery Office, £2.99, 65pp

At one point in Scottish drug addict Alexander Trocchi's notorious novel Cain's Book, he writes: "Loose ends, things unrelated, shifts, nightmare journeys, cities arrived at and left, meetings, desertions, betrayals, all manner of unions, adulteries, triumphs, defeats... These are facts."

How strange then to find the same words in the introduction to the government's annual report: "These are the facts. People can make their own judgement on them. But my assessment is that most of the key measures are going in the right direction. And for those that are not we are putting in place plans to turn them round."

In Trocchi's case, the illusion of factuality is grist to his fictional mill. In a government report, one hopes for something less tricksy, although there has long been an intriguing relationship between political documents and more traditional forms of literature. In the days before Hansard, Samuel Johnson himself used to write up versions of parliamentary proceedings for a journal called the Gentleman's Magazine. It was against the law to report verbatim parliamentary debates, so Johnson did it in a thinly fictionalised form.

Although the usual run of government material makes for dull reading (the Pink Books and the Red Books and the Blue, the Green and White Papers), some is fascinating, as the Stationery Office realised when it decided to publish its Uncovered Editions series. This offers official but far from dusty accounts of events in history and politics. Never before made available to the reading public, the titles in the series (see below) are drawn from the Controller's Library, a unique archive of official government publications.

One doubts that this report will ever be republished in such a way, even though it too is a Stationery Office publication - one that makes you think that once august organisation, formerly HMSO, lost some gravity when it was privatised in 1996 after 200 years in the public sector.

The authorship of the report is mysterious. Although the Prime Minister is said to have written the introduction, a coda points to a body called the Annual Reports Desk at 10 Downing Street. The first two reports on the Blair administration were greeted as, at best, Labour Party manifestos produced at taxpayers' expense, at worst blatant propaganda. Many argued that rather than do it itself, the government should allow the National Audit Office independently to audit its manifesto pledges and its delivery of public services.

For all that, this is an interesting document. The introduction is the section that repays the most study. Mr Blair, if it be he, continues thus: "Only by laying down the foundations, dealing with debt, sorting out the public finances, cutting down on fraud and abuse, could we begin to make real investment and improvements in public services."

It has an odd conditionality, that "could", doesn't it? There is an uneasy tentativeness about its use in this context, as if conceding that these mighty innovations are not yet under way. There is also something of the housewife under siege in the paragraph, as if the Prime Minister were Hyacinth Bouquet: What are you thinking of? How could I possibly even begin to do the dusting when there is a tank on my drive?

An annual report in most contexts would be perceived as a document of fact. This has very much the feel of a document of assertion: it even needs to assert that it is factual, reminding one of those Rider Haggard novels with a bogus framing device in which the discovered narrative is purported to be genuine.

Assertion tends to be a forward-thrusting, even aggressive mode. There is plenty of thrusting here, the kind of bullet-point, clause-avoiding Anglo-Saxon clarity that we have grown used to in the Labour rhetoric. Tough on crime and its causes is back, as is another favourite old refrain, albeit splendidly deflated by the sentence after it: "We said education, education, education. The spending review will confirm our commitment."

Opposite the introduction, in one of the red sound-bite paragraphs that pepper the document, comes another assertion, one that has very weird deixis, as grammarians call the process by which writers suggest a present atmosphere. The foundations of the novelist's art, deictic words - words such as now, here, this, or next week - suggest the temporal and geographic context in which they are used. "This," it says with a nod at Will Hutton and John Motson, "is the state of play."

In other words, the game is not over. Some people (and I write as Labour voter) think it's up. As Mr Hague remarked in parliament, there is a lot of "getting there" in this text: over 150 transitional verbs in a 65-page document.

In some ways, this willingness to concede that there is still much to be done is modest and attractive. In other ways, it conjures up a vision of an awful, eternal, imperfect present. One gets the impression that, like Sisyphus, politicians and civil servants are endlessly rolling the executive and administrative rock up the mountains of amelioration and contingency. "We have a long way to go to meet our goal..." says Tony glumly at one point.

Perhaps the most striking image of this type comes in a sentence referring to the NHS: "Unnecessary red tape is being cut," it states baldly. While one is grateful for any situation in which a cliché is given an injection of semantic life, it is hard to banish the thought that, right now, someone is hard at work with the scissors.

Further on in the introduction, in a rare figurative flourish, comes the image of government as a taxi driver with a defective steering lock: "Few things have been harder than turning round our transport system." After all that surreal transitionary self-consciousness, it is relief to find what one might expect to be the mainstay of such a document, an honest-to-goodness perfect tense: "More than one million children have been lifted out of poverty."

Mr Blair's introduction is followed by separate sections describing "promises made becoming promises kept": they include devolution, the economy, work and welfare, Europe, education, health, environment, crime and housing. Each one is followed by vérité snippets in which we learn of the success of particular ventures related to the topic in hand - small business in Devon, a benefit office in Milton Keynes. There are pictures, too.

The main body of the report is far better written, clearer and more useful than the introduction, which reads like the work of diverse hands. Generally, the vibe is good - but don't hold your breath for utopia. As a section called "prosperity for all" puts it: "The Government's vision of a fair and inclusive society will take time to become a reality."

Alas, as TS Eliot pointed out in Four Quartets, "human kind cannot bear very much reality". Perhaps this is why it was thought necessary to include a gelded section called "more out of this life". Here the Government's belief in the beneficial effects of artistic and sporting creativity is, well, not exactly spelled out. "In culture and sport, as in education or health, the Government believes in supporting excellence - but also excellence for the many, not the few." Athletics, the Lottery, the Media (new and old), Millennium Celebrations ("while the Dome remains controversial...") and football are the key notes sounded. Literature, music (neither pop nor classical), and the theatre are noticeable only through their absence.

Overall, this report is to applauded for its insistence on what emerges as a major underlying theme - the reduction of poverty - and to be deplored for its insistence on presenting government achievements as "work in progress" rather than telling us exactly what has and hasn't been done; rather than, in other words, giving it to us straight.

Blue Book

The report of a House of Commons Select Committee or a Royal Commission, etc.

Pink Book

The annual analysis of Britain's balance of payments.

White Paper

A statement of government policy and proposed legislation on a particular topic.

Green Paper

A statement by the government not of policy already determined, but of propositions put before the whole nation for discussion.

Red Book

The Chancellor's Financial Statement and Budget Report, containing analyses of public spending and a report on medium-term financial strategy. The oldest of the books, it first appeared in 1230 as the Liber ruber Scaccarii, or the Red Book of the Exchequer.

Hansard

In 1809 William Cobbett turned to printer TC Hansard to print his records of parliamentary proceedings. Hansard later came under the control of Horatio Bottomley, one of the 19th century's most infamous conmen. From 1866 the publication came under the control of parliament itself.

Any other business

The Scarman (the Brixton riots) and Scott (arms to Iraq) reports were judicial rather than government documents. Official documents published in the Stationery Office Uncovered Editions series include: John Profumo and Christine Keeler, The Loss of the Titanic, The Judgement of Nuremberg, and UFOs in the House of Lords, a debate about the existence of extraterrestrial life.

 Giles Foden is the author of two novels, Ladysmith and The Last King of Scotland.

fields.headline: The questionnaire: Tim Lott
fields.trailText: Tim Lott was born in 1956 and grew up in London. Having studied and worked in journalism, at 27 he went to read politics and history at the LSE. He left with a good degree, but sank into depression. Just months after his recovery, his mother committed suicide. His award-winning memoir about his life, The Scent Of Dried Roses, was published in 1996. His first novel, White City Blue, won the 1999 Whitbread First Novel Award.
fields.body:
Tim Lott was born in 1956 and grew up in London. Having studied and worked in journalism, at 27 he went to read politics and history at the LSE. He left with a good degree, but sank into depression. Just months after his recovery, his mother committed suicide. His award-winning memoir about his life, The Scent Of Dried Roses, was published in 1996. His first novel, White City Blue, won the 1999 Whitbread First Novel Award.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
The 15 minutes between my cleaning lady leaving my flat and me laying it to waste once again.

Which living person do you most admire?
Harold Pinter, not for his politics but because he's England's only surviving literary genius.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Condescension.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
That combination of extreme arrogance and complete stupidity sometimes found among the inbred rich.

What is your favourite smell?
Creosote, nail varnish, hot-dog stands.

What is your favourite word?
Verdigris.

What is your favourite book?
The New Journalism, edited by Tom Wolfe.

What is your favourite fantasy?
Two women.

Do you believe in monogamy?
I believe that being unfaithful is more trouble than it's worth.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
I am currently reconsidering that question.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Charm.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
The unequivocal and imperishable love of a woman possessing both strength and kindness.

What would your motto be?
Always burn your bridges; be ruthless with the past.

What keeps you awake at night?
Trying to understand.

How would you like to die?
My head suddenly exploding in the middle of coitus.

Do you believe in life after death?
Put it this way: if it were possible for a human, it would also have to be possible for a slug.

How would you like to be remembered?
As someone who wrote page-turners good enough to be literature.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Just because you feel guilty doesn't mean you're in the wrong.

fields.headline: Alone with the Greta Garbo of verse
fields.standfirst: Wislawa Szymborska tells James Hopkin why she doesn't know anything
fields.trailText: Wislawa Szymborska tells James Hopkin why she doesn't know anything
fields.body:
A diminutive old lady with quick, bird-like features and dark, knowing eyes, Wislawa Szymborska claps her hands, and says, "Generally speaking, life is so rich and full of variety; you have to remember all the time that there is a comical side to everything." Her charm and sense of mischief perhaps explain why one Italian newspaper called this Nobel prize-winning septuagenarian "the Greta Garbo of World Poetry".

Born in 1923, Szymborska has lived in Krakow, Southern Poland, since she was eight years old. She studied Polish philology and sociology at the city's Jagiellonian university, and then set about a career writing poetry, working for literary magazines, and translating poetry from French.

Under the Communist regime in Poland, Szymborska's first collection of poems, That's What We Live For (1952), was socialist realism. Yet it's a testament to her integrity that only two years later, with Questions Put to Myself, she moved towards the life of the individual.

After Poland's terrible century, Szymborska's poetry speaks with a beguiling simplicity about the everyday details and emotions that recover our humanity, and she does this without cynicism or sentiment. A first read may suggest ordinariness, but there is a complexity at work beneath her economy, a naivity that has to be worked for, and a wisdom she has acquired through experience. "I'm fighting against the bad poet who is prone to using too many words," she says. In 1996, having published only eight or nine slim volumes, she was awarded the Nobel Prize.

Now 76, Szymborska is an icon in a country that takes great pride in its poets. She is everyone's favourite literary grandmother. And it's easy to see why. Her poems are accessible and often learned by heart. One of them, "Cat in an Empty Apartment", about a cat's perspective of its departed owner, is recited across Poland by young and old alike.

Yet Szymborska does her best to lead the life of a recluse. "There's simply too much fuss about myself," she explains, with characteristic modesty, and another teasing smile. "Everyone needs solitude, especially a person who is used to thinking about what she experiences. Solitude is very important in my work as a mode of inspiration, but isolation is not good in this respect. I am not writing poetry about isolation."

As with the cat poem, much of her work is predicated on absence, while elsewhere she likes to invert scenarios, or affirm someone for what they cannot do, for "they themselves don't realise/ how much they hold in their empty hands". Hers is a poetry of approaches rather than reproaches.

Without being overtly political, her aesthetic is very much a democratic one. She uses colloquial speech and as many voices as possible, whose tone is alive and inquiring, and always provocative. Sometimes her poetry has the insistence of urgently whispered advice.

Like another post-war Polish poet, Rosewicz, she doubts the efficacy of poetry while at the same time devoting herself to it. Such refinement can be hard work. "First, it is a struggle," says Szymborska, "because, obviously, at the very core of every poem, there is emotion. What you have to do is fight against this emotion. If you were to use emotions only it would be enough to say: 'I love you. Full stop. Don't leave me. What shall I do without you? Oh my poor country! Oh my poor homeland!' "

She laughs, and her laughter is like the irony in her poems: warm and non-malicious. "Sometimes I write quickly, sometimes I spend several weeks on a single poem. I would really love for readers not to be able to guess which of the poems took so much work!"

The words she retains talk of love and loss, and of migrations, internal and external. There is wit and insight, and the reader is constantly nudged to respond. "In every possible answer," says Szymborska, "there should be another question". Opposing dogma, she uses big words and themes only to break them down into countless pieces. "I'll remind you in infinite detail," she promises in "Archeology", "Of what you expected from life besides death."

Her poems also convey a quiet dignity, an equanimity, gained by living through the worst excesses of the last century. After all, she says, ruefully, "Sadness is a beautiful category."

Szymborska's quest for simplicity explains why this delightful poet loathes to play the poet's role. She just can't understand why people still want to interview her. "For the last few years my favourite phrase has been 'I don't know'. I've reached the age of self-knowledge, so I don't know anything. People who claim that they know something are responsible for most of the fuss in the world."

But surely the Nobel Prize is a recognition of her wisdom? Even here she has a story to counter such a claim. "It all happened because of a friend in the States. It's all because of his sofa. Just before getting his Nobel Prize Czeslaw Milosz [1980] sat on this sofa, then Seamus Heaney [1995] sat on it and he won the prize, and then it happened that I sat on it, and then I got the prize! It's a magic sofa!" She laughs, throws back her head, and then leans forward again, assuming a mock-serious expression. "Unfortunately, he has since had it repaired, so no chance of a Nobel for you!"

"I'll remind you in infinite detail," she promises in "Archeology", "Of what you expected from life besides death." Her poems also convey a quiet dignity, an equanimity, gained by living through the worst excesses of the last century. After all, she says, ruefully, "Sadness is a beautiful category." Szymborska's quest for simplicity explains why this delightful poet loathes to play the poet's role. She just can't understand why people still want to interview her. "For the last few years my favourite phrase has been 'I don't know'. I've reached the age of self-knowledge, so I don't know anything. People who claim that they know something are responsible for most of the fuss in the world." But surely the Nobel Prize is a recognition of her wisdom? Even here she has a story to counter such a claim. "It all happened because of a friend in the States. It's all because of his sofa. Just before getting his Nobel Prize Czeslaw Milosz [1980] sat on this sofa, then Seamus Heaney [1995] sat on it and he won the prize, and then it happened that I sat on it, and then I got the prize! It's a magic sofa!" She laughs, throws back her head, and then leans forward again, assuming a mock-serious expression. "Unfortunately, he has since had it repaired, so no chance of a Nobel for you!"

fields.headline: Brown's boost for school sports
fields.standfirst:
£200m for professional coaches and new facilities
Education Unlimited
Special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is expected to announce a huge and unexpected boost for school sport on Tuesday in a move mirroring a decision taken by Charles de Gaulle 40 years ago that led to the revival of France as a world sporting power.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is expected to announce a huge and unexpected boost for school sport on Tuesday in a move mirroring a decision taken by Charles de Gaulle 40 years ago that led to the revival of France as a world sporting power.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, who made school sport the top priority in his spending bid, is said to have won a huge increase in funding from the chancellor, who once described himself as "sports crazy".

The bid for £200m - five times the present Treasury funding for Sport England - is understood to have been largely met but will be split between Mr Smith's department and the Department for Education and Employment.

Ministers are said to have been influenced in deciding to give more money by England's poor showing in Euro 2000, Wimbledon, the cricket World Cup, and the last Olympics.

A Sport England survey also showed a huge decline in primary school children taking physical education lessons - from 32% to 11% between 1994 and 1999. Teenagers, too, usually stop playing sport as soon as they leave school.

The figures are said to have alarmed ministers who are already concerned about the failure of the UK to produce new sporting heroes - particularly with Premiership football clubs relying ever more on foreign players.

The new funding is to be split into two parts - a revolutionary national scheme involving professional coaches to back teachers in schools, and a new investment programme in school and community sports facilities.

The main argument behind Mr Smith's bid is that teachers are under unprecedented pressure to meet the continually changing demands of the national curriculum and the call for higher academic standards.

Mr Smith wants schools to be able to employ professional coaches to train and inspire schoolchildren to play sport - and also give support to teachers who cannot spare the time to train youngsters.

The scheme will build on projects already being run by Sport England to encourage coaches and sporting stars to teach at schools and youth centres. Sport England has had trouble persuading the celebrities to attend as all it can offer is to pay their fares.

Mr Smith is said to want to launch a national scheme so that primary and secondary schools can benefit and have the money to employ professional coaches in football, rugby, swimming, cricket, tennis and athletics.

He would also like some of Britain's former world class athletes - who benefitted from public funds - to participate.

Sport England receives only £40m a year from the Treasury and only a small proportion of the money goes to schools. It receives far more from the national lottery, but this is dropping every year and was down from £300m to £200m a year over the past three years.

The other part of the sports bid would be funded through the education department and would involve a big increase in the school building programme to pay for all-weather pitches, gyms and swimming pools. This three-year commitment to the building programme should reverse years of neglect - which have seen the sale of school playing fields for housing developments.

Sources in Sport England said that if the government did go ahead with such a big boost, it could be seen as a parallel to a decision taken by the French 40 years ago and the Australians in the 1970s to plough hundreds of millions into school and youth sport in the wake of poor performances at the Olympics and in international competitions.

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: The Lake District | Jordan | Safari
fields.body:
Europe

The Lake District: Four-night easy-walking break staying near Grasmere from September 25. Cost is £179pp with half-board plus packed lunches. Countrywide Holidays (01942 241432).

Gibraltar: Two nights for singles at the Rock Hotel between November 1 and December 10 is £280pp from Gatwick. Cadogan Holidays (023-8082 8303).

Cruise: Three-night European pre-Christmas cruise on board Fred Olsen's Black Prince departing Southampton December 20, visiting Antwerp and Le Havre. Prices start at £210pp. Fred Olsen (01473 292222)

Middle East

Jordan: Seven-night escorted trip visiting castles, Wadi Rum, Mount Nebo (where Moses glimpsed the Promised Land), and Petra. Prices is £738 departing September from Heathrow. The Imaginative Traveller (020-8742 8612).

Caribbean

Cruise : Festival Cruises (020-7734 0005) is running two alternative weekly cruises out of Guadeloupe from December 22 to April 2001 for £982pp. The first sails on December 22 and visits St Maarten, Tortola, Dominica, St Barthélemy, Antigua and Mayreau. A week later, the cruise calls in at Martinique, Trinidad, Barbados, Grenada, St Lucia and Mayreau.

Africa

Safari: Fourteen-night East African tour from Nairobi to Zanzibar taking in Lake Naivasha, Christmas dinner at Lake Nakura, and the Serengeti. First departure December 23. Price £445 per adult, £405 per child, plus international flights. Dragoman (01728 861133).

Ethiopia : Seventeen-day group trek across the Simien Highlands departs October 13. From £1,765pp from Heathrow. Worldwide Journeys and Expeditions (020-7386 4646).

Asia

Tibet : Mount Kailash is the holiest mountain in the Himalayas. Walk the route of pilgrims on the 31-day Mount Kailash Pilgrimage and Kingdom of Guge trek. Price is £3,495, departing September 10 from Himalayan Kingdoms (0117 923 7163).

Malaysia: A seven-day autumn break in the beautifully-restored Tanjon Jara resort on the east coast. Valid from September 1 to November 30, the price is £1,020pp. The resort has pool and a spa. Steppes East (01285 810267).

Australia

Tour : Fourteen nights for £942 flying into Sydney with an optional stop-over in Seoul. Includes four nights at Sullivans Hotel, Sydney plus 10 days' car hire and hotel vouchers. From September 17 - December 9 with Austravel (0870 0550206).

fields.headline: Secret pleasures
fields.standfirst: Author  Fiona Walker rehearses the dialogue for her latest 'bonkbuster' while exploring the hidden charms of the Cotswolds
fields.trailText: Author Fiona Walker rehearses the dialogue for her latest 'bonkbuster' while exploring the hidden charms of the Cotswolds
fields.body:
If you move to the country and get a dog, there's no alternative to plenty of walking. For novelist Fiona Walker, it's meant the discovery and exploration of a half-lost, little-changed English landscape where the river Evenlode winds among rolling hills and honey-coloured villages.

On the map it's a kind of no-man's land where the borders of Oxfordshire, Warwickshire and Gloucestershire are knotted together, but on the ground it's a succession of quiet delights: old manor houses, ancient churches, beautiful views, changing weather and the kind of pubs it's difficult to pass.

Her favourite walk starts in the village of Adlestrop, where an express train made an unplanned stop early last century and prompted Edward Thomas to write his famous poem ("What I saw / Was Adlestrop - only the name / And willows, willow-herb and grass / And meadowsweet and haycocks dry...")

The station has been dismantled, but you can see its old sign in the village before setting off north past the big house. It's uphill, giving Walker the perspective she likes so much: "Almost every view has one or two villages in it, and on a good day you can count about five church spires and three or four grand country houses."

From this hill, the main house you see is Chastleton, one of the country's best- preserved Jacobean buildings. It dates from 1612, and has recently had six years' restoration by the National Trust. It has weird garden topiary and claims to be the place where the rules of modern croquet were codified in 1865.

Walker, often with friends in tow and a pub lunch in prospect, presses on past Peasewell Wood, over the iron-age Chastleton Barrow and down the hill to Cornwell, where the architect Sir Clough Williams-Ellis refurbished the old village houses in the 1930s.

"It's just exquisite, nestled in a crease of the wolds where different slopes meet, and you feel like you've walked into a different time zone," she says. "Unfortunately, there's no pub there, although you might find an ice-cream van sailing past if you're lucky."

From here it's another climb to skirt the wall of Daylesford House, take in more views, then drop to cross the railway and the winding Evenlode: Walker's Jack Russell terrier, Jelly, sometimes takes a swim and can't climb back up the steep banks.

The Fox at Lower Oddington, with its pints of Hook Norton bitter, is beckoning hard now, but you can delay the moment with a glimpse of hell: the village church of St Nicholas has a macabre 14th-century "doom painting" which shows a good man being hauled up a heavenly tower by an angel, a damned soul dangling from a gibbet, and the large, richly-dressed figure of Pride being dragged into the mouth of Hell. It dates from the 15th century, was whitewashed over in the 17th, and rediscovered in 1912.

The move from the image to the word after the Reformation led to the covering of most church wall paintings, and many were lost for good when Victorians hacked off plaster to expose what they considered to be the beautiful stonework.

But the paintings in St Nicholas were saved by their location: by Victorian times, the population had shifted to Upper Oddington, a new church was built there, and St Nicholas fell into the neglect, which preserved its pictures for 20th-century rediscovery. It now stands isolated to the south-east of the village.

"Personally, I'm for getting to the pub first, which is pretty much the end of the walk, and perhaps coming back to look at the picture afterwards," says Walker. "By this time you'll have done about seven miles and spent up to about four hours on it, so lunch at the end is a good thing.

Walker's books are sometimes described as "bonkbusters", with a recurring character called at one point "her much-neglected love bud". On shorter daily walks with just the dog for company, she works on the plots, tries bits of dialogue out loud, and occasionally frightens other walkers.

One example was when the dog disappeared and she hid in a ditch - a standard ploy for getting him back: "After a while, I heard panting and the jingling of an identity tag, so I leapt out of the ditch and yelled: 'There you are, you bugger!' And it was this bloke with a spaniel. He just ran, white-faced.

"I went after him shouting I was sorry, but it was no good. I suppose it was one in the eye for men who terrify women occasionally, but I must have come across like the mad woman of the Cotswolds."

The practicals

For general information and places to stay, phone the Tourist Information Office at Stow-on-the-Wold (01451 831082) or Chipping Norton (01608 644 379) or visit www.visit-glos.org.uk. A wide range of guide books for walking in this area is available from Cordee, Leicester (0116 254 3579). OS Landranger maps (1 inch to 1 mile) 163 (Cheltenham and Cirencester), OS Outdoor Leisure maps (2 inches to 1 mile), 45 (The Cotswolds). Chastleton House (01608 674355) is open Wed-Sat from April 1 - October 31, 1-5 pm (1-4pm in October). Book in advance. Admission to non-NT members £5.10, child £2.55, family £12.75.

 Girls Night In, an anthology of stories including one by Fiona Walker, is published by Harper Collins at £5.99 with £1 per copy donated to the charity War Child.

fields.headline: Open season
fields.standfirst: If next week's Open Championship at St Andrews inspires you to take the covers off your woods, Scotland will spoil you for choice. Our golf correspondent  David Davies picks his top 10 courses
fields.trailText: If next week's Open Championship at St Andrews inspires you to take the covers off your woods, Scotland will spoil you for choice. Our golf correspondent David Davies picks his top 10 courses.
fields.body:
It is fitting that the first Open Championship of the new millennium should be held at St Andrews, the home of golf. For in Scotland, the game is much more open than in the rest of the world, with a few dishonourable exceptions. The whole of Scotland is teeming with golf courses - about 540 of them - and most of them are open to the golf-playing public. Some are great, some more humble and often, if you pass one and you have your clubs in the back of the car, it will be worth enquiring whether you can have a round.

But if you want a guide to some of the best, here, in no particular order, is a top 10.

St Andrews
Not everybody realises that the most famous golf course in the world, the Old, is public and that anyone can play it. In theory, that is. In practice, it takes more than a little organisation (see below), but whatever it takes it is worth it. This is how golf began, with all the idiosyncrasies of those early courses still perfectly preserved and still, amazingly, offering a serious and correct challenge to the modern golfer. Everything about St Andrews, the town and the 99 holes of golf offered, is unique and it is every professional golfer's wish to win here. When Nick Faldo won in 1990, he averaged 67.5 strokes per round which, as Steve Isaac, a Royal and Ancient agronomist observed, was "not murdering the course: a mild mugging perhaps".

Handicap certificate: 24 for men, 36 for women.
Green fees: £80 a round.
Eating: Links clubhouse open from 6am. Also lots of pubs and hotels nearby.
Booking: 01334 466666.
Restrictions: Put in your request at least a year in advance. Applications are acknowledged and held on file until October/November when they are processed in order of receipt for the following year. A request for a time in high season (April 1-October 31) must be accom panied by a request for a time on one of the St Andrews Links Trust's other courses (there are five: the New, Jubilee, Eden, Strathtyrum and Balgove, which is nine holes). Or you can take pot luck in the ballot. Every day except Sunday (the Old Course is closed on Sundays), there is a draw for a number of times the following day. The Saturday draw is for play on Monday. You have to enter by phone or in person the morning before you wish to play and the ballot is drawn after 2pm. The results are announced on www.golfagent.com and, after 4pm, they are posted at the Links clubhouse, the starters' boxes, the caddie manager's office, local golf clubs and the tourist information centre. Single players can join in a two- or three-ball by speaking to the starter.
Pint of lager: £2.10.
Address: St Andrews Links Trust, Pilmour House, Fife KY16 9SF.
Website: www.standrews.org.uk

Turnberry
Probably the most scenic of the acknowledged great courses. Certainly, it has one of the all-time great tees in golf, the ninth, which has the sea crash ing around on three sides and presents a fearsome carry over waves, rocks and cliff edge to the fairway. The 10th is a beauty, too, curving around a driftwood- and seaweed-strewn bay, with magnificent views out to the huge rock of Ailsa Craig. The course hosted perhaps the greatest major championship of them all, the 1977 Open confrontation between Tom Watson and Jack Nicklaus. Nicklaus, having birdied the last hole - only for Watson to do so also and win - was as gracious as ever in defeat. Wrapping an arm round his conqueror's shoulder, he said: "You have seen my best - and you've beaten it."

Handicap certificate: There's no rule that says you even have to have a handicap.
Green fees: Weekdays £120 a round, weekends £150 a round (for non-residents).
Eating: Restaurant/grill/bar at clubhouse.
Booking: 01655 331000 and ask for pro's shop.
Restrictions: Hard to get a time. Will send you a request form - for date, numbers etc - and let you know two or three weeks prior to the date.
Pint of lager: £2.25.
Address: Turnberry Hotel Golf Courses and Spa, Ayrshire KA26 9LT.
Website: www.turnberry.co.uk

Muirfield
Here dwelleth the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers, and also some modern myths about the impossibility of gaining access to one of the world's top 10 golf courses. One of the best stories came courtesy of the late Payne Stewart, at the time the US Open champion and in Scotland on vacation. A friend rang to see if Stewart could come and play but the assistant, catching only the fairly common Scottish surname, did not connect it with the American champion and explained that the course was full that week. When the tabloids inevitably got hold of it, it was "Toffs Snub Champ" all over the place. You can play if you pull the right levers, and wonderfully rewarding it is, too. Jack Nicklaus loved it so much he named his own course in Ohio after it, Muirfield Village, and he considered it to be the fairest of all the courses on the Open rota.

Handicap certificate: 18 for men, 24 for women. Must be members of a recognised golf club.
Green fees: £80 a round, £105 a day.
Eating: Gentleman can, ladies can't (in the clubhouse).
Booking: 01620 842123.
Restrictions: Tuesdays and Thursdays only. Probably have to book a year ahead. Books for 2001 opened on May 1, phone has hardly stopped ringing since. Women must play with men, one each (ie can't have three women and one man).
Pint of lager: £1.65.
Address: Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers, Muirfield, Gullane, East Lothian EH31 2EG.
E-mail: hceg@btinternet.com

Nairn
This is one of those gems that until relatively recently has been unrecognised by the various championships. It is a magnificent test of golf, hard by the Moray Firth, with a glut of great holes. Because it is fairly exposed, it is subject to - and is the better for - a wind, that can blow severely. Nairn needs only a few more yards to be worthy of an Open.

Handicap certificate: 28 for men, 36 for women.
Green fees: Weekdays £60 a round, weekends £65 a round.
Eating: Full catering.
Booking: 01667 453208.
Restrictions: Members' times 9am-9.30am. Four-balls after 9.30am. Some at weekends.
Pint of lager: £1.80-£1.90.
Address: The Nairn Golf Club, Seabank Road, Nairn IV12 4HB.
Website: www.nairngolfclub.co.uk

Royal Dornoch
This is a place of pilgrimage, a long way even from Edinburgh or Glasgow. It is the most northerly championship course in the world, on the same latitude as Hudson Bay and Labrador. But, as the Michelin guides say, it is worth a detour as two players who arrived singly and were introduced on the first tee discovered. One had flown from New York to London to Inverness and then taxied to Dornoch; the other had driven from Birmingham and both had taken 10 hours. But they discovered a course that is a delight, wandering around the whins, the heather and the gorse in full accord with its surroundings. Tom Watson said of it: "I have played none finer, a natural masterpiece."

Handicap certificate: 24 for men, 39 for women.
Green fees: Weekdays £57 a round, weekends £67 a round. Weekdays combination ticket £62 for both courses.
Eating: Full catering.
Booking: 01862 810219.
Restrictions: Saturday morning members only. Blocks of times for visitors but very busy mid-May to early October.
Pint of lager: £1.60-ish.
Address: Royal Dornoch, Golf Road, Dornoch IV25 3LW.
E-mail: www.royaldornoch.com

Carnoustie
This might have been purpose-built for the masochists of the golfing world. It is 7,371 yards long from the back tees and has a par of, wait for it, 71. It can be the hardest golf course in the world. Carnoustie is a brutal test even on a nice day and when, as so often occurs, the weather draws its great grey curtains, the bleakness of the surroundings can be overwhelming. The daunting nature of the course can be summed up in one word, and was when the comedian and singer Danny Kaye made the following entrance in the vistors' book: "Murder," he wrote. The local council lost the plot in the 1970s and 80s, allowing the course to become a milked-out cash cow in clapped-out condition. It is restored now, so go and be proud if you get within five of your handicap.

Handicap certificate: 28 for men, 36 for women.
Green fees: £70 all the time.
Eating: Golf club or the hotel.
Booking: 01241 853789.
Restrictions: Weekends more difficult. After 2pm on Saturday, 11.30am on Sunday.
Pint of lager: £1.40-£1.80.
Address: Carnoustie Golf Links, Links Parade, Carnoustie, Angus DD7 7JE.
Website: www.carnoustie.org/golf

Royal Troon
"Royal" was added to its name quite recently despite the fact that 50% of the world's population are not allowed on to the championship course. Women are expressly forbidden from playing there, presumably because they might strain themselves, poor dears. This barmy ban apart, Troon is a great place to play golf. The course runs out-and-back in the classical manner and, if the wind is from the north, the homeward half becomes monstrous.

Handicap certificate: 20 for men, 30 for women (on the Portland course).
Green fees: £125 a day, includes coffee/lunch and a round on both the Old and the Portland courses (women excepted). £85 a day includes coffee/lunch and two rounds on the Portland course.
Eating: Full catering, including Ailsa lounge, where you don't need to change and soft spikes (not hard) are permitted. In the dining room and smoke room, jacket and tie required.
Booking: 01292 311555.
Restrictions: Old 9.30am-11am and 2.30pm-4pm; Portland 9am-10.30am and 2.30pm-4pm. Women and players under 18 can play the Portland course. Women are not allowed to play the championship course but are permitted to "accompany and look decorative". Are they allowed in the clubhouse? Doubtless, on special occasions, under armed guard.
Pint of lager: £1.73.
Address: Royal Troon Golf Club, Craigend Road, Troon, Ayshire KA10 3EP.
E-mail: bookings@royaltroon.com

North Berwick
Another old Scottish course that is laid out seemingly in the only way possible - following precisely the contours of the land, which happen to be just perfect for golf. It has a famous last hole, a drivable par four, which features a green raised rather like a cake tin, throwing any ball not perfectly struck off into the grassy swales that surround the green. This natural outcrop has been copied by designers worldwide, mostly inappropriately. There is not enough room on the course for large crowds to follow play, so although an Open is out of the question, one of the final qualifying rounds is always played there when the Open goes to Muirfield.

Handicap certificate: 24 for men, 34 for women.
Green fees: Weekdays £36 a round, £54 a day, weekends £54 a round, £72 a day.
Eating: Full catering.
Booking: 01620 892135 from 11am on. If no answer or engaged, try the pro's shop on 01620 893233.
Restrictions: Can't get out before 10am.
Pint of lager: £1.65.
Address: The Glen Golf Club, Tantallon Terrace, North Berwick EH39 4LE.

Machrihanish
Mention this one to an aficionado and they'll start drooling at once, picturing a wild, windswept landscape and a links to die for. It's remote enough, even these days, situated on the Mull of Kintyre, near Campbelltown, but few who've been there moan about a wasted journey. If you take the car, it takes a long time to get there - about three hours from Glasgow - but it's only 25 minutes by air and, either way, you'll enjoy some stunning scenery. It's not advis able to rush on to the first tee without warming up. The view of the bay and the beach is fantastic but the drive is daunting, tempting the brave, or foolhardy, to take too direct a line over the sea. Old Tom Morris, a pioneer of the game, said the Almighty had designed Machrihanish for playing golf.

Handicap certificate: None, just as long as you can play.
Green fees: £28 a round, £45 a day, except Saturday, £35 a round, £55 a day.
Eating: Catering available 11am-3pm, 6pm on. Also rolls, soup etc.
Booking: 01586 810213.
Restrictions: Not many. Pretty easy going. Tee times from 9am on.
Pint of lager: £1.75.
Address: Machrihanish Golf Club, Machrihanish, Campbeltown, Argyll PA28 6PT.

Boat of Garten
It's not a great course - Tiger Woods would probably consider it a pitch and putt, with only four holes longer than 400 yards - but that's not a problem for most of us. The Boat is a great place to be and to play and that's what stays in the memory. It's the sort of course that will still be a favourite 30 years after your only visit. It's a handful of miles north of Aviemore, so there's the river Spey, the Cairngorms, pine trees, perhaps the odd osprey and enough undulations and variety to test your shot-making. A gem and a delight.

Handicap certificate: Should have a handicap but no certificate necessary.
Green fees: Weekdays £23 a round, £28 a day. Weekends £28 a round, £33 a day.
Eating: Catering 9am-8pm.
Booking: 01479 831282.
Restrictions: Booking system, otherwise not many.

Address: Boat of Garten Golf and Tennis Club, Inverness-shire PH24 3BQ.
Website: www.boatgolf.com

fields.bodyText: It is fitting that the first Open Championship of the new millennium should be held at St Andrews, the home of golf. For in Scotland, the game is much more open than in the rest of the world, with a few dishonourable exceptions. The whole of Scotland is teeming with golf courses - about 540 of them - and most of them are open to the golf-playing public. Some are great, some more humble and often, if you pass one and you have your clubs in the back of the car, it will be worth enquiring whether you can have a round. But if you want a guide to some of the best, here, in no particular order, is a top 10. St Andrews Not everybody realises that the most famous golf course in the world, the Old, is public and that anyone can play it. In theory, that is. In practice, it takes more than a little organisation (see below), but whatever it takes it is worth it. This is how golf began, with all the idiosyncrasies of those early courses still perfectly preserved and still, amazingly, offering a serious and correct challenge to the modern golfer. Everything about St Andrews, the town and the 99 holes of golf offered, is unique and it is every professional golfer's wish to win here. When Nick Faldo won in 1990, he averaged 67.5 strokes per round which, as Steve Isaac, a Royal and Ancient agronomist observed, was "not murdering the course: a mild mugging perhaps". Handicap certificate: 24 for men, 36 for women. Green fees: £80 a round. Eating: Links clubhouse open from 6am. Also lots of pubs and hotels nearby. Booking: 01334 466666. Restrictions: Put in your request at least a year in advance. Applications are acknowledged and held on file until October/November when they are processed in order of receipt for the following year. A request for a time in high season (April 1-October 31) must be accom panied by a request for a time on one of the St Andrews Links Trust's other courses (there are five: the New, Jubilee, Eden, Strathtyrum and Balgove, which is nine holes). Or you can take pot luck in the ballot. Every day except Sunday (the Old Course is closed on Sundays), there is a draw for a number of times the following day. The Saturday draw is for play on Monday. You have to enter by phone or in person the morning before you wish to play and the ballot is drawn after 2pm. The results are announced on www.golfagent.com and, after 4pm, they are posted at the Links clubhouse, the starters' boxes, the caddie manager's office, local golf clubs and the tourist information centre. Single players can join in a two- or three-ball by speaking to the starter. Pint of lager: £2.10. Address: St Andrews Links Trust, Pilmour House, Fife KY16 9SF. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Dining out | Taking off | Gaining currency
fields.body:
Dining out
A family of four can enjoy a three-course meal every night for a week plus drinks in the Algarve for £312 according to Thomas Cook's cost of living index for this summer. They reckon the prices in other places are: Tenerife £198, Costa del Sol £226, Cyprus £243, Turkey £251, Majorca £270, Madeira £310, Zante £336, Sicily £312, Florida £462 and Sorrento £616.

Taking off
Some 83% of a sample of 3,000 university applicants intend to take a gap year to travel and work abroad, according to STA Travel

Gaining currency
Barclays is offering commission-free currency to the most popular holiday destinations - the US, France, Italy, Portugal and Spain - throughout July. Customers can visit Barclays branches or ring 0845 6008090. Currency can be delivered to home or your place of work for £3.50.

Luton delays
Passengers travelling to Luton Airport this summer should allow extra time for their car journeys as there are to be night-time closures at junction 10 of the M1 for four weeks from July 23.

Away match
British Airways has just launched a brochure concentrating solely on weddings. Kenya, Mexico, Thailand and Cuba are all new "wedding destinations" featured. Mauritius is the most popular destination so far this year, followed by St Lucia, Barbados, Antigua and Bahamas. BA Holidays Weddings 0870 2424245.

Eastern promise
Russia and Croatia are set to lead the tourism boom in central and eastern Europe over the next 20 years, according to a study by industry analysts Travel and Tourism Intelligence. TTI expects the number of foreign visitors to the whole region to treble in the next 20 years, to more than 220m. It considers Krakow, St Petersburg and Zagreb to be the main cities to benefit from an increase in visitors. The reprt, Tourism in Central and Eastern Europe, costs £395 from TTI (020-7814 3820, www.t-ti.com).

All in good taste
Brittany Ferries has produced a Winebuyers Pocket Guide to entice their passengers to buy bottles on board, which will be delivered to your car. Brittany Ferries 0870 5360360.

Downhill struggle
The UK's largest ski holiday company, Crystal (0870 848 7000), says bookings are 8% up on last year but still below where they were two years ago.
