fields.headline: Water under the bridge
fields.standfirst: Sickly people used to go to the Auvergne for the waters of Vichy. Now, it's getting a more active reputation.  Emma Brockes reports
fields.trailText: Sickly people used to go to the Auvergne for the waters of Vichy. Now, it's getting a more active reputation. Emma Brockes reports
fields.body:
The tourist officer looks uncomfortable. We are standing on the steps of her office, preparing to enter a pavilion where you can taste 10 different types of spring water, some fizzy, some still, some warm and smelling of rotten eggs, all constituted to neutralise bugs in your system. It is the town's chief attraction and has been pulling in consumptive pilgrims since Roman times.

But Françoise is looking grim, because eschewing the water angle, I've asked her about the town's history as a base for Marshal Pétain's collaborationist government during the second world war. Given the scale of interest in the period, you'd expect coach-loads of A-level history students to be backed up all the way to Nice.

"Yes, the government buildings were here," she says, wearily indicating the tourist office behind us, "and Pétain's private quarters were at the end of the block."

Bit of an oversight by the tourist office, isn't it? No plaque? No museum? No wall of remembrance where you can lay a wreath to the victims of the Vichy regime?

"It's not a period we want to remember," she says and, looking suitably tortured, clips off across the road towards the curly white ironwork of the pavilion.

The town's reluctance to put its more recent history to commercial or even educative use means that what you will find is a beautifully-manicured spa town with landscaped parks, perfectly-restored architecture and not a single reference to the war.

Vichy is remarkable for being a town in which there appear to be no ugly bits. It is like a feature on a wedding cake, clean and sparkly, the beneficiary of 500 years' worth of investment by wealthy hypochondriacs. Napoleon III loved it and had two houses built there during the 1860s. The buildings are a mixture of art deco, gothic and baroque, with a 19th-century copy of the Venetian Gustinian building tucked away in a side-street, as if it was any other ordinary semi.

One third of the town is made up of parkland, exquisite belle-époque lawns dotted with old-fashioned iron gazebos and trees waving in the wind.

While bigger centres in the region, such as Clermont Ferrand, boast nothing higher than three-star hotels, Vichy has a four-star stunner - Les Célestins - with a rooftop swimming pool curled like an intestine so that half of it is inside and half out, with candy-striped sun loungers parked at the edge.

For a hotel more in keeping with the style of the town, the Aletti Palace Hotel, built in 1911, has the understated chic of the Titanic. The reception, in the shadow of a terrifying crystal chandelier, is decorated in heavy red velour with a grand staircase whisking up from it like a tornado, and wooden panelling adorning the walls.

Beautiful, airbrushed Vichy is in the Auvergne region of central France, an area characterised by 88 dormant volcanoes that give it a skyline more redolent of Costa Rica than somewhere within 90 minutes' flying time of London. Seen from the vantage point of a hot-air balloon, it is full of densely- vegetated lacunae and bleached stone villages with dinky steeples - a vista worth getting up for at 4am and parting with £150.

For those who enjoy a more leisurely approach to taking in the scenery, a car-ride around the Auvergne will still get your heart rate up. It takes an hour to drive from Vichy to Clermont Ferrand, and another hour to hit the deep, soft countryside. But towards the small towns of Brioude and Langeac, you come across a perfect picture-postcard rendition of France - an avenue lined with plane trees.

The village of Lavote-Chilhac perches on a rock with an 11th-century church, a fantastic restaurant - Le Prieuré, about £10 a head - and two-star accommodation overlooking a stone bridge over the Gorge. It is a spot of such weird perfection that it is worth going out of your way for.

Half-an-hour to the east is Le Puy en Velay, a larger-scale version of that same, ancient splendour. The cathedral, with its 13th-century fresco of the Crucifixion, made it the Lourdes of the middle ages, and it is still a major destination for pilgrimages. The winding streets are like something out of Shakespeare, since the authorities long ago stopped giving planning permission for anything modern looking. Three stars are as high as the hotels go, but luxurious accommodation seems less important with countryside this stunning.

Action in the Auvergne

From a terrestrial viewpoint, the best way to penetrate the Auvergne countryside is to book for some off-road activities. A day's mountain biking will cost £13 (including bike hire), horse riding is from £21 for half a day, and white-water rafting in the Gorges du Haut-Allier is £29 for the day, or £15 for the afternoon.

At the Ecuries du Breuil, I was given Paddy,a brown and very docile horse. The 30km trek went along wooded tracks, across hills and streams, from which I could see endless scooped out mountains and rippling fields.

The riding was idyllic: better than walking because you can see over the hedgerows; better than driving because there is no sound of an engine. The trips are tailored to experience and have a maximum of 15 people.

Mountain biking was provided by Dome VTT, run by Eric Gire, who leads groups of around 10 on complicated routes through the Parc des Volcans. These involve skidding down steep, wooded inclines on an earth and shale track, doing BMX-style jumps over tree roots and stopping for breath in a valley surrounded by the husks of dead volcanoes, with red gravel slopes and towering pine trees of a kind regularly featured in the Fortean Times as likely spots for UFO sitings.

To complete the set of activities, I attempted white-water rafting with the Tonic Adventure company. We were given wetsuits and paddles and told to sit on both sides of the squat yellow dingy and row. As we bombed through the white water, the scenery on either side of the rapids rose up like Montana's finest.

The practicals

Ryanair (0870 333 1231) flies from Stansted to St Etienne from £90 return.

Hotels: Les Célestins, 111 Boulevard des Etats-Unis, Vichy (00 33 4 70 30 82 00) from £120 a night. Aletti Palace Hotel, 3 Place Joseph Aletti, Vichy (00 33 4 70 31 7877) from £50 a night. Hotel Le Regina, Le Puy en Velay (00 33 4 71 09 18 57) from £37 a night.

Restaurants: La Brasserie du Casino, 4, rue du Casino, Vichy (00 33 4 98 23 06). Le Prieuré, Lavote-Chilhac (00 33 04 71 77 47 93).

Activities: Ecuries du Breuil (00 33 4 70 99 20 02). Dome VTT (00 33 4 73 62 19 04). Tonic Adventure (00 33 04 71 77 25 64). Objectif hot-air ballooning.

Car hire: Holiday Autos (0870 400 0011). Auvergne Tourist Board 0033 4 7329 4949.

We are standing on the steps of her office, preparing to enter a pavilion where you can taste 10 different types of spring water, some fizzy, some still, some warm and smelling of rotten eggs, all constituted to neutralise bugs in your system. It is the town's chief attraction and has been pulling in consumptive pilgrims since Roman times. But Françoise is looking grim, because eschewing the water angle, I've asked her about the town's history as a base for Marshal Pétain's collaborationist government during the second world war. Given the scale of interest in the period, you'd expect coach-loads of A-level history students to be backed up all the way to Nice. "Yes, the government buildings were here," she says, wearily indicating the tourist office behind us, "and Pétain's private quarters were at the end of the block." fields.headline: Independence online
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor  had four days to organise every detail of a long weekend somewhere in Europe.
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor had four days to organise a long weekend in Europe.
fields.body:
Some readers probably wonder how much travel I actually book online. The answer, naturally, is as much as possible, but until last week I hadn't attempted to organise an entire trip (flights, accommodation, research, car hire) online. And this time I only had four days to organise a long weekend somewhere in Europe.

Expedia and Ebookers
Searching for two return flights under £150 was easy enough, but the results were disappointing. Not only did every flight seem to be full, but anything to the south of France and Italy appeared to cost at least £300.

Buzz, Go and easyJet
Earlier this year I picked up a return to Paris for £48 on Buzz, so I was happy to consider flying to Carcassonne, Bordeaux or Marseille with the airline. Unfortunately the prices had risen with the summer. Go was almost completely booked (deservedly so) and easyJet's flights to Nice were startlingly expensive. It was time to go lower.

Ryanair
Ryanair's website leaves a lot to be desired. It's hard to navigate, ugly and frankly misleading. One-way flights do start from £9, but there is no easy way of finding the cheapest way to fly, and airport taxes increase the price substantially.

Nonetheless, Ryanair had seats to Pisa on the appropriate dates and the cost was just over £130, which was slightly cheaper than flying Alitalia via Expedia and didn't involve a change in Milan. I booked. Ryanair suggested printing out the confirmation screen but didn't offer to send an e-mail.

Universal Currency Converter
My budget was immediately multiplied by 3,085 (lire to the pound).

Italy Hotel Reservation
IHR allows you to search for hotels in a particular region and links to their own websites. In some cases, it's possible to check availability and book online too. A pleasant two-hour trawl of bad English and large photographs ensued, which would have been shorter if the site had been capable of searching for availability across its database.

An appealing hotel in Colle di Val d'Elsa had double rooms available, but I had never heard of the town and the Rough Guides hadn't either. I was also unhappy with the site's security and unwilling to trust it with a credit card number.

AltaVista
Typing the name of the town and the hotel returned several pages on different booking networks. Visiting them all gave a much better picture of Colle di Val d'Elsa.

TuscanyNet
Booking on TuscanyNet appeared to be more secure, but there was no guarantee of a quick reply. Worried that the hotel would forget to check their email, I faxed them to reiterate what I wanted. They faxed back the following morning to confirm the booking, but added that they had not received the email.

Hertz car hire
Progress was halted by a call from my travelling partner. "I've booked the car, and it was only £70," he informed me.

"But I could have found a better price online!"

"Yes, but when I call them, they ask which flight you're arriving on, and you can talk to someone..."

fields.headline: Mother of all cities
fields.standfirst: Visitors are beginning to return to Egypt to take in the wonders of its ancient capital. Author  Michael Asher  goes on a magical history tour
fields.trailText: Visitors are beginning to return to Egypt to take in the wonders of its ancient capital. Author Michael Asher goes on a magical history tour.
fields.body:
Locals like to call Cairo "the Mother of the World", but in fact the city is a whirlpool of life and culture on the edge of many worlds - Upper and Lower Egypt, Asia and arid north Africa, the Mediterranean and tropical Africa, the desert and the sown. You can peel layers off the city's history like an onion skin, for almost anyone who was anyone in the business of conquest has been here at some time or another.

The fortress-city of Al-Qahira was built by a heretical Arab clan called the Fatimids in 969AD, but millennia earlier the area had been a centre for pharaonic civilisation. Heliopolis - a suburb of modern Cairo - was the headquarters of the mysterious Ra brotherhood, who were the secret power behind the ancient Egyptian throne, while the Giza plateau, with its pyramids and Great Sphinx, was their most sacred site.

The Persians arrived in 525BC, bringing the hitherto unknown camel with them, followed by Greeks, Byzantines, Arabs, Mamluks, Turks, French and British. Each band of newcomers has added new ingredients to the heady stockpot of history still simmering alongside the modern office blocks, bridges and flyovers.

What to see

Tahrir Square is the centre of Downtown Cairo, and the site of one of the city's greatest attractions, the Egyptian Museum - an Edwardian baroque palace in red sandstone housing the best exhibition of ancient Egyptian relics anywhere in the world. It really requires more than one visit to do it justice, but for those with a limited time the Tutankhamen treasures are probably the principal highlight. Discovered by Howard Carter in 1921, the three golden catafalques, solid gold death-mask, ceremonial gilded couches and chariots, jewellery, scarabs, diadems, weapons, statues and more than 1,600 other items were buried with an 18th-dynasty boy-king.

The museum houses more than 100,000 relics and is open every day (9am-4.45pm) except for a two-hour break for prayers (noon-2pm) on Friday. The admission fee of about £3.50 is good value, and students pay only £1.75, though admission to the royal mummies room is an extra £7.

The pyramids

No one visits Cairo without seeing the pyramids at Giza, of course, and no matter how many times you have seen them in films and pictures, at close hand these colossal structures remain stunningly impressive. There are three giant pyramids at Giza, built with a precision that even today is the envy of engineers.

No one knows for certain when the pyramids and Sphinx were built, nor what their purpose was. But with visitors to Egypt now back to almost two million a year, and most of them paying £3.50 for admission to the Giza necropolis and a further £3.50 to enter each of the three pyramids, one wonders if the original builders weren't inspired by an entrepreneurial genius that was millennia ahead of its time.

Shopping and how to haggle

Visit the warren of bazaars of Khan al-Khalili and you will have stepped into the One Thousand and One Nights. The bazaar grew up organically around a caravanserai built to serve camel-caravans from Persia and China in the 14th century, and many of its buildings and gateways still date from that era. Within the maze of winding, narrow alleys, you can find brassware, Bedouin jewellery, carpets, gold, glass, incense, leatherwork, perfumes, papyrus, silver, precious stones, spices and textiles.

Although some shops display "fixed price" signs, haggling has always been the true order of things in the bazaar. Most merchants enjoy the cut-and-thrust of bargaining and have scant respect for anyone who promptly pays what is asked.

As a general rule, offer about two-thirds of the original asking price and end up paying somewhere half way between the merchant's first price and your own. Don't be afraid to walk away - there is plenty of competition and you may always get the same thing cheaper elsewhere.

Where to eat

All of the more expensive hotels have good restaurants, but for something more local there is Felfela's (392 2751) - walking distance from the Nile Hilton, on Hoda Shaarawi street - which offers traditional Egyptian dishes such as stuffed vine-leaves, fuul beans, roast pigeon, grilled aubergines with olive oil. Dinner with beer or wine can cost as little as £5.

What to do out of town

The Cairo camel market at Birqash, about 35km northwest of the city centre, is reachable by taxi. The market - probably the largest camel souq in the world - symbolises the secret world of the desert, hidden behind the luxuriance of the Nile Valley. Egypt has few camels of its own, and virtually all the animals you will see at Birqash are brought on the hoof from the Sudan - more than 1,000 miles across the desert - by an ancient caravan route known as the Forty Days Road. The market flourishes most in the early mornings, and admission is about 20p per person, 10p for a camera and about £2.50 for a video camera.

Where to stay

Many of Cairo's hotels are part of the city's rich historical fabric.

Standing almost in the shadow of the pyramids, the Mena Palace Oberoi (383 3444) at Giza is where Winston Churchill, Lawrence of Arabia and others met in 1920 to decide the future of the Middle East. Originally an early 19th-century hunting lodge, it was converted into a hotel by an eccentric British couple, Hugh and Ethel Locke-King, who also created the famous golf course where crowned heads of Europe once practised their strokes. In 1915, the then Prince of Wales is said to have driven a golf ball on to one of its greens from the top of the second pyramid nearby. Single rooms cost about £146, doubles about £120pp including breakfast.

Shepheard's is another famous name - used as an HQ by Napoleon himself, and later the unofficial officers' mess of British forces in both the first and second world wars. The present Helnan Shepheard (355 3800), standing on the Nile Corniche near Tahrir Square, is not on the original site, but still conjures up something of the atmosphere of Victorian Cairo. Singles cost about £95 a night, doubles at £75pp.

The Semiramis InterContinental (355 3020) next door is a late 20th-century incarnation of another famous turn-of-the-century hotel that stood on the same site, but which now gives precedence to comfort rather than character. Rated as one of the city's top watering places, it is currently offering an excellent value weekend saver package at £75pp.

A little further up the Corniche is one of the best known of Cairo's modern inns, the Nile Hilton (578 0444), standing where the notoriously flea-ridden British barracks of Qasr an-Nil once stood, and offering somewhat more salubrious accommodation at £188 for singles, £135pp for doubles. The Hilton's coffee-shop terrace is one of the most pleasant places in the city to smoke a shisha , or waterpipe, and to drink a coffee or a beer, though it has a minimum charge of £4.50 per person. The hotel also boasts an excellent restaurant, Da Mario, offering pasta dishes at around £3.50.

The blade-shaped tower of the Ramses Hilton (574 4400) was designed so that every room has a breath-taking view over the city. Single rooms cost about £114, doubles about £77pp.

More basic but full of character is the Garden City House (354 4969). Rooms range from about £11-£18 with shared bathroom, and about £13-£20 with bath, including breakfast and dinner.

For something really downmarket, there is the Dahab Hotel (579 4400) in Mahmoud Bassiouni street, which offers huts on a rooftop, Arab-style floor cushions and bamboo screens. Doubles with private showers cost about £7.

How to get there

If you book before the end of this month, Trailfinders (020-7938 3939) offers Lufthansa return flights via Frankfurt for £236. British Airways (0845 7733377) offers direct scheduled flights from Heathrow for £352.10 inc tax.

· Michael Asher's new Cairo-based thriller, Firebird, is published on Monday by HarperCollins at £16.99.

The hotel also boasts an excellent restaurant, Da Mario, offering pasta dishes at around £3.50. The blade-shaped tower of the Ramses Hilton (574 4400) was designed so that every room has a breath-taking view over the city. Single rooms cost about £114, doubles about £77pp. More basic but full of character is the Garden City House (354 4969). Rooms range from about £11-£18 with shared bathroom, and about £13-£20 with bath, including breakfast and dinner. For something really downmarket, there is the Dahab Hotel (579 4400) in Mahmoud Bassiouni street, which offers huts on a rooftop, Arab-style floor cushions and bamboo screens. Doubles with private showers cost about £7. How to get there If you book before the end of this month, Trailfinders (020-7938 3939) offers Lufthansa return flights via Frankfurt for £236. British Airways (0845 7733377) offers direct scheduled flights from Heathrow for £352.10 inc tax. · Michael Asher's new Cairo-based thriller, Firebird, is published on Monday by HarperCollins at £16.99.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Minnesota

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Minnesota
fields.standfirst: Jim Keeble
fields.trailText: Jim Keeble
fields.body:
Why: It is one of those vast American states that is virtually empty of people. The licence plates read "Land of 10,000 Lakes" and that's basically it - lots of water, lots of trees but not a lot of people. Minnesota is quirky and the people are very strange and very endearing. Once you get out of Minneapolis, you are in rolling countryside with lakes and forests - classic American countryside exactly as you imagine it, with a frontier, backwoods, lumberjack mentality. It is like stepping on to the set for a movie about small-town America.

The best thing: I love the people, they are generously weird and just talk to you about nothing in particular. The stories all seem to come back to tactics for surviving the winter, which can get down to minus 40.

My advice: Sit in the middle of a continent, surrounded by land and know that there is nothing there. It is a wonderful feeling and something that is impossible to experience in Europe - it is the ultimate escapism.

How do I get there? British Airways (0345 222111) sells return tickets to Minneapolis via Chicago from £695; Virgin Atlantic (01293 747747) from £570.

 Independence Day, A Broken Heart's Voyage Around the USA, by Jim Keeble is published by Abacus at £10.99.

fields.trailText: Most people ask a friend before choosing their holiday. These awards are an extension of this principle. Some 17,000 friends - readers of the Guardian and Observer - responded to our questionnaire about their travels. The results offer a unique insight into the attitudes of a demanding group of travel consumers.
fields.body:
These are not just the longest-running consumer travel awards (launched in 1987); they are the most transparent. We declare the number of coupons assessed for every company in every category: the scoring system and the thresholds are made clear. Nothing is hidden or disguised. Just less than 17,000 questionnaires were completed. Readers were asked to name the companies they travelled with and to rate the quality of the service they received by ticking one of four boxes: excellent, good, fair or poor. We scored these results giving three points for excellent, two for good and one for fair - poor was zero-rated. Best brochure awards

Short breaks
Winner: Travelscene Paris & Amsterdam

Best cover in set that states what is being sold. Simple, unfussy layout, excellent price panels with minimum of supplements. Clean, with a rare example of clear symbols. We liked especially the "meatless & fancy free in Paris" symbol. A little gem.

Commended: Magic Cities
Also short-listed: Abercrombie & Kent Weekends and Beyond, Marriott Leisure Breaks and Simply Cities.

Long haul

Winner: Sunsail
Yes, it does have some British and European holidays but it is a new worldwide brochure. Good index page and interesting use of the layout grid. It gave a real sense of the holiday experience: clearly run by people who understand sailing.

Also short-listed: Cazenove & Loyd, Cox & Kings, Exodus and Seasons in the Sun.

Skiing
Winner: Mark Warner

Great feel of place from the images. The resort details were good and came with piste maps. An unfortunate cover with little impact but the open ing spreads gave a clear feel of the type of holiday being sold. The pricing was clear. Non-skiing families would also feel confident that this company knew what it was doing. Understated branding - perhaps rightly banking on the strength of the brand.

Also short-listed: Flexiski, Meriski, Ski Safari and the Ski Company.

Special interest
Winner: High Places

The recycled paper was just right for this brochure - and yet the images came out nicely. Wonderful fit of design and content on a budget. It worked to a grid but managed to vary the pattern. The testimonials were all the better for being attributed. A lot of ground is covered without complication thanks to the clear navigation.

Also short-listed: Bloomfield Rainforest Lodge, Dragoman, Hebridean Princess and Yes Iceland.

Summer
Winner: Eurocamp

Brilliant cover that skips straight into the theme of family holidays. The early pages explain the concept, leaving no doubt about what is being sold. Children will love the symbols and it is they who will force the holiday decision for camping. The gatefold is a superb tool for adults planning a self-drive holiday. Exciting.

Also short-listed: Mark Hammerton's Family Camping in France, The Greek Islands (Greek Sun), Tapestry Turkey and VFB's Cottage Holidays in France.

Mass market
Winner: Kuoni Tropical Sun

It dared to be different from the usual Kuoni approach. Also ready to break the design mould with pictures on right and text on left. Clichéd, but aimed at target audience. An easier job than the big summer "bible" brochures but a job well done.

Also short-listed: Cadogan Collection, JMC Summer Sun, Thomson's Just and Unijet Summer Sun.

Website
Winner: www.visitbritain.com

This was a site designed directly for the web with a unique search engine. The British Tourist Authority must be commended for seizing the opportunity to use the new medium to spread its message. The links were good but the search engine was slow on home lines. The design was clean and the messages clear. The foreign language translations were sometimes schoolboyish but a great attempt that can only get better.

Also short-listed: www.leski.co.uk, www.markhammerton.com, www.regal-diving.co.uk, www.wallacearnold.co.uk

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Share your expertise with fellow travellers
fields.body:
Amina Claasen does not want to travel as a female on her own. She wanted to know which group she could join that organises packages for single people.

I would suggest that Amina takes a look at the brochure for Ramblers Holidays (01707 331133). Moderate fitness is all that is required. You will find yourself in a mixed party of couples and singles to be taken off the beaten tourist track by a competent friendly leader. The evening meal is taken all together at one long table, so no hiding behind a book in the corner of the dining room.
MA Coulthard

I recommend the small personalised companies that specialise in one or two countries and those that offer special interest holidays, travelling in small groups (under 10) with guides who know the country and speak the language. This enables you to make friends easily and discover the authentic country. They also rarely charge a single supplement. Particular favourites are Gecko Travel (0239 2376799) and Symbiosis (020-7924 5906) - both specialising in SE Asia.
Jo Baker

Amina may be interested in holidays provided by organisations such as Exodus or Explore.

While they do not specifically cater for single people, their holidays are well suited to people on their own, and there tend to be quite a few single travellers in any group. There is no single supplement, although individuals will generally be expected to share a room with someone of the same sex, although (I had a tent to myself in Nepal). The holidays tend to be based on walking, cycling or sightseeing rather than beaches and nightclubs.

Group sizes vary but are smallish - 12 to 20 people maximum.Exodus (020-8673 0859) and Explore (01252 760 100)
Alison Mesher

I would recommend Solo's Holidays (020-8951 2811). Although not cheap, in my experience they always use quality hotels and you get a single room without paying a supplement. You'll meet lots of like-minded people and a group atmosphere always seems to develop, though there's no compulsion to stick with the group.

If your tastes in travel are more adventurous, there are many companies like Exodus that specialise in overland travel. Many of their clients seem to come on their own, so you won't stay alone for long.
Philip Garrison

This week's question

I am thinking of taking my two children, aged 10 and eight, on a six-month world trip from March to September. We will be travelling on our own most of the time, my husband joining us for two fortnight periods. Have any readers done this, and, if so, have they any advice on places to go, accommodation etc?
Janet Morris

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Canterbury tail | Rally round | Feel the beat
fields.body:
Canterbury tail
A naked female bottom from the Miller's Tale, sculpted by a local artist, swings out towards unsuspecting visitors at the Canterbury Tales attraction, minutes from Canterbury cathedral.

 Open daily, 10am-4.30pm (9am-5.30pm summer). £5.50/£4.60/family £17.50. Audio tours and guided walking tours. St Margaret's St, Canterbury, Kent (01227 479227).

Rally round
Almost 100 self-built vehicles will be on show at the Belsay Hall Rally, including Caterham Sevens, Marlins and the elegant Beauford drop head "wedding" car.

 Sunday, from noon (property open 10am-6pm). £3.80/£1.90 includes admission to the hall, castle and gardens. Belsay, Newcastle upon Tyne, Northumberland (01661 881636).

Feel the beat
Cartoon characters, metronomes and throbbing sound-tracks take visitors on a journey through nature's life cycles from birth to death, in the Rhythms of Life exhibition at the Natural History Museum.

 Open daily until May 2001, 10am-5.50pm. £7.50/children free. Exhibition Road, London SW7 (020-7942 5000).

Lock stock
The key to Rotherham's Town Lock Festival is boating activity on the canal, plus bankside walks, family entertainment and mock trials in the Magistrates Court Open Day.

 Saturday, 10am-5pm. Rotherham Town Centre, Yorks (01709 835904).

Hey nonny
You can take a giant leap back to 15th-century England at Warwick Castle's Medieval Festival. Jousting knights, wandering minstrels, armourers, birds of prey displays and duelling knights add to the atmosphere.

 Open daily until Sept 10, 10am-6pm. £10.95/£6.50/family £29. Warwick Castle, Warwick (01926 406600).

Eyes up
Harry Potter's broomstick has nothing on the Red Arrows. More than 36 displays are expected at the Festival of Flight, the biggest civil air show in Scotland.

 Sat/Sun, 8am-6pm. Cars £20, pedestrians £8/£3. The Museum of Flight, East Fortune, East Lothian (01620 880308).

High as a kite
Fly your kite on Dunstable Downs. Displays by experts will show you how it's done.

 Sunday, noon-4pm. Free. Countryside Centre, Whipsnade Road, Kewnsworth, Dunstable, Beds (01582-608489).

Battle stations
The War and Peace Show in Kent claims to be the world's largest military show, with tank rides, battle re-enactments, a militaria market and an army of military vehicles and equipment.

 July 19-23, 9am-6pm. £6/£4, family £17; weekend £8/£6/£25. Hop Farm Country Park, Beltring, Kent (01622 872068).

fields.headline: England's perfect ten-wicket win
fields.standfirst:
West Indies 169 for 8 (50 overs)
England 171 for 0 (35.2 overs)
England won by ten wickets
fields.trailText: This is as good as it gets. England cruised to a clinical ten-wicket victory - their first in one-day internationals - over West Indies in the NatWest Triangular Series at Chester-le-Street, knocking off the 170 they needed with more than 14 overs to spare. Marcus Trescothick hit a fluent unbeaten 89, while Alec Stewart was not out 74. Only a miracle will deny England a place in the final now.
fields.body:
This is as good as it gets. England cruised to a clinical ten-wicket victory - their first in one-day internationals - over West Indies in the NatWest Triangular Series at Chester-le-Street, knocking off the 170 they needed with more than 14 overs to spare. Marcus Trescothick hit a fluent unbeaten 89, while Alec Stewart was not out 74. Only a miracle will deny England a place in the final now.

It was a superbly controlled opening stand. Trescothick's great strength in this series has been his cover driving, and he was quickly into his stride here, timing Reon King to the extra-cover boundary in the third over with no more than a push.

England scored just 16 from the first six overs, but there was no hurry, particularly after Stewart pulled King for four in the seventh over, before cutting him high over point for four more three balls later. 'Sex Bomb' blared out over the tannoy.

Nixon McLean came on in the eighth over, but he dropped too short and Trescothick pulled for four. Stewart meanwhile had moved to 12, his score in each of his first three innings in this tournament so far, and looked relieved when he managed three through midwicket off Mervyn Dillon.

Trescothick continued to sparkle. In the next over, from McLean, he followed a gorgeous cover drive for four with a squarer, equally elegant drive to the boundary three balls later. It brought up the England 50 in the 12th over.

Stewart carved Dillon for four square on the offside in the next over. The crowd roared its approval, but West Indies had gone very quiet. Without Curtly and Courtney, they look ordinary in the field.

Franklyn Rose was given a go, but he drifted onto Trescothick's pads and the ball sped away wide of mid-on. And when Dillon overpitched in the next over, Trescothick launched him through extra cover with the shot of the day.

Desperate for a wicket, Jimmy Adams brought on Chris Gayle with his slow dobbers. But the runs kept coming. Stewart pulled Rose emphatically for four, before Trescothick reached his second fifty of the series with a gentle push for a single off Gayle to long-off.

fields.headline: So far - so good
fields.standfirst: It's a country that promises something for everyone, which is probably why you voted it your favourite long-haul destination in this year's Guardian and Observer Travel Awards.  Jonathan Freedland  explores
fields.trailText: It's a country that promises something for everyone, which is probably why you voted it your favourite long-haul destination in this year's Guardian and Observer Travel Awards. Jonathan Freedland explores.
fields.body:
It is the Caribbean and the English countryside, Antarctica and California, Sydney and Gleneagles all rolled into one. It is the department store of holidays, promising everything you could want under one, clear sky.

Like any good store, some of the lines are tried and trusted and none more so than the brochure's promise to transport tourists back to the England of the 1950s. For years, the clichéd view of New Zealand was that the green hills and polite, provincial manners combined to provide a kind of heritage themepark for the nostalgic Brit.

Go-ahead, modern Kiwis - particularly those on the North Island - loathe that idea, of course. They insist NZ has become a cool, Pacific nation looking forward towards Asia rather than back to the old country. They're mostly right, but the British influence has not vanished completely. The South Island still boasts towns called Middlemarch, Cromwell and Palmerston, while Christchurch might have been prised out of the Home Counties and air-dropped from the sky.

Even the trendier North Island has reminders of the first settlers' country of origin. Head east out of Auckland, around the Firth of Thames and into the Coromandel Peninsula, and you'll see enough hills, valleys and sheep to remind you of the Scotland or Wales that the pioneers left behind.

In Auckland itself, you can sample a taste of home by bedding down at the Aachen House, a boutique hotel built in Edwardian style in 1913 for an English doctor. The chintzy bedrooms, sunny conservatory and warm hospitality will remind you of the best of Blighty.

But nostalgia-travel is not what it used to be, at least as far as being the top-selling product in the NZ holiday-shop. In the past decade, the country has cultivated an altogether different lure for a new generation of traveller, becoming the number-one playground for danger-junkies. On the backpacker circuit, Queenstown on the South Island has become an essential stop - the place where gap-year daredevils try their hand at paragliding, tandem-parachuting or extreme sports that promise a face-to-face encounter with the Grim Reaper.

A special badge of honour is reserved for those who have notched up the Awesome Foursome: bungee jumping, skydiving, whitewater rafting and zorbing. (For the uninitiated, to zorb involves being strapped inside a giant plastic ball and rolled down a hill, hurtling at such breakneck speeds that gravity plasters your body against the sides.)

For those who don't fancy the taste of their own heart between their teeth as they careen in a jet-powered boat through an inches-wide canyon, NZ has often seemed like an afterthought, a bolt-on extra to Australia, only worth visiting if there's time.

But that is to forget the country's role as the variety pack of holiday destinations, with a little bit for everyone. If a beach vacation is your thing, for example, look no further. NZ, with its long, thin, banana shape, has just short of 10,000 miles of coastline - shared between just 3.8 million people. The result is a land of empty, pristine beaches, a place where you can find a stretch of fine sand and clear water, spread out your towel - and not see a soul all day.

And the beaches are not all the same. In the Coromandel, you can leave behind the tourists on Waihi beach, take a half-hour walk high up in the mountain bush and descend on to Orokawa, site of an ancient gold mine where the sea crashes and curls with white surf, as if in a sound-and-light display.

Or you can head in the opposite direction and see the shore from a whole new angle - from the top of a horse. An hour's drive west out of Auckland takes you to Muriwai Beach, where a couple of gentle mares can be yours for a morning's canter, courtesy of the local riding centre. Don't worry if you're new in the saddle: the horses are blessed with an intuitive gearbox that makes them amble along at strolling speed - if that's what you want. Once you are ready to pick up the pace, they will sense it - galloping through the surf and racing over the flats of black sand that glitter in the daylight, as if embedded with precious jewels.

A couple of hours are exhilarating, not just for the thighs but also on the eyes. Close by Muriwai Beach is a gannet colony and a famed stretch of surfing water: whichever exotic creature you enjoy watching, there's a perfect view from here.

But no self-respecting beach-hunters will ever forgive themselves if they leave it at that. They'll want to take the coastal road a tad further south and make for Karekare. It may be on the other side of the world, but you would recognise it immediately. For Karekare was the location of perhaps the most memorable movie beach scene since Burt Lancaster and Deborah Kerr rolled around in From Here to Eternity. It was here that Holly Hunter was washed up, along with child and beloved instrument, in The Piano.

You can see why New Zealand-born director Jane Campion dragged her entire cast and crew down the tiny, windy roads and sharp hillsides to reach Karekare. The beach is impossibly wide and almost absurdly beautiful - not in a picture-postcard way, but with a rugged, austere grandeur. The sand is dark and stretches the length of a football pitch before it touches the ocean. The cliffs are sheer and stark, the rocks bold and craggy - one curve forms a natural bay that the locals call The Cauldron, where the surf crashes and roars like hellfire. Visit here in early January, the height of the summer season, and you will be able to run, whirl and even dance on the sand without embarrassment because you will have the whole, magical place to yourselves.

If that does not satisfy the appetite for sun and sea, South Island has some jewels of its own. Most Kiwis rarely take the short flight between the two islands, so the south is more roomy and unspoiled. For an absolute pearl, the destination ought to be the Abel Tasman National Park.

This corner of the coast has been entirely preserved from development, some of its bays and inlets accessible only on foot or by boat. The result is an area that, if it were anywhere else in the world, would have been over-run long ago with hotels, nightclubs and beachside restaurants - but which is virginally untouched. You can spend a day sea-kayaking from one natural lagoon to another, or hiking along the bush trail, encountering no sign of tourism other than your own good self.

Now a clutch of eco-friendly tour operators arrange three- or five-day trips through the Abel Tasman park - with guides who will show a novice couple how to steer and paddle a two-person canoe in the ocean or simply navigate your path through the thick, dense bush. Either option is magnificent, whether it is the satisfaction of docking the boat on a deserted beachside or scaling a hillside crowded with silver ferns before reaching a perfect view.

A spot such as Torrent Bay would look quite at home in a Caribbean brochure of paradise island beaches, complete as it is with turquoise blue water and bone-white sand.

To add to the appeal for the non-backpacker, the family-run Abel Tasman National Park Enterprises has a string of ultra-comfortable lodges along the coast - so you can unwind with a glass of New Zealand chardonnay while a first-rate chef rustles up dinner. Like NZ itself, Abel Tasman offers two kinds of holiday - adventure and luxury - in one.

The choice does not end there. If a California-style trip is your thing, NZ has it covered. Outside Auckland, whose wharfside fish restaurants and sushi bars would not be out of place in San Diego, there are plenty of towns such as Titirangi - funky, granola communities where the organic cafés jostle for space with the new age health stores. On South Island, you can stroll down Nelson's Trafalgar Street which, despite the name, owes more to San Francisco than to SW1. Here the vegetarian eateries, stripy sweaters and green awareness meetings would make any Californian feel at home. NZ even has its own Pacific Coast Highway - not quite the same as Route 1 from LA, but with views of pelican colonies and native wildlife that are just as spectacular.

But perhaps the closest connection with California is the wine. Like South Africa or Australia, NZ has a thriving wine industry specialising in the light, warm taste of the new world. For a tourist, there can be few more joyful ways to pass a day than with a visit to, say, the Neudorf vineyard outside Nelson. Anyone is welcome to take a table in the garden, spread out a picnic and turn their face toward the sun - and their nostrils toward the grapes ripening all around. It is an idyllic spot, matched only by the prospect of dinner around the corner in Mapua - at a local legend of a restaurant called Nature Smoke, right on the water. There, naturally, smoked fish and seafood served with fresh vegetables are washed down with local wines. Get there early, to guarantee a table and enjoy the sunshine.

If it is mountains that you're after, South Island has a range larger than the French, Austrian and Swiss Alps combined, while the North has its very own volcanic region (to say nothing of the geysers and hot springs of Rotorua). Add to that the fjords, glaciers, lakes and rainforests, and you should always have plenty to admire.

Even the political tourist has reason to visit New Zealand: the country now has a radical left-wing, pro-republican government that is fulfilling all its promises while remaining popular. Now that, surely, is worth travelling across the world to see.

The practicals

Tourism New Zealand: The best time to visit is during the British winter.

Air New Zealand (02087412299) offers return flights from Heathrow to Auckland or Christchurch, via Los Angeles, with optional stop-over, costs from £718 inc tax.

Neudorf Vineyards, Neudorf Road, Upper Moutere, Nelson (tel: 64 3 543 2643)
Muriwai Beach Riding Centre, Muriwai Beach (tel: 64 9 411 8480).
Abel Tasman National Park Enterprises, PO Box 351, Motueka, Nelson (tel: 64 3 5287801).

Aachen House hotel, 39 Market Road, Remuera, Auckland (tel: 64 9 520 2329), rooms from NZ$150
Copthorne Rutherford Hotel, Trafalgar Square, Nelson (tel:64 3 5482299) rooms from $122.

fields.headline: Package holidays for single travellers
fields.standfirst:
I hope to go on holiday this summer, but don't want to travel as a female on my own. Who can I contact or which group can I join that organises packages for single people such as myself who feel happier and more secure travelling as part of a group.
Amina Claasen
fields.trailText: I hope to go on holiday this summer, but don't want to travel as a female on my own. Who can I contact or which group can I join that organises packages for single people such as myself who feel happier and more secure travelling as part of a group.
fields.body:
 I would suggest that Amina takes a look at the brochure for Ramblers Holidays (01707 331133). Moderate fitness is all that is required. You will find yourself in a mixed party of couples and singles to be taken off the beaten tourist track by a competent friendly leader. The evening meal is taken all together at one long table, so no hiding behind a book in the corner of the dining room.
MA Coulthard

 I recommend the small personalised companies that specialise in one or two countries and those that offer special interest holidays, travelling in small groups (under 10) with guides who know the country and speak the language. This enables you to make friends easily and discover the authentic country. They also rarely charge a single supplement. Particular favourites are Gecko Travel (0239 2376799) and Symbiosis (020-7924 5906) - both specialising in SE Asia.
Jo Baker

 Amina may be interested in holidays provided by organisations such as Exodus or Explore.

While they do not specifically cater for single people, their holidays are well suited to people on their own, and there tend to be quite a few single travellers in any group. There is no single supplement, although individuals will generally be expected to share a room with someone of the same sex, although (I had a tent to myself in Nepal). The holidays tend to be based on walking, cycling or sightseeing rather than beaches and nightclubs.

Group sizes vary but are smallish - 12 to 20 people maximum.Exodus (020-8673 0859) and Explore (01252 760 100)
Alison Mesher

 I would recommend Solo's Holidays (020-8951 2811). Although not cheap, in my experience they always use quality hotels and you get a single room without paying a supplement. You'll meet lots of like-minded people and a group atmosphere always seems to develop, though there's no compulsion to stick with the group.

If your tastes in travel are more adventurous, there are many companies like Exodus that specialise in overland travel. Many of their clients seem to come on their own, so you won't stay alone for long.
Philip Garrison

fields.headline: Disgrace to the nation
fields.standfirst: Jason Isaacs' role in American Revolution epic The Patriot suggests that the British were dastardly, cheating torturers - something he takes great pride in.
fields.trailText: Jason Isaacs' role in American Revolution epic The Patriot suggests that the British were dastardly, cheating torturers - something he takes great pride in.
fields.body:
Last seen playing the priest in The End Of The Affair, Jason Isaacs is currently torturing his way through the American Revolution in The Patriot. As the villainous Colonel William Tavington, he gets to face off with Mel Gibson in what's by far the biggest movie role of his career. Now 37, Isaacs graduated from the Central School Of Speech And Drama and has appeared in award-winning plays like Angels In America, on TV in Capital City and Lynda LaPlante's Civvies, as well as playing the cleverest man on the planet in the 1998 blockbuster Armageddon.

Is it true you cried after first reading the script for The Patriot?

Yeah. I'm very sentimental. I'm aesthetically sentimental. I cry at that Yellow Pages advert where they go out and buy their gardener a drive-around lawn-mower. I'm sad like that, but it was a cracking story.

Was it a fun film to make?

I had an embarrassingly enjoyable five months. I got to be on a horse every day, I got to command an army, I got to do scenes with some fantastic actors, one of whom was a global superstar. It was a very unhierarchical set. For a film that's full of battle scenes, it was a very gentle set. I didn't hear anybody raise their voice once.

What about Mel Gibson, notorious practical joker?

Mel jokes around a lot but he does it for very good reasons. Acting is play. I mean, it's not a very serious job. We're just like a bunch of kids playing around in a sandpit.

Didn't the Brit-bashing worry you?

Not at all. First of all, Britain's history with the empire is shameful. Then when I looked into the history of the man who was the base for the character I was playing, he was despised. He was known as "The Butcher" and he was famous for slaughtering his opponents when they'd surrendered and for leaving IOUs all over South Carolina.

So you had a lot in common with him?

Actually he has lots of strange parallels with my life: he was the third of four sons from Liverpool, which I am, and he studied law, which I did, and then he became addicted to gambling and whoring. I went to drama school, which isn't too dissimilar.

Why did you study law at Bristol University?

It seemed like something that problem-solvers should do. I've always liked doing crosswords and I thought it would exercise my brain. It turned out to be too much exercise because I'm a lazy sod.

So you took up acting instead and it all clicked?

The first time I went into a rehearsal room, I felt like I belonged. It didn't matter where you came from or what your accent was because you had a common purpose, and there was a ready-made community of friends, people to sleep with. I was always shy around girls but if you're rehearsing with someone and you get to know them well, you end up sleeping with them. Certainly as a student that was the case.

Would you like to be a leading man?

There's virtually nothing to do as an actor in leading man parts, other than be charming and charismatic. I'm not an actor because I really want people to know who I am; I think one of the reasons I was attracted to acting is that I get to be other people.

This is your highest-profile role so far, but you don't seem to be getting too excited.

I think that's pretty sensible. I've got lots of mates who've had jobs that got people saying, "This is really going to change your life," and it not only didn't change their life, it really screwed them up. My life is really pretty good at the moment. I hope things don't change too much, I don't want them to.

As the villainous Colonel William Tavington, he gets to face off with Mel Gibson in what's by far the biggest movie role of his career. Now 37, Isaacs graduated from the Central School Of Speech And Drama and has appeared in award-winning plays like Angels In America, on TV in Capital City and Lynda LaPlante's Civvies, as well as playing the cleverest man on the planet in the 1998 blockbuster Armageddon. I cry at that Yellow Pages advert where they go out and buy their gardener a drive-around lawn-mower. I'm sad like that, but it was a cracking story. Was it a fun film to make? I had an embarrassingly enjoyable five months. I got to be on a horse every day, I got to command an army, I got to do scenes with some fantastic actors, one of whom was a global superstar. It was a very unhierarchical set. For a film that's full of battle scenes, it was a very gentle set. I didn't hear anybody raise their voice once. What about Mel Gibson, notorious practical joker? Mel jokes around a lot but he does it for very good reasons. Acting is play. I mean, it's not a very serious job. We're just like a bunch of kids playing around in a sandpit. fields.headline: Elasticated sleeping bags
fields.trailText: Easy to sit up and move around in the bag.
fields.body:
Why elasticated? Because the average human turns over 40 times a night.

So? Traditional bags can be too tight: any movement is a struggle.

Like a straitjacket? Wakes you up, drives you mad. These let you move more easily.

What's the trade-off? Increased weight, risk of cold spots.

So how do they do it? The UK's Mountain Equipment just elasticate the knee area, so the vital chest and feet don't lose heat. Easy to sit up and move around in the bag.

Other makes? So far, Canada's Sierra Designs. They elasticate the full length, but aren't on sale here yet. More firms will follow.

Are they more expensive? ME's part-elasticated Sleepwalker is around £100. Synthetic rather than down insulation keeps the price low.

So it's the coming thing? Retailers say they're walking out of the shops.

What else is new? Baffles. Top-of-the-range bags from Rab, Mountain Equipment and Mountain Hardware have variously-shaped baffles, which keep the goose down well spread out. Lots of "fillpower" and "loft" .

Stop showing off. Fillpower measures the height of one ounce of down - 450 is about average, but the best bags have 700-plus.

And loft? Loft means nice and puffy: it's the height off the floor when you pull it out of its stuffsack and lay it out.

How much do the top ones knock you back? Between £300 and £370. But they keep you warm at 30 degrees below.

I'm only going to Cornwall for the summer. Then pick a good all-rounder for about £100.

Where do I get one? Specialist outdoor shops and chains: Cotswold and Field and Trek. Visit also www.snowandrock.com, www.rab.uk.com, www.sierra-designs.com, www.mountain-equipment.co.uk and www.mountainhardward.com.

What's the alternative? A couple of blankets; a touch of hypothermia.

webTitle: Susan Greenfield: Eye make-up remover | An escapist novel | A gold Columbian figure

fields.headline: Susan Greenfield never travels without...
fields.trailText: Eye make-up remover | An escapist novel | A gold Columbian figure
fields.body:
A necessity: Eye make-up remover. I always wear eye make-up and, if I can't remove it properly at the end of the day, I feel all gungy. Soap and water is never enough.

A luxury: A good, thick escapist novel, but a well-written one. I hate bad writing.

A memento: I have a little gold Columbian figure which was given to me by a colleague when I was working in the US 20 years ago. It is in my purse wherever I go and is like an old friend.

If only: I would love a personalised collection of miniature toiletries. I always take too much as I'm worried about running out.

 Susan Greenfield is director of the Royal Institution. Her series Brain Story begins on BBC2 at 9pm on Tuesday July 18.

fields.headline: Blunkett humiliated in pay row
fields.standfirst: Judge rules that formula to decide teachers' wages is illegal
fields.trailText: Pay rises for up to 200,000 teachers were put on hold yesterday when a high court judge humiliated the education secretary, David Blunkett, by ruling that he broke the law in setting standards for the performance-related pay without proper consultation.
fields.body:
Pay rises for up to 200,000 teachers were put on hold yesterday when a high court judge humiliated the education secretary, David Blunkett, by ruling that he broke the law in setting standards for the performance-related pay without proper consultation.

Mr Justice Jackson's verdict was a victory for the National Union of Teachers, which brought the judicial review against a key plank of the government's education reforms.

But Mr Blunkett and rival unions railed against the NUT, warning that its "pyrrhic victory" would delay applications for a £2,000 pay rise made by more than 197,000 teachers in England and Wales.

The judge declared that Mr Blunkett's Education (School Teachers' Pay and Conditions) (No 2) Order 2000, which came into effect on April 1 and effectively rewrote the contracts of 400,000 teachers, was a "hybrid and flawed" document.

Gavin Millar QC, for the NUT, said that the document sowed "division and conflict" because heads of department were required to assess their own colleagues' suitability for the pay award. The union called it "informing".

The judge ruled that Mr Blunkett had acted outside the powers of the 1991 Teachers' Pay and Conditions Act. He said the threshold standards should have been placed before parliament, the Welsh assembly and the School Teachers Review Body (STRB).

"Albeit with good intentions", the education secretary had effectively "evaded scrutiny" by legislators. Under the ruling, the assessment procedure is now illegal.

Mr Blunkett will now have to consult the STRB in full and - though government sources thought this unlikely - he may even have to bring the measure back before parliament and the Welsh assembly.

Head teachers will be advised to keep the pay applications on file in the meantime. Ministers have already said that most teachers will be granted the award. This may now be paid in December or January and backdated to September 1.

Steve Sinnott, the assistant general secretary of the NUT, said the NUT wanted every teacher to be given the £2,000 pay rise.

"This government has shown enormous arrogance in the way it has treated teachers. It has assumed it can change their contracts of employment by whim and messages on the internet," he added.

Mr Blunkett said he was taking legal advice on whether to appeal. He told BBC Radio 4's PM programme: "They've [the NUT] had a pyrrhic victory as well as a victory in the court. The judges ruled - and I obviously appreciate that - that we didn't follow the procedures in quite the way he would expect.

"I take the advice of my civil servants and if that advice is wrong in the end I carry the can for it - they don't ... I'm embarrassed that the advice I've received has proved to be inadequate, I'm embarrassed that I took it.

"But I'm not embarrassed about the performance-related promotion, the prospects for paying good teachers well, giving them entirely new scales which they can aspire to as good teachers."

Nigel de Gruchy, leader of the second largest teaching union, the National Union of Schoolmasters / Union of Women Teachers, said he had received the same legal advice as the NUT and had warned the government against using a fast-track procedure to push the plan through.

But he added: "The NUT success in the high court could penalise teachers more than the government."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "Head teachers are distressed and angry at the chaos into which the threshold pay application process has been thrown."

The NUT said that even without its action there would have been delays in introducing the pay increase, with the deadline for applying for the rise extended until yesterday, the eve of the summer holidays.

The STRB, chaired by the industrialist Tony Vineall, recommends teachers' pay awards after hearing submissions from government, unions and school inspectors. The government tends to follow its recommendations with minor modifications.

It had complained about some aspects of the PRP but accepted Mr Blunkett's decision to push ahead with the order without full consultation.

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: Paddle Sports  (Discovery Travel Adventures/ Insight Guides, £14.99)
fields.trailText: Paddle Sports
fields.body:
If you thought paddling holidays were all about rolled-up trouser legs and kiss-me-quick hats, think again. There's plenty of rock in this book, but it comes in canyons, not sticks. Welcome to the world of rafts and kayaks. Come on in - the water's lovely.

And whatever the picture on the cover suggests, it's not always white. Sure, there's an "extreme" side to paddle sports, but alongside all this rushing adrenalin there runs a gentler current. This guide is as much about exploring the Big Country (the country in question being North America) as making a bigger splash. There's a section on canoe touring, and detailed information on a score of locations, so you can plan an adventure holiday and avoid finding yourself up Proverbial Creek without a paddle.

fields.headline: Hendrickje Stoffels, Rembrandt (c. 1654-6)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Rembrandt van Rijn (1606-1669), whose intimate, expressionist paintings were modern before modernism, and are indisputably the greatest portraits of all time.

Subject: Hendrickje Stoffels (d.1663), who was part of Rembrandt's household at least from 1649, initially as housekeeper and nurse to his son Titus. Soon afterwards she became Rembrandt's lover.

Distinguishing features: There's the irresistible suggestion of the aftermath of sex in this painting. Hendrickje Stoffels is in what can easily be imagined as a bedroom, wearing a fur wrap, a gold necklace, pearl earrings and jewels in her hair.Under the wrap she is wearing a white shift, but it doesn't hide much. She's relaxed about showing the painter her breasts, her naked throat. The fur and the jewels heighten rather than hide her nakedness. Even after they've both been dead for centuries, and even though we have no final proof that this even is a portrait of Hendrickje Stoffels, the way she drapes her hand over a gilt rest, the way she looks back at Rembrandt - at us - leaves no doubt as to what this is about.

Hendrickje is located in a dark, private, interior space in which she and the artist share their deepest secrets. The redness that burns on the left of the painting is fierily erotic. It sets off the fluffy whiteness of the fur wrap, whose painting is deliberately unfinished, heightening the impressionistic casualness. Rembrandt uses these painterly pleasures to make us feel the physical presence of Hendrickje; the milky texture of the fur makes us aware of our own flesh and therefore hers. Her body is substantial and adult; her hand is sculpted, monumental, her face not idealised but real. Hendrickje's eyes are big, black pools full of thought. It's the consciousness behind those eyes that makes you pause before this painting, convinced you are looking at someone who is looking back at you with complete intimacy.

In 1654, Hendrickje Stoffels appeared before the Church Council of Amsterdam accused of "living in whoredom with the painter Rembrandt". This painting answers the charge of whoredom not by denying sex but glorifying it. Rembrandt painted Hendrickje several times in the mid-1650s, not only in straight portraits but also in biblical poses. He painted her as Bathsheba, the young wife of Uriah the Hittite lusted after by King David; and, possibly, as Susannah spied on by the Elders in the National Gallery's A Woman Bathing in a Stream. These Bible stories concern the lasciviousness of old men, satirising the disapproving patriarchs of the Church Council and perhaps mocking his own love for a younger woman. But in this painting, myth is put aside and Rembrandt asserts his love directly. You also get a sense of Hendrickje Stoffels's strength. She was to support Rembrandt in his desperate old age and she and Titus became his business representatives when he was declared insolvent.

Rembrandt's unconcealed, intense sexuality in this portrait makes you think of Picasso or Degas. But where these modern artists are brutal and possessive in their depictions of women, Rembrandt is tender. The sexuality of this painting is not that of a voyeuristic elder spying on Susannah. It is loving. It is about recognising the full, real presence of a lover.

Where is it? Room 23, National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).
