webTitle: The suburb where one in four voted BNP

fields.headline: The suburb where one in four voted BNP
fields.standfirst:
Campaign targeting a handful of asylum seekers creates poll 'triumph' for far right in a deprived corner of south-east London
Special report
fields.trailText: For a loser, Colin Smith is a happy man. He has every right to be. Representing a minority party campaigning on a single local issue with only a handful of activists to help get his message across, he last week pulled off an electoral coup.
fields.body:
For a loser, Colin Smith is a happy man. He has every right to be. Representing a minority party campaigning on a single local issue with only a handful of activists to help get his message across, he last week pulled off an electoral coup.

In a council byelection in the North End ward of Bexley, south-east London, Mr Smith lost - but came second behind the Labour candidate and pushed the Tories into third place in the process. It was, his party newspaper trumpeted, a triumph.

It was also a triumph for fear, hatred and racism. Mr Smith represents the British National party, and campaigned on a single issue: asylum seekers.

In election literature and on the ward's 4,000-odd doorsteps, Mr Smith played on fear and prejudice. North End was a "dumping ground" for "undeserving scroungers", he said; asylum seekers were housed as a priority while homeless local people stayed on waiting lists and illegal immigrants "milk the benefit system" while "British children are in poverty".

The literature did not mention that Bexley has 390 asylum seekers - fewer than all but two of London's 33 boroughs. Just 17 families seeking asylum live within the ward. None the less, it was a persuasive message. The BNP took 26.2% of the vote. "British people have sent a message to Tony Blair - democracy is coming home," Mr Smith said this week.

Forlorn

North End lies just south of Erith at the eastern edge of Greater London - a cluster of low-rise estates centred on a forlorn precinct of shops and Slade Green railway station. It shares none of the leafy desirability of nearby Bexleyheath or Upper Belvedere. Unemployment runs at 8%, twice the national average; around half the housing is owned by the council or housing associations; teenage pregnancy rates are higher than elsewhere in Bexley, as is the incidence of poor health. Vandalism, burglary and drugs blight the lives of residents, 96% of whom are white.

For the BNP a deprived area such as North End is fertile ground. "On the doorsteps it is made for us," said Mr Smith.

But while he sees political opportunity, Linda Taylor's experience is very different. She runs the Howbury Park hostel in North End, an emergency housing facility with room for nine families. It is available to anyone with an acute housing need, but in the past two years has accommodated asylum seekers from the Czech Republic, Poland, Croatia, Rwanda, Afghanistan, Serbia, Latvia and Dubai. It has come under attack as a result.

"We have had lots of harassment. Much of it is not reported to the police because people are scared, but it got to the stage where the children couldn't play in the garden because of the abuse," she said.

Until recently local youths would gather and throw bricks over the garden wall, shouting racist abuse and spitting at the foreign children. White children living at the hostel were left in peace. In response Bexley council installed CCTV cameras and replaced the wall with railings so that the youths could no longer hurl bricks without being seen.

"We've seen improvement here but the assaults, name calling, and abuse all continue outside," said Ms Taylor.

One Romany family from Poland returned home after their daughters were attacked at Slade Green fair, while another Polish man was attacked with a bottle on his way to the shops. Neither incident was reported to the police.

"What people misunderstand is that this centre is for all people, not just asylum seekers. Anyone who comes here is at rock bottom, black or white. Within the hostel their children play together with no problem," said Ms Taylor.

"The other kids, 'the baseball hat brigade', are different. Their parents encourage them to racism. But the majority of people are decent, honest and not racist."

Debbie Lee, Ms Taylor's neighbour, is typical of that majority. Her husband Dave, a lorry driver, has twice been attacked by asylum seekers trying to get into his vehicle on the continent, but she still feels asylum seekers deserve sympathy.

"If they are genuine then fair enough. I don't agree with the bogus ones, but real ones deserve a chance. I told the BNP where to go when they knocked on my door. They are using asylum to bring up racism, and that is wrong."

English nationalism has long been strong south of the Thames estuary, and the BNP's strength lies in harnessing lo cal disaffection to antipathy towards asylum seekers, who are no more than a convenient scapegoats in an area with profound problems.

The North End result sent shock waves beyond Bexley. Most tellingly, it raised concerns within Conservative central office that immoderate language employed by the Tories on asylum might have been partly responsible for the improving fortunes of the BNP.

The Tory candidate for London mayor, Steven Norris, went further. "It looks as if the BNP is on the up. I don't believe a politician in any party can afford to relax their guard. If you just appeal to your core vote, it can be very satisfying, but it is not going to win a general election," he said.

Perhaps not, but in this deprived corner of the greater London hinterland, race in politics is a matter of degrees. No mainstream candidate can ignore it here and hope to win popular support.

Tory election literature was in some respects indistinguishable from the that of the BNP. "For bogus asylum seekers ... Britain is the biggest soft touch in the world," it read.

Nationalist

The local Labour MP, Nigel Beard, is mindful that nationalist feelings run deep in Bexley. "I do have to take into account that this is an area with a long tradition of English patriotism. There is a deep feeling of identification with the country's tradition and history which is perfectly acceptable and valid," he said.

"I walk into pubs and people shout, 'when are you going to do something for the English?' That is not racist, it is a feeling of being bypassed, left in the queue for services while others go to the front. The area is almost exclusively white working class. It is an understandable reaction."

Drinking in the Cross Keys at nearby Erith, Del and Ken bear out Mr Beard's point. Ken says the town is "bursting with Bosnians", that they are "scumbags, no asset to anyone". He says the council saves all the money for the middle class wards, and dumps the asylum seekers on his doorstep. Del agrees, and says an anti-racism festival planned for September will cause trouble. "They spend money on all that, but not on me and my family."

The BNP knocked on Ken and Del's doors, but neither of them could be bothered to vote. Apathy may yet halt the racists' progress.

 North End ward byelection

Labour: 772 (44.4%)

BNP: 456 (26.2%)

Conservative: 413 (23.8%)

Lib Dem: 99 (5.7%)

Turnout: 19.34%
fields.bodyText: For a loser, Colin Smith is a happy man. He has every right to be. Representing a minority party campaigning on a single local issue with only a handful of activists to help get his message across, he last week pulled off an electoral coup. In a council byelection in the North End ward of Bexley, south-east London, Mr Smith lost - but came second behind the Labour candidate and pushed the Tories into third place in the process. It was, his party newspaper trumpeted, a triumph. It was also a triumph for fear, hatred and racism. Mr Smith represents the British National party, and campaigned on a single issue: asylum seekers. In election literature and on the ward's 4,000-odd doorsteps, Mr Smith played on fear and prejudice. North End was a "dumping ground" for "undeserving scroungers", he said; asylum seekers were housed as a priority while homeless local people stayed on waiting lists and illegal immigrants "milk the benefit system" while "British children are in poverty". The literature did not mention that Bexley has 390 asylum seekers - fewer than all but two of London's 33 boroughs. Just 17 families seeking asylum live within the ward. None the less, it was a persuasive message. The BNP took 26.2% of the vote. "British people have sent a message to Tony Blair - democracy is coming home," Mr Smith said this week. Forlorn North End lies just south of Erith at the eastern edge of Greater London - a cluster of low-rise estates centred on a forlorn precinct of shops and Slade Green railway station. It shares none of the leafy desirability of nearby Bexleyheath or Upper Belvedere. Unemployment runs at 8%, twice the national average; around half the housing is owned by the council or housing associations; teenage pregnancy rates are higher than elsewhere in Bexley, as is the incidence of poor health. Vandalism, burglary and drugs blight the lives of residents, 96% of whom are white. For the BNP a deprived area such as North End is fertile ground. "On the doorsteps it is made for us," said Mr Smith. But while he sees political opportunity, Linda Taylor's experience is very different. She runs the Howbury Park hostel in North End, an emergency housing facility with room for nine families. It is available to anyone with an acute housing need, but in the past two years has accommodated asylum seekers from the Czech Republic, Poland, Croatia, Rwanda, Afghanistan, Serbia, Latvia and Dubai. It has come under attack as a result. "We have had lots of harassment. Much of it is not reported to the police because people are scared, but it got to the stage where the children couldn't play in the garden because of the abuse," she said. Until recently local youths would gather and throw bricks over the garden wall, shouting racist abuse and spitting at the foreign children. White children living at the hostel were left in peace. In response Bexley council installed CCTV cameras and replaced the wall with railings so that the youths could no longer hurl bricks without being seen. "We've seen improvement here but the assaults, name calling, and abuse all continue outside," said Ms Taylor. One Romany family from Poland returned home after their daughters were attacked at Slade Green fair, while another Polish man was attacked with a bottle on his way to the shops. Neither incident was reported to the police. "What people misunderstand is that this centre is for all people, not just asylum seekers. Anyone who comes here is at rock bottom, black or white. Within the hostel their children play together with no problem," said Ms Taylor. "The other kids, 'the baseball hat brigade', are different. Their parents encourage them to racism. But the majority of people are decent, honest and not racist." Debbie Lee, Ms Taylor's neighbour, is typical of that majority. Her husband Dave, a lorry driver, has twice been attacked by asylum seekers trying to get into his vehicle on the continent, but she still feels asylum seekers deserve sympathy. "If they are genuine then fair enough. I don't agree with the bogus ones, but real ones deserve a chance. I told the BNP where to go when they knocked on my door. They are using asylum to bring up racism, and that is wrong." English nationalism has long been strong south of the Thames estuary, and the BNP's strength lies in harnessing lo cal disaffection to antipathy towards asylum seekers, who are no more than a convenient scapegoats in an area with profound problems. The North End result sent shock waves beyond Bexley. Most tellingly, it raised concerns within Conservative central office that immoderate language employed by the Tories on asylum might have been partly responsible for the improving fortunes of the BNP. The Tory candidate for London mayor, Steven Norris, went further. "It looks as if the BNP is on the up. I don't believe a politician in any party can afford to relax their guard. If you just appeal to your core vote, it can be very satisfying, but it is not going to win a general election," he said. Perhaps not, but in this deprived corner of the greater London hinterland, race in politics is a matter of degrees. No mainstream candidate can ignore it here and hope to win popular support. Tory election literature was in some respects indistinguishable from the that of the BNP. "For bogus asylum seekers ... Britain is the biggest soft touch in the world," it read. Nationalist The local Labour MP, Nigel Beard, is mindful that nationalist feelings run deep in Bexley. "I do have to take into account that this is an area with a long tradition of English patriotism. There is a deep feeling of identification with the country's tradition and history which is perfectly acceptable and valid," he said. "I walk into pubs and people shout, 'when are you going to do something for the English?' That is not racist, it is a feeling of being bypassed, left in the queue for services while others go to the front. The area is almost exclusively white working class. It is an understandable reaction." Drinking in the Cross Keys at nearby Erith, Del and Ken bear out Mr Beard's point. Ken says the town is "bursting with Bosnians", that they are "scumbags, no asset to anyone". He says the council saves all the money for the middle class wards, and dumps the asylum seekers on his doorstep. Del agrees, and says an anti-racism festival planned for September will cause trouble. "They spend money on all that, but not on me and my family." The BNP knocked on Ken and Del's doors, but neither of them could be bothered to vote. Apathy may yet halt the racists' progress.  North End ward byelection Labour: 772 (44.4%) BNP: 456 (26.2%) Conservative: 413 (23.8%) Lib Dem: 99 (5.7%) Turnout: 19.34%

webTitle: Are bookshops losing the plot - and discerning readers?

fields.headline: Are bookshops losing the plot - and discerning readers?
fields.standfirst: Bookshops are dumbing down, stocking fewer titles and losing their individuality says Christopher MacLehose, chairman of an independent publishers. Not at all says the managing director of Waterstone's, it's just a sign of moving with the times. Have your say here
fields.trailText: Dear Mr Kneale,
fields.body:
Dear Mr Kneale,

Last summer you took on the management of the finest chain of bookshops Britain has ever had. What Tim Waterstone created, beginning in 1982 with one shop in Old Brompton Road, London, has grown into a group of bookshops in Britain and Ireland, and made a massive contribution to the cultural life of the country.

Those bookshops attracted, trained and kept (and made happy, though by no means rich) a range of staff who matched a range of stock that had hitherto been available only in Blackwell's in Oxford, Heffers in Cambridge, Dillons, Gower Street, London and nowhere else. Those booksellers knew the books and knew their customers and were given the autonomy to make of their branches what local book-buyers wanted.

The Harvill Press is not the only independent publisher of literary works which owes its existence to the culture that Tim built. But no publisher in Britain - even if owned and sustained by Rupert Murdoch or by the German media giants Bertelsmann or Holtzbrinck (and between them, these three own most of British publishing) - can view with anything but anxiety the systematic deconstruction of that culture.

I am talking about a narrower range of titles in your shops, too few staff, piles of discounted bestsellers and front-of-shop and window displays dictated by head office. Heaven knows what Tim thinks of all this, but is this really what you have calculated that your customers wanted? If I have singled out Waterstone's it is because among all booksellers in Britain, Waterstone's was the crusader, the one who showed everybody else the way in selling serious books.

Yours sincerely, Christopher MacLehose Chairman, Harvill Press

Dear Mr MacLehose,

Our customers always have been and will remain the focus of everything we do. Our booksellers' expertise, passion for books and commitment to their local communities remains second to none. But you must acknowledge that the bookselling world has changed. There is more competition than ever before, and new sales channels such as the internet. What we're doing is using the knowledge of the booksellers in our branches, coupled with improved technology, to better inform our stock range and to reflect what our customers want. It's nonsense to say Waterstone's is intent on stocking a narrower range of books. We aren't.

We continue to champion the best new writing and, in your own words, serious books. But our booksellers also know that their customers want to be able to buy bestsellers too. Surely there's no conflict between being able to present the latest Thomas Harris alongside the Harvill-published Norwegian Wood by Murakami?

We believe that customers are capable of making their own decisions. What we do is offer recommendations from our range and value for money. What's wrong with that?

Yours sincerely, David Kneale Managing director Waterstone's

Dear Mr Kneale,

I don't find that the context in which books are published and sold has much changed. Yes, we have better bookshops and the number of people who have been encouraged to read good books has not diminished. On the contrary; the internet will only be a challenge to booksellers if service levels in shops fail to keep pace with the speed, courtesy and knowledge with which Amazon responds.

But I would like to take issue with you on customers being empowered to make their own buying decisions. Your bookshops are sent by head office impressive quantities of a limited number of titles and there is for your managers and buyers a tiny, almost risible budget left with which to use their expertise, passion and commitment: which essential properties are inevitably in decline.

The passion is still there, but staff levels have been reduced to the point at which booksellers have no time to do the vital job of communicating with customers and publishers' representatives, and no time to make bookshops regular haunts in which to meet authors and hear them read. It is sad that in one Waterstone's in Manchester there are - or were - more events in a month than all 33 shops in London can muster. Which is why Harvill books are being bought in ever greater numbers at independent shops such as John Sandoe's, Daunt Books and the Pan Bookshop.

It is the booksellers - not the market researchers - who are selling the books and who know what their customers want. Why not let them get on with it?

Yours sincerely, Christopher MacLehose.

Dear Mr MacLehose,

Are you saying that customers aren't capable of making their own decisions? They are and they do. And yes, we do want to see booksellers spend more time with customers. A key role for booksellers is to deliver excellent customer service by offering them help, recommendations and advice.

Our booksellers buy books for their own shops. Our managers manage their own budgets. Readers of your letter might assume otherwise. In fact, fewer than five per cent of titles stocked in our branches are centrally chosen. You are right in that many of these are bestsellers. They are bound to be. As for the remainder of those nationally promoted titles, they include new writing, such as the recent award-winners from our Originals campaign.

With best wishes, David Kneale.

Dear Mr Kneale,

We are not going to disagree that good bookshops are crucial to the cultural life of this, or any, country, and that the best bookshops have traditionally been (and still are, more or less) autonomously managed. Let's spend no more of our exchange on the wisdom of imposing (that is, selling to publishers) nationally standardised window displays, or on a central body deciding what is going to be a bestseller.

Independent bookshops and individual booksellers in the chains have in the past, to their delight and credit, created bestsellers and made authors - for example, William Maxwell - widely read. It is less satisfying or businesslike only to promote books that have become bestsellers, and plain dotty not to give a bookseller enough money to go on buying books that he or she knows can be sold, just to satisfy a centrally-devised budget process.

Readers of the financial pages don't need reminding that there is a question mark over the viability of centrally-managed book chains. Readers of, and browsers among, good books would welcome a choice of bookshops: places where experienced, well-paid staff are proud to work; where authors will gladly read, sign books, meet their readers; bookshops that are specialised, open late, recognise their responsibility to the communities they work in; vital places in every sense.

Their responsibility will be yet more onerous in a time when literary editors are not doing the work for them. That, in short, would be my plot and I am dismayed to think that many of what were the best bookshops have lost it.

Yours sincerely, Christopher MacLehose

Dear Mr MacLehose,

I am confident that, collectively and individually, booksellers will continue to support bestsellers and champion new writing; I see no conflict in doing both these things. What is more, we believe that bestsellers - such as William Maxwell - are created through a partnership between authors, publishers, booksellers and, most importantly, our customers.

Waterstone's has always promoted titles nationally. Some people may well regret the move towards more businesslike central promotions but it is a fact that these are helping to sell both new and established authors to a wider public than ever before.

We are committed to ensuring that bookshops remain at the heart of communities through the UK and Ireland. We have a passion for books. And we want to share that passion for readers; that, put simply, is our plot.

Yours sincerely, David Kneale

Harvill Press

fields.headline: Rhyme and reason
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I have just found a sheaf of poems hidden inside the panel surrounding the washbasin. They are in Glenn's handwriting. Why he feels the need to hide the evidence of a fine sensibility is a mystery to me
fields.body:
Wednesday, July 5, Arthur Askey Walk

My father originally went into hospital with fractures of the leg and various other injuries, caused when he fell off a ladder while constructing a Japanese-style pagoda for his new wife, Tania, who is obsessed with all things Oriental.

He's been in hospital for months, suffering from a hospital-borne infection, and is now completely institutionalised. When he hears the food trolley arrive at the end of the ward at 7am, 12 noon and 5pm, his mouth fills with saliva. He claims to be happy there, says he has no worries: other people pay the bills, walk the dangerous streets, get immobilised in traffic jams, and do the Sainsbury's run.

Sharon Bott, the mother of my son, Glenn, works as a cleaner at the hospital. She says that, as part of an infection-control programme, her mop was taken away for laboratory tests. She said that when the mop was returned to her, "It looked as if it had been through the mill."

Thursday, July 6

I have just found a sheaf of poems hidden inside the panel surrounding the washbasin. They are in Glenn's handwriting. Why he feels the need to hide the evidence of a fine sensibility is a mystery to me. This house is devoted to the creative spirit. William, for instance, has a passion for making miniature gardens in old shoe-boxes. Perhaps he will grow up to be a landscape gardener like Capability Brown or Charlie Dimmock.

My favourite poem is entitled Why?

Why?
Why, oh why do nice things die?
A leaf, a flower, a humble fly?

I will have to correct Glenn on an inaccuracy in this poem. Flies are not nice. They have vile personal habits. My second-favourite poem is called Patsy:

Patsy
I love the way your mouth goes up
When you drink from out a cup.
That Liam was no good for you
Come to me, I will be true.
I cannot give you mega-wealth
But I am young, I have my health.
Flee from London, leave your cage
But know one thing, I'm under-age
I can't have sexual intercourse,
I'm chaste like that Inspector Morse.

When Glenn came home from school, I tackled him about the poem. He hung his head and blushed scarlet. "Don't tell no one, Dad," he said.

Saturday July 8

My mother has called a family conference. I am the subject. My father was on the end of his hospital telephone. Others present were: Ivan Braithwaite, Tania, Mrs Wormington, and my auntie Susan, a prison warder. They are concerned that I am wasting my life. I pointed out that I am a full-time carer of two boys and a 90-year-old woman. My mother said, "What was the point of reading all those books if all you're going to do with that knowledge is to wash and iron and cook. You might as well have been born a woman."

Auntie Susan stubbed out her cigar and raked her fingers through her number two before saying, "Adrian, I could get you a job in the prison library."

To shut them all up, I promised to think about it but the thought of being in contact with even literate prisoners fills me with horror. Tania said that, in her opinion, I had an unhealthy fixation with old people. "Why can't you be content to do voluntary work in a retirement home? Why do you feel the need to have one living with you in your home?" I was unable to give her an answer. When they had gone, Mrs Wormington asked, "Who was that stuck-up bitch in the kimono?"

Monday, July 10

Next week, I go to Wind-on-the-Wolds prison to be shown around the library. There is a part-time job available, worse luck!

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText:
Slash and burn may have improved this lush tanglewood
Hear audio clips
fields.body:
Emotionally Weird
Kate Atkinson
(HarperCollins, £8.99, 180mn)
Hear an extract

Severe slash and burn has arguably improved 450 pages of lush tanglewood. Two threads survive: Effie's essay-crisis week at Dundee university during the 1970s, and Nora's tauter revelations that she tried to kill Effie's mum. Alpha-plus comic observation of Effie's classmates' hopeless struggles with life and lit crit propped up by Nora's bleaker tale. Frances Tomelty's wonderful reading keeps this jalopy going when the road peters out.

webTitle: Sinister shadow over an average town

fields.headline: Sinister shadow over an average town
fields.standfirst: Swindon's prosperity proves a lure to the heroin trade
fields.trailText: Swindon's prosperity proves a lure to the heroin trade
fields.body:
A girl who looks no older than 15 stands on a street corner waiting for her next client. She is dressed in tight jeans and a skimpy top and wears heavy eyeliner and bright lipstick. No doubt, her pimp lurks nearby, ready to take the money she earns and in exchange to supply her with the drugs she craves.

Not an uncommon sight in deprived inner cities across Britain. But this is no notorious red light district in London, Birmingham or Glasgow. The girl is working the streets of Swindon, one of Britain's most prosperous towns and a firm favourite with market researchers because it is perceived as home to a well-to-do Mr and Mrs Average, a place which reflects changing trends and attitudes.

Beneath the Wiltshire town's comfortable exterior lies a serious and growing social problem. New figures reveal that the number of hard drug users in Swindon is on the increase.

The price of heroin, in particular, has dropped sharply because so many dealers have descended on the town, realising it has a population with money to spend. And the sidelines which dealers inevitably have - such as drawing vulnerable teenagers into prostitution - are inevitably on the increase.

It is because Swindon is perceived as an accurate gauge of prosperous Britain that the drugs problem there is so relevant. The trade in hard drugs and the associated social issues are no longer only an inner city problem but one which is facing communities across the country. One drugs worker said: "Swindon is seen as a microcosm of the country, so if it is happening here, it is happening everywhere."

Disturbing trend

The annual report of the Druglink, a Swindon charity which is often the first port of call for drug abusers, makes disturbing reading. It dealt with 2,500 "clients" last year, an increase of 600, or 30%, over the previous 12 months.

Heroin was easily the most common drug new clients were taking, followed by amphetamines and then cannabis. The majority of younger users, Druglink found, were injecting rather than smoking heroin. And, perhaps most tellingly, of these new clients only one in five were homeless or lived in "insecure" accommodation. Most were from relatively secure homes. Michael Robinson, team leader of the community and drug and alcohol services in Swindon, has had experience of working with addicts in some of Britain's most challenging areas, including King's Cross and Brixton in London. On his arrival in Swindon a year ago, he discovered a contrasting, but no less worrying, picture.

"Swindon has very different drug problems," he said. "There is nearly full employment and there are a lot of new housing estates. Many people we deal with here have jobs, homes and families. They may be working in factories or in the car industry. They have quite a lot of money and find that heroin is cheap and available - it is something to do."

Over the past 10 years, business has boomed in Swindon. Blue chip firms flocked to the town, taking advantage of its transport links and forward-thinking local authority. Smart new estates continue to spring up, to house a growing and affluent populace, while the vibrant town centre bustles with shoppers with money to spend. Innovations such as eye recognition cash machines have been tested in the town because it is seen as so typical - albeit that some residents complain at being labelled average. Dave, 20, is one such. He works in a local car factory and lives with his girlfriend on one of the new estates in the west of the town.

He said: "I didn't really come across heroin when I was at school though there were other drugs we dabbled in - cannabis mainly, and ecstasy.

"It was after I had left and started work that myself and a group of friends began experimenting with it. I only smoked it, but some of the others began injecting. We would get it from a man in a pub. Everybody knew where to go.

The pimp would then, perhaps, say he owed money for the drugs he had supplied to her and coerce her into sleeping with someone to repay the supposed debt.

Ms Armstrong said: "By that stage she is isolated from her family and friends and dependent on drugs. If the girl tried to break away from the pimp, he threatened to tell her family what she had become involved in."

There are few places in Swindon for young women - and others drawn into the world of drugs - to meet to receive support and help. One organisation at the sharp end is the Stepping Forward project, run with the help of national lottery funds from St John's church hall in Park North in the east of the town.

Caroline Kelly, a specialist outreach worker at the project, began working as a volunteer with young drug users after discovering that her son was taking heroin. She was amazed to find that users had to wait months for treatment - last year some drug users in Swindon who had asked for help were waiting several months to be assessed for counselling and treatment - and then had nowhere to meet as they tried to piece their lives back together.

Stepping Forward officially opened at the start of this year and it now caters for 60 youngsters aged 14 to 25 every week. They can spend their time playing pool or table tennis and they have access to computers. Those who need it can receive tutoring in reading and writing and other skills from visiting teachers. The project is visited by youngsters from all sorts of backgrounds and with different problems. Some are from prosperous, stable families, while others, inevitably, have had more troubled upbringings and are hampered by lack of qualifications and life skills. Even in prosperous Swindon, some fall through the net.

Peter, 24, for instance, describes how he has taken heroin and crack cocaine since the age of 15. Then, there were only one or two dealers on the streets. Now, he says, there are so many that they are fighting over their patches. They carry knives, and, he says, will soon be carrying guns.

Peter, who is now on the heroin substitute methadone, says he had no idea what he was becoming involved in when he first took heroin. "I used to smoke blow [cannabis] with a group of friends and then one day someone said, 'Try this brown stuff'. I thought it was another type of cannabis. When I realised that it was smack, it was too late - I was hooked."

Since then he has been in and out of prison but is now determined to kick the drug habit. He shows how the needle tracks in his arms have healed.

At Stepping Forward he is trying his hand at being a DJ on the centre's turn tables, which boom out dance music at deafening levels. The music and the optimism of the centre's visitors and inspirational staff make Stepping Out a welcoming place for the outsider.

But the atmosphere changes subtly when a couple of teenage girls walk into the centre. Keeping their eyes to the ground, they speak quietly to a volunteer, then join friends tapping away at a computer. Tidy and fresh-faced, they look as if they should be worrying about homework or giggling with schoolmates about boyfriends. In fact, they are prostitutes. If market researchers are correct to tap into Swindon as an indicator of trends across the country, then its drugs problem is probably hitting, or is about to hit, other towns nationwide.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Museum of Doubt by James Meek

fields.headline: Surreality check
fields.standfirst:
Justine Jordan on James Meek's strange collection of stories, The Museum of Doubt
Read an extract
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan on James Meek's strange collection of stories, The Museum of Doubt
fields.body:
The Museum of Doubt
James Meek
Rebel Inc, £10, 294pp
Buy it at BOL

"I want to give you a demon. I want to give you a demonstration of something unlike anything you've ever seen before," begins the title story of James Meek's new collection, which ricochets between the supernatural and the suburban throughout. Jack, the devil-cum-door to door salesman making this irresistible proposition, is hawking capital-L Life, our everyday orgy of overconsumption; he comes up against Adela, who has stripped her life of objects and whose empty house is a "museum of doubt".

This sounds an easy opposition of empty clutter versus zen asceticism, but Meek makes it into much more; like the other pieces in this dense, puzzling book, it becomes an open-ended parable of need, possession and desire. His lost, regretful characters are searching for the essence of things; names slide away from them, the past is unreliable, the present tangential.

He shows an impressive range of ideas and moods, from the tender, perplexed tale of Adam, who imagines in the impenetrable babble of his wife, the last speaker of Mercian, discussion of "the limits of time... the very colours... the very love there was", to the fabulist story of a lawyer who is drafted by deities to fight a civil action on behalf of the dead for "involuntary separation from life".

It's a classical fable, this well-worn journey through the underworld, but the gods have modernised and morphed into committees: Nato, the god of war, Imf, the god of money, Wto, the god of trade. In the baroque "The Queen of Ukraine", politics is conjured as sex and dream, while in the tense, realistic "Bonny Boat Speed", a race for the last ferry is heightened by a series of urban myths and apocrypha.

The writing fizzes throughout, and Meek excels at absurdist, bravura turns: the 1979 general election as horse-race commentary ("the vets now moving swiftly over to David Steel, I'm afraid he'll have to be shot") and an all too convincing sidesweep at moustaches, explained as "a pubic substitute in a socially acceptable place" for those men who'd rather have their hands down their trousers: "Stalin - moustache. Hitler - moustache. Saddam Hussein - moustache. It's so fucking obvious."

Interleaved in this dazzling array is the episodic progress of Gordon, whining pensioner, sex tourist and bungalow bigot. The embodiment of the nastiest needs and terrors of the subconscious, he is "a burglar who'd broken into his own mind and found it was a terrible fearful place but that he couldn't get out or do anything about it". His wife keeps turning into the best friend he drove to suicide, so that she has to demonstrate her sex by baring a breast over breakfast. His only emotion towards his son is furious resentment at his possession of one of the young girls he longs to "press his erect fear inside": "Was there not a law, if your own son had a woman in his legal father's house and his legal father lawfully wanted to take her upstairs."

There is a faint, unnecessary sneer to Meek's detailing of suburban hell, the "separate puce leather suite items" and "gold velvet-effect curtains", the weak-joke rants about foreigners (if people want to be refugees, they should do it in their own countries). But as what begins as uncomfortable comedy with desperate gropes over the dinner table escalates, tale by tale, into disassociated mayhem, Gordon's psychic journey to hell through Scottish garden centres and Bangkok red-light joints becomes powerfully unsettling. This is truly experimental writing: careless of taboo, teeming with ideas, elusive yet utterly controlled.

fields.headline: The almost-perfect England one-day team
fields.trailText: The Wisden Column: Punter's Point by Nick Ryder
fields.body:
Can anyone else remember the late 80s and early 90s when England were one of the best one-day sides in world cricket, despite the inadequacies of the Test side? We reached the World Cup final in 1987 and 1992 and would regularly beat the likes of West Indies and Australia in the Texaco Trophy before getting slaughtered in the Tests.

Back then we almost took our one-day success for granted, but now we are arguably even worse in the limited-overs format of the game than we are over five days. This is frustrating, particularly as we have the players to achieve success, at least on seaming wickets. There are plenty of excuses, but our continuing and baffling inability to select anything resembling our best side is driving me to breaking point.

During the World Cup last year we consistently picked a side with five batsmen, four bowlers and two "allrounders". The idea of this was to create depth in the batting down to No. 7 and to give the captain the option of six bowlers. In practice it gives you a tail that starts at No. 6 and two bowlers that concede about seven an over. Despite the clear evidence that we do not have the players to pursue this tactic, the selectors persisted to pick these allrounders throughout the winter.

The selectors also find it hard to grasp the fact that we patently do not have a spinner capable of succeeding in one-day cricket. Robert Croft had an initial honeymoon period as England's main spinner, but since '98 he has been carved around almost every time he has bowled. Ashley Giles is probably our best one-day spinner, but has yet to convince that he can bowl as tightly against world-class batsmen as proven seamers like Alan Mullally or Mark Ealham are able to do. As the next World Cup is in South Africa, where the wickets suit seam bowling, why do we need a spinner at all when the evidence suggests an all-seam attack would be more effective?

We must surely play a team of specialists, with six batsmen and five seamers, rather than picking bits-and-pieces players like Adam Hollioake and Craig White who are simply inadequate with both bat and ball. Ealham has proved to be effective as a stock bowler, and can at least contribute from No.7 (he averages about 18).

In order to play a team with six batsmen and five bowlers we must pick a wicketkeeper/batsman and, despite his age, Stewart is the only one we've got (resting him at the end of a gruelling winter tour would have been a good idea; dropping him was idiotic). He'll be 40 by the next World Cup, and we must pray he can continue until then.

We must then decide who has done enough over the last 12 months to justify automatic selection. In the batting, probably Graeme Hick, Nick Knight and Nasser Hussain; of the bowlers, Darren Gough, Mullally and Andy Caddick have been consistent.

So far, that's eight players who should be automatic selections.

Although Graham Thorpe has been lacking form, passion and urgency of late, we can't afford not to select a player with his international record. Marcus Trescothick has been the most impressive one-day batsman in county cricket this year and has earned an opportunity. Finally Dominic Cork, who surely must be retained from the Test side after single-handedly defeating the West Indies, is at his best a proven high-class seamer who can score important runs.

Of the five bowlers - Gough, Caddick, Mullally, Ealham and Cork - it is hard to imagine any of them getting smashed around. Indeed, the bowling has been our main (or only) strength over the last couple of years. The main weakness is the batting, particularly the middle/lower-middle order. With Stewart, Knight and Trescothick you have three natural openers who all have attacking games. You can then delay Hussain, Hick and Thorpe until Nos 4,5 and 6 to keep the momentum of the innings going. These three are also the best players of spin in the side and should reduce the extent of England's problem playing slow bowlers.

If you compare my team with the current side, it is hard to believe that they wouldn't be far more effective in both departments, although we may have to accept we are behind other countries in terms of fielding. It is not a side picked around an idealistic vision of the perfect one-day team, but a selection that acknowledges the weaknesses of our players in certain areas and attempts to counter that with genuine ability by selecting the 11 best players.

But then I am only a supporter, so what do I know?

Nick Ryder's England one-day XI

Stewart (wk)
Knight
Trescothick
Hussain (c)
Hick
Thorpe
Ealham
Cork
Caddick
Gough
Mullally

Nick Ryder, 22, is an IT network administrator from Chingford

fields.headline: Langshott Manor Country House, Surrey
fields.trailText: The rooms have space to swing one's heraldic lion cub, with plush chairs, leaded windows, a big TV and a good minibar.
fields.body:
Address: Langshott, Surrey RH6 9LN
Tel: 01293 786680

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: www.qxl.co.uk
fields.trailText: www.qxl.co.uk
fields.body:
QXL or Quicksell? What does it stand for? Good question. It used to be pronounced Quicksell, but the public didn't catch on. So you can call it Queue Ex Ell.

Why are you blinking? I've been assailed by a sinus-inducing field of orange. "HOT! HOT! HOT!" shouts the headline. "MOSCOW: 2 nights - The Spy Game - Mastertour - Heathrow - 22 September - £141."

What does it all mean? QXL would like you to bid more than £141 for an autumn package trip to Moscow. This is an auction site for holidays and flights. The reserve price is reasonably low, but anyone can outbid you - if they do, QXL can send you an SMS message on your mobile to let you know - but if they don't, you may have a bargain. Before bidding, you have to entrust QXL with your credit card number and become a member.

Any notable bargains? Disappointingly few, but there are hundreds of deals on offer. And you may spot something that has gone unnoticed by everyone else, particularly since many offers attract no bids at all.

Will I get carried away? That depends on how susceptible you are. QXL relies on creating a sense of urgency among users. Once a bid is made, a legally-binding agreement is formed, so you can't change your mind.

Oddity of the week

Fielding's DangerFinder

Dominated by a cackling skull, DangerFinder warns you of the dangers lying in wait for travellers to Peru, Uganda, Algeria and similarly troubled locations. It's all rather perverse and about as sincere as the skeleton's warnings at the entrance to a ghost train, but as a corrective to the rose-tinted delusions of the tourist industry, it deserves a look.

fields.headline: Cotto, London
fields.standfirst: Cotto is easily good enough to withstand the competition, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: Cotto is easily good enough to withstand the competition, says Matthew Fort.
fields.body:
What is it about Blythe Road that is so attractive to restaurateurs of every hue? I know that this may cause offence, but I wouldn't call Blythe Road romantic, dramatic or beautiful, or anything other than really ordinary. Tucked away in the backwoods of Hammersmith, it wiggles and it waggles all the way from Shepherd's Bush Road to just behind Olympia, where it peters out in a baffling sequence of twists and turns.

Yet every few metres along its length are notable places of refreshment - Popeseye for the unreconstructed steak-and-claret lover, Wilson's for new-wave Scottish, Chez Marcelle for Lebanese delights, and now Cotto for... for what, exactly? Well, for a damned good version of that much-abused style, concept, precept, metaphor, approach, movement, call it what you will: modern British cooking. In effect, modern British is no more than old British with a bit of a contemporary spin in terms of presentation, and ingredients such as wild mushrooms from Africa, artichokes from Brittany, risottos from Italy, truffles from... come to think of it, where do truffles come from in mid-summer?

These, and various other ingredients, run freely through the menu of James Kirby, chef/prop of Cotto. Cotto has been open only a couple of months. It's a very bright place, on a corner, and there's lots of glass about, so that the light gets in from two sides. And then it's quite white and clean and modern-looking, though not in any way clinical or chilly. In fact, it seems rather the reverse: cheerful and open.

The name of the place might lead one to expect that everything will be treated in a very Italian fashion - "cotto" being the Italian for "cooked" - which would have been typically modern British. But what with the pavés and pot roasts, the poaching and confiting, I'd say that Kirby's primary technical influences are French, while the broad-based construction of the dishes is British.

In the end, however, satisfaction comes not from labels, conceits, concepts, precepts, metaphors approaches and movements, but from what the assembly tastes like, and here Kirby scores heavily. To be truthful, he scored a little too heavily with the salt in Iphigenia's wild mushrooms and broad beans with Parma ham, or so she said. The ham would have been salty enough on its own, but someone in the kitchen had added a considerable dash to the mushrooms, too, thus spoiling what would have been, in Iphi's view, an absolutely A-1 dish, rich, earthy and full of floppy textures.

I had no criticisms of the pavé of lamb sweetbreads with asparagus and artichoke that graced my plate. It was an elegant construction, the flavours delicate but distinct, the density firm but not compacted. It showed a classical training in the attention to detail and in the very precise standard of the cooking.

This was even more in evidence with the pan-fried brill with crushed potatoes, peas and meat juices. The slab of brill must have come off a truly massive fish, and it had been fried to the exact point where the individual strata of flesh slide from each other with the slightest resistance. Ooooh, very nice. Using meat stock to beef up the flavour quotient of fish dishes is a French idea, and one that works brilliantly when used with intelligence and discretion, as it was here. The juices, I would guess, were possibly veal, probably chicken. The potato anchored the dish in stern reality, and the very good sweet peas added a touch of seasonal fantasy.

Iphigenia took a very long call on her mobile halfway through her steady consumption of poached loin of new-season's lamb with ceps and roast shallots, so in revenge I helped myself to about half her dish while she wandered up and down the street outside in search of a clearer signal. Again, classic techniques had been applied with perceptive intelligence to bring out the specific qualities of the ingredients. The lamb was impeccably elegant, tender and tasty, the ceps and shallots hitting sweeter, more primitive notes. It was a big dish in terms of thought and flavour.

My companion rather faded at the thought of pudding, but there was no stopping me from strawberry shortbread with fromage-frais ice cream and basil. I'm not sure what the basil was doing, but the rest promised seasonal delights and delivered them with something to spare.

The bill was for the food was a pretty standard £43.75, which, for cooking that is really pretty serious, seems pretty fair as well. We also drank well (but not too deeply) of something of which I have lost the details (and memory).

It obviously hasn't taken the locals that long to decide that Cotto is a good thing. The place was hugger-mugger on the warm weekday evening that Iphigenia and I settled down at table 12, while all around us a lot of white wine went the way of all white wine, along with vibrant conversation and the like. I would say the locals were quite right.

fields.headline: Three wonderful chicken recipes
fields.standfirst: Chicken stock, coronation chicken and southern-fried chicken: Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.trailText: Chicken stock, coronation chicken and southern-fried chicken: Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.body:
All recipes serve six.

Chicken stock

The soul of so much cooking and, in the great scheme of things, remarkably swift to prepare.

1 top-quality chicken

2 onions

2 carrots

2 leeks

3 sticks celery

2 bayleaves

12 peppercorns

1 sprig thyme

1 clove

Truss the chicken, then place in a roomy pot. Peel the onions and cut into four pieces. Scrape the carrots, rinse the leeks and wash the celery, and add these to the pot whole or broken in two. Drop in the herbs and spices, put the pot on the stove and fill to just below the brim with cold water. Over a medium flame, heat until the surface of the liquid is broken by the occasional bubble, then bring down to the quietest simmer and skim off any foamy matter that floats to the top. Leave undisturbed for an hour, excepting the odd glance to ensure that the surface is broken only by the gentlest movement.

After an hour, skim again, turn off the heat, and set aside. When the meat is cool enough to handle, remove the bird from the stock and cover with a damp cloth. Pour the stock through a fine sieve, after which it will sit happily in the fridge for a couple of days.

Coronation chicken

A once and future classic that has graced many a fine do, although none of them to compare with the event for which it was created: the coronation of HM.

1 large top-quality chicken

1 tbsp oil

1 small onion

1 dssp curry powder

1 heaped tsp tomato purée

100ml red wine

75ml cold water

1 bayleaf

Salt

Sugar

A fully-charged pepper mill

lemon

18 dried apricots

450ml home-made mayonnaise (or from a jar, if you really have to)

4 tbsp double cream

Cook the chicken as in the recipe for making chicken stock. Leave the bird to cool in the stock once done. Put the apricots into a small pan, cover them with water, leave to soak for half-an-hour then set the pan on a high heat, bring to the boil and simmer until all the liquid has evaporated. Liquidise the apricots.

Peel and finely chop the onion, and fry gently in the oil until soft. Add the curry powder and fry gently for a few minutes more, then add the tomato purée and fry for another minute or two. Pour in the water and wine, then drop in the bayleaf, bring the pan to a simmer and season with salt, a little sugar and some pepper. Squeeze the juice from the lemon half, and add this to the pot, too. Simmer for another 10 minutes, then strain the sauce through a fine sieve and leave to cool. Whip the double cream until it is just thickened, then fold it into the mayonnaise, along with the apricot purée.

Strip the skin from the cooked chicken, and remove all the flesh from the bone, taking care to leave all the fiddly little bones and gristle behind (on no account forget the oysters under the wings, or any of the other choice morsels that sit close to the bone). Cut the meat into largish pieces, and mix with the sauce. Originally, this was served with a rice salad, but I prefer a salad of green beans, toasted almonds and a few green leaves.

Southern-fried chicken

The best recipe I know for a dish that is just memorably munchable.

For the marinade

8 cloves garlic

200ml milk

tsp salt

tsp freshly-ground black pepper

- tsp cayenne (the amount depends on your heat threshold)

1 tsp sweet pimenton (or paprika)

2 chickens, or 9 legs, or 18 thighs (the thighs are the best)

For the coating

200g plain flour

2 tsp salt

2 tsp freshly-ground black pepper

2 tsp cayenne

Peanut oil (or vegetable oil)

Prepare the marinade: crush the garlic, and mix it with the milk, salt and peppers. Cut the chickens (if using whole ones) into eight pieces each - remember that meat always tastes and cooks best when left on the bone. Coat the chicken in the marinade and leave to sit, covered, in the fridge overnight.

Lay the chicken on a rack to drain for 15 minutes or so. Mix the flour with the salt and spices, and cover the bottom of a tray with it. Coat the chicken with the flour, shake off any excess, then toss in the flour again, to ensure that it is well-coated. Place again on a rack and leave in a cool spot for an hour or so - they will become messy to handle, but it's worth it.

Deep-frying is the obvious option here (just follow the manufacturer's instructions), or fry gently in a heavy-bottomed frying pan and finish off in the oven once the pieces have turned golden brown and are well crusted. Cook until the juices run clear, but be careful not to over-cook them (15-20 minutes' gentle frying is adequate for a chicken thigh). Serve with chips, a mayonnaise made spiky with lemon juice and some crisp lettuce

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.

webTitle: Where to source the perfect chicken

fields.headline: Where to source the perfect chicken
fields.standfirst: Forget Chicken Run: if you're after real star quality in your chooks, you just have to go organic, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: Forget Chicken Run: if you're after real star quality in your chooks, you just have to go organic, says Matthew Fort
fields.body:
There is a discreet reek of money and horse manure about the lanes into Lambourne. This is racing country. Stables, rides, thoroughbreds are all tucked away among the rolling acres of the Berkshire Downs. And chickens - chickens, cattle and sheep, to be exact, all as organic as can be, scratching, munching and meandering over Sheepdrove Organic Farm (01488 71659). Sheepdrove is the creation of erstwhile publishers Peter and Juliet Kindersley and their team, headed by Charles Maclean. Sheepdrove wasn't organic when they took it over; it has taken five years of hard work, setting about crop rotation to fix the nitrogen, dealing with blackweed and other botanical pests, and bringing the land into a natural state of health.

And healthy it looks: rich, glossy, not manicured, but well cared for, well used. The secret, it seems, is to keep animals and crops on the move: monoculture doesn't suit the land in the long term. So here, for the time being, are the chickens, all 6,000 of them; 1,000 per state-of-the- free-range-poultry-art mobile barn, a crowd of white-feather-dusters fossicking around in the grass surrounding their homes. These are Rosscobs, says Maclean, who wears the kind of moustache you last saw in that Kevin Costner film about Wyatt Earp. Rosscobs, he says, are the racehorses of the poultry world, bred to put on weight rapidly and for flavour.

The only trouble with them, however, is that they are nervy creatures, given to dying in numbers that can affect the farm's profitability. And, yes, Sheepdrove has to make money. There's no point in having a farm that is not run as a commercial enterprise; organic farming isn't just for posing. And he rattles off a battery of statistics, the general drift of which is to show that, while the yields and densities of crops and animals may be marginally lower and the pay-bill rather higher, the fact that he doesn't have to nuke the 1,850 acres, 130 suckler cows, 1,400 sheep and 6,000 chickens with a battery of chemicals means that he can achieve the same level of profitability as a conventional farm.

But having chickens die on him doesn't help, so he's changing to Shavers. By the time they have been nurtured the organic way, he says, there won't be a discernible difference in quality, and he won't have so many unwanted carcasses on his hands. They don't deal in eggs at Sheepdrove, so they buy in day-old chicks, at which stage they are not organic - there isn't yet the supply of organic chicks available in this country - but, with the Soil Association's blessing, they will become organic by the time they leave the farm, plucked, trussed and packed.

And here they are, 1,000 little fluffy balls hurtling around their nice warm, glassed-in room, just a few days old, just starting out on their 12 weeks of life - which, in case you're feeling sorry for them, is more than twice the life-expectancy of a broiler, whose span is a mere 35 days, and those spent in the most hideous of conditions. This lot are coddled. No debeaking here, or routine dosing with antibiotics. Organic feed, too.

In a few days, these little chaps will be moved on to a less warm room, to make way, after the room has been cleaned and left for a week to reduce any risk of disease, for the next 1,000 lunches. Then, over 21 days or so, the warmth is reduced to acclimatise them to the temperatures outside. They're funny things, hens, you see - they like being outside. In fact, the colder it is, the better they like it. Give them a warm summer's day, and they lie around in the shade. Give them a good fall of snow, and they dash outside like small children.

They are fairly carefully guarded against foxes by electric fences, but Maclean puts his faith more in what he calls the dominant-vixen system. Briefly, it goes like this. You let a vixen settle on your land. If she's happy, she'll keep her mate in order and scare off other foxes. All you have to do is bung her a few dead chickens every so often, so that she knows how well off she is. Not so long ago, Maclean was shooting half-a-dozen foxes a season - well, you would, if they kept going through your poultry shed like the plague. Now, he doesn't shoot any. That's called being in balance with nature.

So, the chickens will enjoy these carefree conditions for around 81 days, until they weigh in at around 1.8-2.5kg, and then, at night, when they are all warm and sleepy, they are rounded up, popped into individual boxes to minimise stress and injury, kept in the dark for the same reason and, before they know what's happening to them, dispatched, bled, plucked and eviscerated in an ultra-modern unit and then hung up to get a bit of flavour into them.

Actually, most of them aren't hung. Supermarkets aren't really in favour of too much flavour. More to the point, they think we aren't. But we should be. What is the point of a chicken, particularly an organic one, that doesn't taste of anything?

So, here I have one in front of me, a fine fellow of 2kg or more. The breast is a bit longer than what you usually see in the chiller cabinet, and less, well, bust-like. The legs are longer, too, with the well-muscled look of the outdoor athlete. And, oddly, it's bright yellow. Not corn-fed, or anything like that, says Maclean. It's the clover. That's what turns them that colour. All natural, you see. Just like the flavour.

Other notable suppliers

Pipers Farms 01392 881380;

The Farmyard Chicken Company 0870 9002900 for a Marchents catalogue;

Northfield Farm 01664 474271;

Mortons 01692 538227.

So here, for the time being, are the chickens, all 6,000 of them; 1,000 per state-of-the- free-range-poultry-art mobile barn, a crowd of white-feather-dusters fossicking around in the grass surrounding their homes. These are Rosscobs, says Maclean, who wears the kind of moustache you last saw in that Kevin Costner film about Wyatt Earp. Rosscobs, he says, are the racehorses of the poultry world, bred to put on weight rapidly and for flavour. The only trouble with them, however, is that they are nervy creatures, given to dying in numbers that can affect the farm's profitability. And, yes, Sheepdrove has to make money. There's no point in having a farm that is not run as a commercial enterprise; organic farming isn't just for posing. And he rattles off a battery of statistics, the general drift of which is to show that, while the yields and densities of crops and animals may be marginally lower and the pay-bill rather higher, the fact that he doesn't have to nuke the 1,850 acres, 130 suckler cows, 1,400 sheep and 6,000 chickens with a battery of chemicals means that he can achieve the same level of profitability as a conventional farm. But having chickens die on him doesn't help, so he's changing to Shavers. By the time they have been nurtured the organic way, he says, there won't be a discernible difference in quality, and he won't have so many unwanted carcasses on his hands. They don't deal in eggs at Sheepdrove, so they buy in day-old chicks, at which stage they are not organic - there isn't yet the supply of organic chicks available in this country - but, with the Soil Association's blessing, they will become organic by the time they leave the farm, plucked, trussed and packed. And here they are, 1,000 little fluffy balls hurtling around their nice warm, glassed-in room, just a few days old, just starting out on their 12 weeks of life - which, in case you're feeling sorry for them, is more than twice the life-expectancy of a broiler, whose span is a mere 35 days, and those spent in the most hideous of conditions. This lot are coddled. No debeaking here, or routine dosing with antibiotics. Organic feed, too. In a few days, these little chaps will be moved on to a less warm room, to make way, after the room has been cleaned and left for a week to reduce any risk of disease, for the next 1,000 lunches. Then, over 21 days or so, the warmth is reduced to acclimatise them to the temperatures outside. They're funny things, hens, you see - they like being outside. In fact, the colder it is, the better they like it. Give them a warm summer's day, and they lie around in the shade. Give them a good fall of snow, and they dash outside like small children. They are fairly carefully guarded against foxes by electric fences, but Maclean puts his faith more in what he calls the dominant-vixen system. Briefly, it goes like this. You let a vixen settle on your land. If she's happy, she'll keep her mate in order and scare off other foxes. All you have to do is bung her a few dead chickens every so often, so that she knows how well off she is. Not so long ago, Maclean was shooting half-a-dozen foxes a season - well, you would, if they kept going through your poultry shed like the plague. Now, he doesn't shoot any. That's called being in balance with nature. So, the chickens will enjoy these carefree conditions for around 81 days, until they weigh in at around 1.8-2.5kg, and then, at night, when they are all warm and sleepy, they are rounded up, popped into individual boxes to minimise stress and injury, kept in the dark for the same reason and, before they know what's happening to them, dispatched, bled, plucked and eviscerated in an ultra-modern unit and then hung up to get a bit of flavour into them. Actually, most of them aren't hung. Supermarkets aren't really in favour of too much flavour. More to the point, they think we aren't. But we should be. What is the point of a chicken, particularly an organic one, that doesn't taste of anything? So, here I have one in front of me, a fine fellow of 2kg or more. The breast is a bit longer than what you usually see in the chiller cabinet, and less, well, bust-like. The legs are longer, too, with the well-muscled look of the outdoor athlete. And, oddly, it's bright yellow. Not corn-fed, or anything like that, says Maclean. It's the clover. That's what turns them that colour. All natural, you see. Just like the flavour. fields.headline: Divine inspiration
fields.standfirst: Christopher Lloyd's annual visit to Scotland has once again furnished an old hand with new ideas
fields.trailText: Christopher Lloyd's annual visit to Scotland has once again furnished an old hand with new ideas.
fields.body:
If you don't make a point of visiting other people's gardens to pick up ideas, you become stale. This is one of the pleasures I get from visiting Scotland, quite apart from seeing old friends and making new ones.

I have, in the past, stated that Iris reticulata is not a good species for growing to display in a pan because, even if the bulbs are fresh, a number are apt to come blind, which creates a spotty effect overall. A gardener near Edinburgh tells me that she succeeds by growing the bulbs in the same container (she uses big pans for impact) over a number of years. In this way, the bulbs increase and, if some are blind, which they will be, there'll be plenty of others to make up for them.

"Do you feed them?" I asked, anticipating that the compost (I would recommend a soil-based compost) would become impoverished. She does, now and again, with Phostrogen, when the foliage is active after flowering. You can also do a bit of surreptitious soil replacement, when the bulbs become dormant, by teasing out some of it from the surface, without actually disturbing the bulbs; then top-dressing with fresh.

I have often seen examples of a meadow area being broken up by dotting shrub rose bushes around it. More often than not, this is a failure, the bushes being starved by the turf and becoming unsightly scrags. However, I have recently seen examples where the roses throve, and in Scotland this was particularly the case with the so-called Scotch roses, varieties of Rosa pimpinellifolia, which do so well there. R. rugosa is another winner, being sometimes planted into broad roadside verges. These need to be on their own roots and will then sucker true to type.

I have been seeing quite numerous beautiful examples of the Katsura tree, Cercidiphyllum japonicum. With its neat, rounded leaves arranged along an elegant branch system, it is most satisfying all summer, without depending on spring freshness or autumn glow. The latter, incidentally, varies a lot, being minimal in some, but with luck it is warm apricot - wonderful when you are close to a tree with sunshine setting it alight.

This tree has quite a reputation for smelling deliciously of caramel, when the leaves are falling. A friend tells me that he catches the same aroma after young foliage has been clobbered by a spring frost. I got a good whiff of it from a friend's unprovoked tree in June, when it was in full leaf.

Katsuras naturally make upwards of a dozen trunks, flaring outwards from the base. This suits them, and they should not be forcibly limited to a single stem. Buy yours young, and let it grow naturally. An exposed position will make it sulk. The shelter of other trees, fairly but not too close at hand, will be a great help.

One of the hostas that I normally dislike most is 'Frances Williams', which has large, corrugated leaves of rounded outline. It commands our attention with a broad, marginal yellow rim, framing a glaucous centre. Unfortunately, the rim makes quite a practice of scorching to brown, even early in the season - look at yours now and see if I'm not right. In Scotland, this defect is less marked and it was less marked still in one example, where the hosta was quite closely set around with other perennials, notably cranesbeills (Geranium sylvaticum was one of them), sometimes even poking through its leaves. This effectively diluted their knock-me-down impact.

It amazed me that in the walled garden at Inverewe, in north-west Scotland, I saw a very wide range of vegetables being grown to greater perfection than I have ever seen them in my life. And they were well on their way to maturity, despite the cool climate and high latitude.

Will Soos, the young man growing them, practises the device of raising a great many kinds in modules under glass, so as to promote good growth early on. They are, of course, hardened off before planting out. This treatment gets them off to a flying start.

There was, on June 22, Florence fennel, almost ready to cut from a March sowing. Then, mouth-wateringly tender-looking kohl-rabi, just right for eating. Will says that, besides steaming them in the usual way, they are also excellent thinly sliced into salads. I can imagine it.

He also grows many flowers in this way, including hardy annuals. Direct sowing could never produce as good results. If each plant is given individual treatment from the moment it can be handled, it will be a primadonna. Large plants have far more staying power than small, and only one tenth the number will be needed.

"What a lot of trouble!" will be the natural reaction, but what a lot of satisfaction, too. This is not a question of producing prize blooms or vegetables for the showbench, but for your own personal enjoyment in garden and kitchen. Neither is there the slightest need or desirability to use artificial fertilisers. I should add that an asset at Inverewe, unavailable to most of us, is fresh seaweed, washed up on the beach at certain times of the year. Without any weathering or other treatment, it can be used immediately, either dug in or as a surface mulch. I have met the same ancient practice in Cornwall.

webTitle: High Fidelity: Setting the record straight

fields.headline: Setting the record straight
fields.standfirst: High Fidelity's journey from page to screen is not a problem. If there is one, it's moving the action 5,000 miles, says Joe Queenan
fields.trailText: High Fidelity's journey from page to screen is not a problem. If there is one, it's moving the action 5,000 miles, says Joe Queenan
fields.body:
Hollywood so routinely butchers everyone's favourite books that when it manages to get things even half right, it should be cause for universal celebration, perhaps even wild rejoicing in the streets. This thought is occasioned by the release of High Fidelity, a movie that isn't quite as good as the book, but is still very, very entertaining. Get out the noisemakers now.

Unlike last year's The End Of The Affair, which inexplicably sabotaged the Catholic under-pinnings of Graham Greene's great novel, or The Talented Mr Ripley, which foolishly jettisoned Patricia Highsmith's calculating psychopath in favour of Matt Damon's petulant nerd, High Fidelity is religiously faithful to the spirit of Nick Hornby's wonderful novel, even though the setting has shifted from London to Chicago. It falls very much into the same class as The English Patient, Housekeeping and The Remains Of The Day: well-made, thoroughly appealing movies that show it is possible to take one beautiful thing and make another beautiful thing out of it. Nothing in the entertainment industry is more miraculous than a great book that does not get turned into an unwatchable movie. It is almost enough to restore one's faith in a caring, loving God. Almost.

For people who are not familiar with Hornby's novel - and you should all be ashamed of yourselves - High Fidelity tells the story of a loveable London loser who is having trouble letting go of his fading youth. The owner of an unprofitable record shop that specialises in rarities, bootlegs and the types of little-known recordings whose ownership identifies one as a high priest of the counter-cultural elect, Rob is the sort of ageing adolescent who can never forgive his girlfriend for deliberately, pre-meditatedly listening to Art Garfunkel records, and worse, actually professing to like them.

While it is true that listening to Art Garfunkel records is one of the worst cultural transgressions for which a human being can be held accountable, it's not on a par with murdering innocent women or children or putting cats in the microwave or even listening to Billy Joel records, so gradually Rob has to face up to the fact that his endless list-making and star-ranking and trotting out of rock arcana is a tad juvenile. Moreover, he has to realise that his determination to remain a ranking member of a microscopic cabal of male rock cognoscenti (his employees, a few pathetic customers) is severely hampering his social life.

Seeking to come to terms with his myriad personality disorders, Rob sets out to reconstruct all of the relationships he has had in his adult life, hoping to pinpoint why each of them went wrong. Ultimately he must come to accept that it is possible to fall in love with a woman who cannot tell Neil Young from Neil Sedaka, and to recognise that endlessly dreaming up new ways to organise his record collection is not the most direct route to developing human potential. In short, while it's nice to know when Nick Drake died, and even who Nick Drake was, it's better to have a girlfriend.

High Fidelity is faithful to the twin strands that run through Hornby's novel. As in the book, the funniest parts of the movie deal with music, the least funny parts with women. This could be because rock'n'roll is inherently easier to laugh at than women, though here I am only guessing. John Cusack, as Rob, spends a good portion of the movie talking to the camera, laboriously explaining his obsessions, his fixations, his failures as a lover. One of the film industry's most persistently entertaining performers, Cusack perfectly captures the plight of the thirtysomething hipster who belatedly realises that collecting obscure Solomon Burke records and limited-edition Dutch EPs by The Cure makes a good hobby but a bad lifestyle.

When he is in the shop, trading rock trivia with his two employees, the results are very comic indeed. Todd Louiso plays a timid, mega-geeky music aficionado with an almost monastic devotion to obscure rock bands, while Jack Black plays a pudgy, acid-tongued social misfit with an encyclopedic knowledge of rock's dimly lit undergrowth. Unlike Cusack, who has trouble hanging onto his dates, these two have trouble getting dates. None the less, they do have an oddly pathetic charm. Or perhaps they are simply charmingly pathetic.

Not all of the casting is equally successful. Catherine Zeta Jones is out of her element as a funky predatoress Rob met in college; though the movie transpires in Chicago's bohemian district of Wicker Park, Zeta Jones seems too bellicosely glamorous to have ever insinuated herself into Cusack's life, much less Wicker Park. Iben Hjejle, who plays Laura, the love of his life, is adequate in the role of the long-suffering wife-to-be, but no more. The ubiquitous indie stalwart Lili Taylor is seaworthy as a ship Cusack passes in the night, Tim Robbins, as a pony-tailed rival for Laura's affections, is, as always, superb.

If High Fidelity has any failing, it is a sense that the subculture Cusack inhabits is more a British one than an American one, that people are much more likely to encounter arrested-development vinyl-philes like Rob in London than America's great midwest. The same can be said of La Cage Aux Folles, whose transplantation from France to Miami in The Bird Cage was not 100% successful. But, like The Bird Cage, the transplant works well enough. High Fidelity is not the funniest American movie of the past year - Being John Malkovich is. But it is the second funniest film and, like Being John Malkovich, it stars John Cusack. John Cusack must be doing something right. Everything, in fact.
