fields.headline: And finally... the carve-up
fields.standfirst: The battle for ITV. Allen applies the cold towel as he decides whether to bid.
fields.trailText: United News & Media and Carlton Communications were last night faced with deciding whether to press ahead with their planned merger after Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, ruled that United News must sell Meridian, the key south of England ITV franchise, to complete the £10bn deal.
fields.body:
United News & Media and Carlton Communications were last night faced with deciding whether to press ahead with their planned merger after Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, ruled that United News must sell Meridian, the key south of England ITV franchise, to complete the £10bn deal.

While the loss of Meridian is considered a blow to the merger, the companies also face the prospect of intervention by Granada Media, which Mr Byers cleared to launch a bid for either of the two.

Shares in Carlton and United fell after the ruling - which was in line with recommendations made by the competition commission to Mr Byers - while the newly-floated Granada Media's shares rose, said to be an indication that it had the stronger hand to play.

With a £1.5bn war chest after it was partly spun-off from the catering business of Granada group earlier this week, one source indicated that it was under less pressure to react quickly to yesterday's ruling.

Charles Allen, the ambitious chairman of Granada Media, is not expected to be satisfied by just taking Meridian, which could cost £500m, off United's hands. He said yesterday he was "well placed to lead the consolidation" in the ITV network.

Paul Richards, media analyst at West LB Panmure, believes Granada will push to buy both Meridian and long-time target Scottish Media Group. Another possible bidder for Meridian is RTL, newly spun out of Pearson.

Other industry sources expected Mr Allen to spend the weekend studying documentation which could lead to hostile bids for United, thought to be his favoured target without the Express newspapers, or Carlton.

Mr Allen, who has said he will wrap his "head in a cold towel" while he scrutinises the 200-page competition commission report, has indicated that he would like to try to engineer a friendly carve-up of the ITV regions.

He is not thought to have engaged yet in such negotiations with either Lord Hollick at United or Michael Green at Carlton, although both companies were last night understood to be facing up to the prospect that they would need to engage in dialogue with Granada.

Even if Granada did decide to make a hostile bid for either party it would have to sell one of its existing franchises - or one it acquired - to remain within existing rules under the Broadcasting Act. This states that no franchise holder can control more than 15% of viewing audiences.

However, those rules are expected to be relaxed after the next general election. To allow yesterday's decision to be reached, Mr Byers relaxed existing rules for advertising revenues, until yesterday voluntarily set at 25%.

Yesterday's move was regarded by the industry as a step towards the eventual creation of a single-owner ITV. The development of such a strong network is seen as part of the way to prevent control falling to foreign bidders, although under existing rules no non-European company is allowed to own the franchises.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, also pledged to relax the rules restricting ownership of digital television licenses. This would make any mergers easier to complete.

A spokesman for Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB welcomed the decision to relax media ownership rules. "It is good news for the whole of the media sector."

Mr Richards said: "The Government clearly wanted to create two equal-sized players split straight down the middle with relatively equal shares of ONdigital, audience and advertising so that when the time comes to create a single ITV it can be done as cleanly as possible."

Meridian, based in Lord Hollick's home town of Southampton, is the jewel in United's crown. It broadcasts to some of England's wealthiest viewers. United sources say it would be an emotional wrench for him to sell it off.

A spokesman for Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB welcomed the decision to relax media ownership rules. "It is good news for the whole of the media sector." Mr Richards said: "The Government clearly wanted to create two equal-sized players split straight down the middle with relatively equal shares of ONdigital, audience and advertising so that when the time comes to create a single ITV it can be done as cleanly as possible." Meridian, based in Lord Hollick's home town of Southampton, is the jewel in United's crown. It broadcasts to some of England's wealthiest viewers. United sources say it would be an emotional wrench for him to sell it off.

webTitle: A single future looks far from likely

fields.headline: A single future looks far from likely
fields.trailText: According to received wisdom, yesterday's announcement by trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers stepped up the pace in the headlong rush towards a single ITV company.
fields.body:
According to received wisdom, yesterday's announcement by trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers stepped up the pace in the headlong rush towards a single ITV company.

But those who repeat the "one ITV" mantra should bear in mind that it will probably be at least a decade before such a move would theoretically - let alone politically - be possible.

For a start, further consolidation in the ITV network would require a change in the law, and there is no possibility of that before the next election.

Legislation is required to remove the rule that any group of ITV companies may not hold more than 15% of the available audience.

Additionally, no one group may control the London weekday and weekend franchises. Relaxing the audience share and London rules would be a big step that a government would not take lightly.

Secondly, the key word in yesterday's competition commission report is "balance". The authority stated that there could be no Carlton-United merger without di vestment. Meridian, it suggested, should be the victim.

Without such a sell-off, Carlton-United would control two thirds of network's advertising revenue, and would be able to hold advertisers to ransom. If Meridian were to fall under Granada's control, however, the balance of power would be far more even.

Had the commission been minded to facilitate greater consolidation, it would not have made divestment a condition of approval.

Even more sensitive is the London franchise situation. The split has always caused tensions within ITV - not least because of sports rights. The cash to pay for formula one, for instance, came out of the ITV network budget, to which Carlton makes a significant contribution. But the races are all shown at weekends, to the delight of LWT, but with no discernable benefit to the London weekday broadcaster. Any changes would involve tricky manoeuvring.

The competition commission report holds a third clue to regulators' thinking. It points out that, in five years ITV's share of the total advertising revenue in British television will still be about 50%. Even with the explosion of digital channels, ITV, it says, will remain central to any television advertiser's strategy.

The one-ITV advocates cannot argue therefore that a single broadcaster is needed to maintain this strength.

webTitle: Byers sets up battle for ITV

fields.headline: Byers sets up battle for ITV
fields.trailText: Three of Britain's most powerful and ambitious media moguls were last night preparing to lock horns in a bitter battle over the ITV network after Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, cleared the way for takeovers within the industry.
fields.body:
Three of Britain's most powerful and ambitious media moguls were last night preparing to lock horns in a bitter battle over the ITV network after Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, cleared the way for takeovers within the industry.

Mr Byers gave the go-ahead for Lord Hollick's United News & Media and Michael Green's Carlton to complete their merger to create a media goliath with interests ranging from Express Newspapers to a range of ITV franchises.

But Mr Byer's insistence that the combined company could only be formed if it sold off the television company covering the south of England - Meridian - put Charles Allen, the thrusting chairman of Granada Media, in the driving seat in the race towards the goal of creating a single ITV.

The path was cleared for his new group to bid for either United or Carlton by Mr Byers' ruling, which followed a seven-month investigation by the competition authorities.

Mr Byers relaxed rules over shares of television advertising to reach the decision but rules limiting companies to a certain share of the television audience remained in place and would be a hurdle to any future mergers.

"The UK media scene has changed radically since the early 1990s. It is important that we allow ITV to develop in a way which allows it compete effectively in an increasingly diverse market," Mr Byers said.

His long-awaited decision ended a frenzied period of speculation about what concessions the government would demand to clear the way for consolidation in the politically sensitive industry.

The investigation was sparked when United, holder of the HTV, Meridian TV and Anglia franchises, and Carlton, owner of the London weekday franchise, Central and Westcountry TV, announced a merger.

Their proposed union left Granada out in the cold and prompted the group to force a competition investigation by suggesting it would bid for either United or Carlton. In preparation for the fight, Granada spun off its media businesses this week from the rest of the company's catering and entertainment divisions.

Mr Allen said yesterday: "We are very well placed to lead consolidation in ITV." He is not afraid of hostile bids - fighting successful campaigns for both LWT and Forte - and has laid plans to launch attacks on either of the companies. He is also thought to be keen to try to engineer a friendly carve up of the franchises.

The prospect of a fight between the three companies, which between them control 10 of the 15 ITV franchises, left Mr Byers with a politically fraught decision .

It pitched Labour peer Lord Hollick, the United's chief executive, and Conservative-leaning Carlton chairman Michael Green against a Granada group run by Gerry Robinson, Labour-appointed chairman of the arts council.

Media sources believe that Mr Green had tried to bolster his political influence by naming Labour peer Lord Alli, the brains behind the Big Breakfast, as managing director of productions after Carlton bought the television production company Planet 24.

United and Carlton were left last night with little to say about their possible merger, although a spokesman for Carlton, which has long-campaigned for ITV consolidation, said it was "fantastic news".

The City, though, believed Mr Allen had been dealt the better hand.

"The disposal of Meridian must be a great disappointment to Michael Green and Clive Hollick. Granada has unquestionably come out of this very well indeed," said Paul Richards, media analyst at Panmure WestLB.

The sentiment was reflected in the stock market, where Granada Media's shares rose 29p to 600.25p, while Carlton and United both fell back.

A spokesman for Mr Byers last night insisted that the decision was above politics. "The competition aspects of the mergers were cleared by the competition commission."

John Milton Whatmore, the chairman of the National Viewers' and Listeners' Association, said the decision was bad for viewers and would stifle competition between different ITV programme-makers. "While I understand the business economics of it, I don't think it will lead to better programmes. It will just mean more money for the companies."

webTitle: England on fire as Windies freeze

fields.headline: England on fire as Windies freeze
fields.trailText: This was England's second emphatic victory in 72 hours. The clinical mood they displayed against Zimbabwe was carried over to chilly Chester-le-Street, while the West Indies froze in alien surroundings. They must now turn their thoughts to the Old Trafford Test, as they have only a mathematical chance of qualifying for the final of what is becoming a nightmarish tournament for them.
fields.body:
This was England's second emphatic victory in 72 hours. The clinical mood they displayed against Zimbabwe was carried over to chilly Chester-le-Street, while the West Indies froze in alien surroundings. They must now turn their thoughts to the Old Trafford Test, as they have only a mathematical chance of qualifying for the final of what is becoming a nightmarish tournament for them.

The conditions were clearly in favour of England, their home advantage exacerbated by Stewart winning the toss and putting West Indies in. When Wavell Hinds and Sherwin Campbell trudged out to the middle this morning they were wearing about eight jumpers each. Only Lara of their batsmen seemed keen to hang around for long.

In every area where England excelled, the West Indians were noticeably lacking: Trescothick's driving was most pleasurable to watch, while the West Indians seemed obsessed with nurdling to leg and off; England's five seamers barely bowled a bad ball, but the West Indians were consistent only in pitching too short. And England's tigerish fielding display (Alan Mullally excepted) made West Indies' blunders all the more embarrassing.

Stewart and Trescothick's record partnership was fantastic, Stewart's brutal pulling and cutting complementing Trescothick's smooth driving. But England won this match in the field. Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Mark Ealham delivered the consistent performances we have come to expect from them, but it was Craig White and Mullaly who stood out. White's bowling to the left-handers, swinging the ball away late, meant that none of the West Indians was good enough even to edge the ball, while Mullally's three for 27 reminded everyone why he had been our best bowler in the World Cup last year. In the field Graham Thorpe was a revelation at extra cover, and even the corpulent Pie-Chucker (Ealham) and Fat Slogger (Flintoff) pulled their weight in the field.

England's bowlers continually mixed up their deliveries, Mark Ealham even bowling slower balls (or bowling even slower balls) and the West Indian tactics were made to look hopelessly outdated. England haven't bowled a wide for two games now, and had Stewart not taken pity on the West Indians by bowling Trescothick for two overs, they wouldn't even have reached their paltry 169.

But let us end with that opening partnership, a record for England against the West Indies. Both batsmen looking largely unshakeable, with the stumps being threatened more by the streakers than the bowlers. Trescothick has now scored 238 runs at an average of 81.33, and is improving with every innings. Here he was made man of the match for the second game in four, and is taking everything completely in his stride.

webTitle: Oops! I made the wrong choice

fields.headline: Oops! I made the wrong choice
fields.standfirst: It's never too late to change your mind
fields.trailText: It's never too late to change your mind
fields.body:
To err is human but some mistakes are more easily rectified than others. That bad perm, for example, will eventually grow out, while your rash purchase of Celine Dion's greatest hits can always be given to a charity shop or jumble sale. But, "Oops, I've done the wrong degree"? What happens if you've spent three years at university studying something you weren't remotely interested in?

It's more common than you might think. David Gilmour went to Portsmouth Polytechnic (now Portsmouth University) in the 80s to study quantity surveying. Within a few weeks, he wished he'd never applied in the first place. "I hated Portsmouth, I hated university and I hated the course," he says.

"I never knew what I wanted to do when I left school but I was good at DIY so someone suggested surveying. I got the idea it would get me out of the office and that I'd spend my time going round building sites doing practical things. It turned out that it wasn't like that at all."

Although he came close to jacking it in, Gilmour completed his degree. "I talked it over with my parents and they persuaded me to stick it out," he says. "But the day after my last exam, I went to Eastbourne to teach English to foreign students for the summer. I'd known right from the start that I had no intention of working as a surveyor."

There are several reasons why people do the 'wrong' degree, says Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology and health at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology. Some, like Gilmour, find the subject doesn't live up to their expectations. Others, he says, are restricted by their choice of A-levels or didn't know enough about all the other options open to them before they decided which course to study.

"You also change as a person when you go to university," Mr Cooper continues. "Often, as a young person, you're influenced by your parents. You want to please them and 'buy' their dream for you, so you go to college to study law or medicine or whatever.

"But when you start the course, you develop interests in lots of things and you meet new people. You may start to realise that you don't want to be a doctor or a lawyer after all."

The good news, says Cooper, is that it often doesn't matter what subjects you studied when it comes to finding a job, so your wrong degree may be alright after all. "People shouldn't think of a degree as vocational training," he asserts. "What it teaches you is how to learn and gives you a framework to do that. You learn that there is more than one answer and more than one textbook. You learn to use your own resources.

"What employers are trying to recruit is talent, analytical ability and self-confidence," he points out.

"The top five accountancy firms, for example, recruit graduates from any discipline. In fact, I would estimate that about 50% of graduates end up doing something totally different to what they studied at university."

David Gilmour agrees. After Eastbourne, he spent two years in Spain teaching English where he learned to speak Spanish fluently. Back in the UK, his language skills, coupled with the fact that he had a degree, secured him a job with a travel agent. From there, he and a colleague set up their own specialist travel company, South American Experience which, 13 years later, has a healthy turnover and employs eight staff.

"I felt for a long time that I'd wasted three years at university," he admits, "but in retrospect I think that getting a degree was important, no matter what it was in. Now I'm an employer myself, I take on people with very different backgrounds and qualifications. For example, we've got one person with a history degree and another who studied psychology. I've noticed that people with a degree tend to pick things up more quickly."

So if you've just left university with a qualification but no desire to use it, take time off, advises Gilmour. "You've probably worked hard to get your degree, so bum around for a while. It's extraordinary the people you'll meet and the ideas you'll pick up.

"You never know where it will lead. It's not the end, it's just the beginning."

webTitle: How to... let off steam without blowing your top

fields.headline: How to... let off steam without blowing your top
fields.standfirst: Flip out in the workplace and you could lose all credibility
fields.trailText: Flip out in the workplace and you could lose all credibility
fields.body:
You're having one of those days. You know the sort: the hot water runs out, it's raining - again. The train is a tardy sardine container, you forgot to charge up your mobile, and some idiot has just spilt their cappuccino to go all over your only suit. In the office, your boss has a go at you, a client calls to complain, and your computer packs up - twice. Meanwhile, your main source of daily nutrition, the sandwich trolley, somehow manages to bypass you. Worst of all though is the irritating internal voice advising you to be cool. Calm. Collected. Are you joking?

Right now the desire to "go and scream at some poor unsuspecting person" is fairly strong for Adriana Paice. She has just graduated from Edinburgh University; the stress of finding a proper job and a life to go with it is mounting. "I really feel like releasing it in some way. But I know I have to keep it together. I know I can't lose it."

Yet in these circumstances, losing it might be entirely understandable. Even acceptable, says Karen Brook, partner with Blueprinting Excellence, specialists in personal and professional change. "If graduates feel like they are out of control - of themselves and where they are going - sometimes the only way of responding is to actually flip out."

But Ms Brook warns that once you are in the workplace, flipping out is no longer appropriate. "If you lose your temper then you risk losing your credibility with it. You could be seen as young, immature and unprofessional."

This is something Matt Rhodes is well aware of. He finished his post-grad legal practice course at Nottingham last year and will soon take up a position with a City firm. "Once I'm there I know I won't be able to be as spontaneous in how I express myself. I'll have to be more contained. I'll have to conform to the conventions of what's expected. Compared to university, it's going to be completely different."

Making this transition is particularly difficult, says Ron Connolly, a development trainer with Pegasus Empowerment. "Graduates are coming out of the world of theory and into the world of reality. Invariably there is a mismatch between what they expected and what they are facing. This mismatch is a real cause for anger and anxiety."

How do you deal with this? The first thing, says Mr Connolly, is to recognise the triggers of your anger and anxiety. He describes five: Thinking 'Shoulds': Where what you think should happen and what does happen is diametrically opposed. Reading Minds: Where you not only get annoyed about someone's behaviour but also what you perceive to be its intention. Collecting Straws: Where you collect the little incidents that ultimately break the camel's back. Suppressing Feelings: Where you deny anything negative only to have it implode later on. Criticising Yourself: Where you push yourself to meet unreasonable goals.

Once you've identified your stress buttons, the next thing to do is realise that you have a choice about whether or not you allow them to get pushed. So, as things build up, and build up, and build up until you can't take any more, try, Mr Connolly says, to remember that you can choose how to react. The secret to keeping calm lies in "accepting you won't always win everything".

There will "always be people, things and circumstances that just won't go your way and you need to accept they never will go your way. If you can do this, you can free yourself from the frustrations associated with them."

All very well in theory. But what about in practice? "I admit this doesn't always work," says Mr Connolly. "Some of the time it will. The majority of the time, it won't. Making a change takes time. And application."

Meanwhile there's nothing like having a good sound off. In private. "I chew my boyfriend's ear off" is how one graduate put it. She graduated from Westminster last year and now works as an information officer in the voluntary sector, dealing with paying members everyday. "I am employed to provide a service and some people expect to be able to say anything they want and for me to deliver anything they ask for. At these moments I'm thinking 'how dare they speak to me like this. I'm not paid to listen to this. I am not prepared to put up with this'. But I have to stay polite and friendly and interested. Until I go home."

Perhaps Adriana Paice, fresh from university, and all those like her, should lose it while they still can.

"Graduates are coming out of the world of theory and into the world of reality. Invariably there is a mismatch between what they expected and what they are facing. This mismatch is a real cause for anger and anxiety." How do you deal with this? The first thing, says Mr Connolly, is to recognise the triggers of your anger and anxiety. He describes five: Thinking 'Shoulds': Where what you think should happen and what does happen is diametrically opposed. Reading Minds: Where you not only get annoyed about someone's behaviour but also what you perceive to be its intention. Collecting Straws: Where you collect the little incidents that ultimately break the camel's back. Suppressing Feelings: Where you deny anything negative only to have it implode later on. Criticising Yourself: Where you push yourself to meet unreasonable goals. Once you've identified your stress buttons, the next thing to do is realise that you have a choice about whether or not you allow them to get pushed. So, as things build up, and build up, and build up until you can't take any more, try, Mr Connolly says, to remember that you can choose how to react. The secret to keeping calm lies in "accepting you won't always win everything". There will "always be people, things and circumstances that just won't go your way and you need to accept they never will go your way. If you can do this, you can free yourself from the frustrations associated with them." All very well in theory. But what about in practice? "I admit this doesn't always work," says Mr Connolly. "Some of the time it will. The majority of the time, it won't. Making a change takes time. And application." Meanwhile there's nothing like having a good sound off. In private. "I chew my boyfriend's ear off" is how one graduate put it. She graduated from Westminster last year and now works as an information officer in the voluntary sector, dealing with paying members everyday. "I am employed to provide a service and some people expect to be able to say anything they want and for me to deliver anything they ask for. At these moments I'm thinking 'how dare they speak to me like this. I'm not paid to listen to this. I am not prepared to put up with this'. But I have to stay polite and friendly and interested. Until I go home." Perhaps Adriana Paice, fresh from university, and all those like her, should lose it while they still can.

webTitle: Recruiters' new tactics to woo graduates

fields.headline: Recruiters' new tactics to woo graduates
fields.standfirst: From leaving fruit in your pigeonhole to promising free beer, firms go all out to attract top bananas
fields.trailText: From leaving fruit in your pigeonhole to promising free beer, firms go all out to attract top bananas
fields.body:
Twenty-two-year old Lynne Miles is one of the feted top 10% that all the big cheeses in graduate recruitment want to woo. On track for a 2:1 and with an impressive 40 A-level points, this Warwick finalist is a great communicator with a good range of work experience and the kind of track record in student societies that gives good CV.

And while her career aspirations have yet to be formulated further than a vague interest in merchant banking, Lynne knows exactly what she wants from her future employer.

"Money," she says flatly. "We students are poor - and mine is the first year who'll graduate with debts from paying tuition fees as well. My friends and I are looking for a salary between £20,000 and £30,000. At £30,000, the wow factor sets in."

According to 'human asset measurement organisation' Saratoga Europe, companies spend on average £7,179 recruiting each of their graduate intake. So it must be disheartening to hear that at least one of their target students can be swayed by something as simple as a pay cheque.

Human resources departments have long been keen to highlight their "competitive" salaries, yet for them this is a single shot in the propaganda war. From a juggernaut visiting your campus to bananas in your pigeonhole, recruiters have ways of making you join.

Today's students are bombarded with corporate information from the moment they matriculate. Faced with university careers services overflowing with glossy company brochures, it is unsurprising that this sophisticated audience treats many of them with cynicism.

"The message we get from students is tell it how it is," says Davina Clapham, who works in graduate communications at consultancy Park Human Resources.

"They switch off when a firm uses corporate speak, talks about its chairman and how long it's been around. They want honesty - and someone who's done it."

Case studies in brochures are popular - although she acknowledges that students are unlikely to warm to a "starry-eyed recruit talking about how her time in Chicago has enriched her life".

"If those brochures are too slick they become unrealistic," she adds. "I remember a brochure for Boots in which one of the case studies admitted that Boots wasn't her first choice employer - but that the job has worked out well and she enjoyed what she did. It was a refreshing and honest approach."

The Naked Truth, the highly praised Asda recruitment video that takes a documentary-style approach to a graduate's lot, is in a similar vein. Shot by their graduate intake for the next generation of potential recruits, it communicates the upsides, downsides and fast pace of the Asda work environment.

"We've actually had a downturn in applications from 8,000 to 2,000 since we started producing a video," says Asda's Andrea Vowles.

"It's great for us, because it acts as a natural filter and ensures that the people who do apply have an understanding of our working culture and know what they're letting themselves in for. Being upfront about commun-icating what we're about has saved both us and our applicants time and effort."

Recruiters are coming to realise that Noughties students have a different set of career aspirations than their predecessors.

While international firms offering big bucks, multinational experience, long-term career progression and a retirement plan won the top graduates of the 80s and 90s, this year's finalists are thinking short-term and looking out for learning experiences and stock options.

Peter Johnston, director of resourcing at Andersen Consulting, noted the change in a presentation he gave at the Association of Graduate Recruiters' annual conference last week.

"Now they're turned on by dot.coms, 'balance of life' and cash - they're not coy about asking about money," he smiles. "I've lost count of the number of people coming to see me about their career break - not a holiday - but serious time out to pursue charity work or travel."

To redress the balance and attract the bright sparks, internationals are now trying to give off an aura of youth and intimacy in the way they sell themselves. They may concentrate on a particular function such as e-commerce to give the firm the feel of a start-up.

Another approach is to be innovative and impressive: Andersen Consulting recently wowed campuses across the country with their recruitment juggernaut, a fully fitted out mobile presentation unit. Why hire a local hotel suite when you can tempt candidates inside your corporate lorry?

Although the competition for the top 10% is hot among employers, students are far from complacent and can be daunted by the application process. So when a recruiter makes a direct approach to a finalist asking them to apply to their scheme or attend their presentation, they're going to be flattered enough to listen.

Unilever got headlines in the marketing press a couple of years ago when it identified student high achievers at Warwick University and placed a personalised message in their campus pigeon holes: bananas labelled, "You're a top banana: come to our presentation." "We'd sent out letters in the past," says graduate recruitment manager Ailsa Falconer, "but students now get so much mail that we wanted to stand out - be wacky and different. This was a technique that our campus managers in Warwick specifically wanted to try, and there was a good response."

Employers have long sponsored certain university clubs in the hope of increasing brand awareness and possibly encouraging members to consider them as a future employer.

A newer approach is to target specific departments - a practice much better established in the United States where it's common for, say, an engineering department to be "branded" by a corporate sponsor who may also provide equipment and placements for students.

Already established in the legal profession, summer internships in all sectors are also growing in popularity as companies realise it's important to contact the best candidates early. Motivated by money and the chance to get great work experience, students are signing up.

A firm's reputation still has cachet. Take Simon Hogg, a recent Nottingham physics graduate, who attended 12 presentations during his final year at university.

"The first thing that attracted me is the company name - if you hear that a Procter & Gamble or a Shell is coming to your campus then there'll always be a big turn-out," he says. "The careers service had a big list of dates, told me there would be free beer and food provided and I signed up. When you tell your mates you're attending a company presentation they get a bit paranoid and feel pressured to go along, too."

Davina Clapham acknowledges that peer pressure is factored into her campaigns - that being able to stand at the bar and say, "I work for McKinsey/the Civil Service/the BBC" et al still has appeal. "A brochure may be only 25% of the influence," she says.

"We also want course tutors, other students and parents to tell a prospective candidate how great the firm is.

"At key points in a recruitment campaign, we try to work with the company's public relations department to ensure that there's positive press coverage in the nationals and other relevant publications," she adds.

"This a four-pronged attack to ensure the target student gets the right message."

fields.headline: Meeting with Ted
fields.standfirst: 'The warmest applause was reserved for a marcher who wasn't in uniform at all - he was the only genuine war veteran in the parade'
fields.trailText: 'The warmest applause was reserved for a marcher who wasn't in uniform at all - he was the only genuine war veteran in the parade'
fields.body:
If you happened to find yourself two Saturdays ago in the village of Badia Agnano near Arezzo in southern Tuscany, you would have witnessed an improbable scene of young men of the village parading in all the uniforms of the second world war. They were dressed as Italian Fascists and German Nazis, as American GIs and British Tommies, all marching along together in cheerful comradeship. Onlookers cheered them as they went by, but the warmest applause was reserved for a marcher who wasn't in uniform at all, but was casually dressed in cotton trousers and an open-neck shirt. Women ran from the side of the street to embrace him; children waved little flags at him. And the flags they were waving were Union Jacks, for this tall and unassuming man was the only genuine war veteran in the parade. He was 78-year-old former British Army private Ted Doyle, from Ellesmere Port on the Mersey, who in July 1944 entered Badia Agnano in the wake of the retreating Germans.

Badia Agnano is a small place with a population of maybe 1,000. It is neither architecturally nor historically distinguished. Most of its buildings are of post-war construction. Nevertheless, a few years ago, a group of its citizens started a society called "Come eravamo una volta" - "How we once were" - to cultivate an interest in its past. They have since been organising exhibitions of old photographs and forgotten agricultural implements to evoke the village of yesteryear. They have even organised historical lectures and debates. But this year they put on their most ambitious festival yet. They staged a weekend of exhibitions and parades, focusing for the first time on the second world war.

As everyone knows, the Italians had an immensely complicated war, from which they failed to emerge with much glory. Allied first of all with the Germans, they were subsequently occupied and brutally treated by them. Three villages close to Badia Agnano were the scenes of massacres on June 29, 1944, in which well over 200 people were shot dead in Nazi reprisals for the killing of two German soldiers by partisans. The British arrived in the area two weeks later, as part of the conquering allied advance, and discovered and investigated the massacres. Rumours still persist that the Germans were aided and abetted in these atrocities by Italians still loyal to the Nazi cause, though there is no conclusive evidence to prove it. Despite all these complications and sensitivities, exacerbated by the fact that there are now far more Germans than British with holiday homes in the area, Badia Agnano decided to celebrate its liberation by the British in 1944 by inviting one of its liberators to attend this month's festivities.

It approached the British ambassador to Rome, Sir Tom Richardson, who happens to have a holiday cottage only a mile or two away, and the research he set in train produced Ted Doyle, who is one of the very few surviving British war-time visitors to Badia Agnano, and practically the only one who met the villagers' condition of actually remembering something about it.

They struck gold in Ted. Although he couldn't remember a great deal about the village - he was there for only a few days, the Germans having abandoned the place before the British arrived - he could at least remember the desperation of its inhabitants at the time, with their lack of food and their ruined homes. He was moving in recalling these things, and they were moving in return. They not only paid the air fares of Ted and his son, Michael, and put them up for several days in a hotel; they wined them and dined them without a break while they were there, and they never stopped thanking Ted for his part in expelling the Germans from Italy. Ted played a big part in this. Although he was involved in no fighting at Badia Agnano itself, he subsequently lost a lung and several fingers in a battle on the Adriatic coast and was invalided back to Britain with the Military Medal.

Now he is a remarkably fit and sprightly man, whom one would hesitate to describe as old. The "Meeting with Ted", as one of the events in the village was billed in ubiquitous posters, was a truly touching occasion, full of genuine emotion. Ted's affection for the people of Badia Agnano was matched by their affection for him.

One of the depressing consequences of British debate about the European Union, about whether or not we should join the euro, is the way it embitters our attitude to other European countries and makes us forget how much we share. We do not even believe that there are people on the continent who are grateful to us for what we did for them in the war. But, as Ted proved, there definitely still are.

webTitle: How to have a sight test

fields.headline: How to have a sight test
fields.trailText: When your optician asks you to get into the chair, make sure that it doesn't tilt back and that it doesn't have a little rinsing bowl built in. Whatever else happens in that chair, it won't help your eyesight.
fields.body:
When your optician asks you to get into the chair, make sure that it doesn't tilt back and that it doesn't have a little rinsing bowl built in. Whatever else happens in that chair, it won't help your eyesight. All it tells you is that you were absolutely right to think that you need glasses.

Once you've found the chair, the optician will put on you a pair of heavy metal glasses that look as if they've been knocked together by a local blacksmith. Whatever your optician tells you, this is not the latest look in Notting Hill, nor is it the new National Health style. They're for test purposes only, and you should not wear them home under any circumstances.

The sight test itself starts when the optician asks you what the lowest line on the eye-chart is. Don't waste their time by saying, 'Printed in the UK'. Your best bet is to say, 'What eye chart?', or even look startled and say, 'Who's there?' The optician will then slide a number of lenses into the special metal glasses and then keep asking you whether it's better with this one or with that one. This is a huge optician's wind-up, as all the lenses are exactly the same - they just want a bit more time to laugh at you in your big metal glasses.

Remember, the phrase opticians hate most in this test is, 'They're much of a muchness.' Say this once too often, and they will send you away with a pair of glasses that'll make you see round corners and, when you complain, they'll say that all glasses are much of a muchness.

Opticians also like to ask whether the circles are clearer in the red box or in the green box. This is no time to tell them that you're colour-blind (otherwise, it's the blacksmith's glasses for you).

At some stage, the optician will want to take a closer look at your eyes, and will then ask you to put your chin in a little holder. Then they'll approach you as if it was their first snog. While they're staring into your eyes, it's important to maintain eye contact. If you look away or blink, it's the blacksmith's glasses for you. During this stage, you will get the unpleasant impression that your entire skull is empty and the optician is saying to herself, 'My God, there's absolutely nothing in there!'

Finally, you'll walk out of the shop with your glasses and crystal-clear vision, then suddenly see that your job, home and family are nothing like you'd imagined. And all everyone else thinks is, 'Why is he wearing those big metal glasses?'

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Flamenco and mother love
fields.body:
'And I became asexual - that's what my readers want,' I explained (I hadn't seen mum for a couple of weeks). She raised her hand to her brow and threw her head back in a dramatic gesture, which I took to be one of despair; then, with astonishing agility, she jumped up on my fabulous new granite-topped table (www.coexistence.co.uk and wailed and stomped frantically.

'What on earth was that about?' I asked when she finally stepped down. 'Flamenco, my new passion,' she replied proudly. 'The urge comes over me, and I have no choice: I must dance.' She's just back from Spain. 'You must help me, darling,' she pleaded. 'Pedro says I have a natural facility, but I want to polish my art and take it to new heights...'

I entered flamenco.uk on the Mamma search engine. One site seemed promising, although it was alarmingly named - www.surfnazi.demon.co.uk. 'They organise flamenco workshops in Dorset, and flamenco-and-guitar holidays in Wimborne Minster...'

'Perfect! Book it for me!' she cried.

'Wait a minute... who is Pedro?'

'My new lover,' she replied, casually.

'Mum, you can't go on like this,' I said. 'At your age, people are supposed to be set in their ways. You're asking for yet another disappointment.'

She gave me a pitiful look. 'Pedro is 26,' she replied.

'My age!' I shrieked.

'Yes, but he's much more mature than you. He has no time for all this nonsense you're addicted to.'

I was able to tolerate her impertinence only because I've taken up golf. The open air soothes my nerves, walking and stretching improve my suppleness, and it is hard to imagine a more asexual sport. I found everything I needed through magicalia.co.uk, a sporting portal that includes golf, cycling and - oh, sweet memories of carefree days with Ricky - surf.

I entered flamenco.uk on the Mamma search engine. One site seemed promising, although it was alarmingly named - www.surfnazi.demon.co.uk. 'They organise flamenco workshops in Dorset, and flamenco-and-guitar holidays in Wimborne Minster...' 'Perfect! Book it for me!' she cried. 'Wait a minute... who is Pedro?' 'My new lover,' she replied, casually. 'Mum, you can't go on like this,' I said. 'At your age, people are supposed to be set in their ways. You're asking for yet another disappointment.' She gave me a pitiful look. 'Pedro is 26,' she replied. 'My age!' I shrieked. 'Yes, but he's much more mature than you. He has no time for all this nonsense you're addicted to.' I was able to tolerate her impertinence only because I've taken up golf. The open air soothes my nerves, walking and stretching improve my suppleness, and it is hard to imagine a more asexual sport. I found everything I needed through magicalia.co.uk, a sporting portal that includes golf, cycling and - oh, sweet memories of carefree days with Ricky - surf.  www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum:  Tate à Tate
fields.standfirst: 'What to do first? Get a haircut or expose myself to Egyptian funeral monuments?'
fields.trailText: 'What to do first? Get a haircut or expose myself to Egyptian funeral monuments?'
fields.body:
Installed in Bloomsbury for a week. Cheap hotel, fourth floor, no lift. Legs and lungs not what they were. Never mind. At least I am spared the hospitality of Alice and Saskia. They are in the middle of one of their rows, so I visit Saskia's exhibition without Alice. Saskia escorts me round a gallery in Islington adorned with rubber gloves artfully arranged with wire, pegs and chains. "It's a comment on the enslavement of women, Dulcie," she explains. Cannot help observing that only other visitor is a shifty-looking man, probably imagining worse enslavement with even more rubber.

Saskia has developed a Charlie Dimmock hair-tossing habit, which seems a little too ingénue for a woman of 50. Still, who am I to talk? My own hair has started to resemble Bob Geldof in his medieval hermit mode.

"Dulcie, I'm so grateful for your support!" Saskia looms in at me. "Alice has been so controlling! She has a colonial approach to relationships - like I'm her territory, y'know? She seems to think she's planted her flag in my summit!"

Make an excuse and leave. Leap on bus and am carried past the Angel, a name I always love, though it is now no more than a tourniquet of traffic. Now my obligations are discharged, I'm free. What shall I do first? Get a haircut or expose myself to Egyptian funeral monuments?

No contest. I am soon gazing up the massive nostril of a Ptolemy. The so-called British Museum is teeming with foreigners, but the exhibits all seem foreign, too. Charmed, as usual, by other religions, though I do, of course, adore Bellini Madonnas with an almost religious fervour. But how groovy those Egyptian gods are, particularly the genetically-modified ones. The head of a dog, the head of an eagle, the head of a lioness... I wonder if in a few years you'll be able to get that kind of choice at Toni & Guy?

Glance briefly at Assyrians (head of a man, body of a horse) and Greeks (body but no head) before slumping down on a bench. Feel I have head but no legs. Must see Elgin marbles, though. Limp to gallery and admire frieze of maidens carrying sacred garment to temple - Greek equivalent of designer's Autumn Collection. An American woman turns to her husband and brays, "Isn't it saaad that it should have to be here?" Tempted to offer savage retort about treasuries of European art and letters slumbering in the air-conditioned archives of the US, but think better of it.

Hobble out and catch sight of myself in a shop window. Compared with Egyptian goddesses, I resemble a furtive Neanderthal. Perhaps civilisation is unravelling backwards, like a sweater snagged on the thorn of time. But maybe a haircut would help. Take bus to Covent Garden therefore and venture timidly into first salon I come to. As it happens, a Chinese stylist called Don, or possibly Dong, is free. He suggests that, since it is summer, I could do with a few tasteful highlights. Unable to argue - after all, the Chinese civilisation has been fully developed for millennia and Londoners have evolved only as far as the Second Ken Dynasty.

Dong cuts my hair with little enthusiasm. But perhaps that is the Zen way. Perhaps I should not express gratitude when it is finished, but ignore it with a graceful shrug. Curiously, the haircut is asymmetrical, but perhaps that is Zen also and I am too intimidated to enquire. I am blow-dried and the final result is strangely reminiscent of a windswept tree atop a cluster of weatherbeaten rocks. I have achieved the longed-for Japanese garden at last, although I had not realised it would take shape on top of my own head.

Manage to conceal dismay at appearance and horror at bill, and assure Dong I will return. Rush back to hotel and wash hair awkwardly in en-suite washbasin. My appearance is restored to the comfortable old Neanderthal model, but with a slightly pretentious air about the ears, as if I am attempting to evolve towards curlers, or possibly the head of a koala. What was the dawn of hairdressing? Was it Occam's Razor?

Decide to do the sensible thing, ignore the trivialities of personal appearance and visit both Tates, which are conveniently linked by something called the Art Bus, though privately I think of it as the Tate à Tate.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
It is a long time since I have read a more self-indulgent piece than Dave Eggers' (Orphans On A Roll, July 8). It is a scrawling stream of adolescent consciousness with faintly interesting insights about Dave Eggers but none whatsoever about 'Toph'. If that is a work of genius, then perhaps we ought to think of a new word for great writing.
George Bancroft
Blackpool
fields.body:
It is a long time since I have read a more self-indulgent piece than Dave Eggers' (Orphans On A Roll, July 8). It is a scrawling stream of adolescent consciousness with faintly interesting insights about Dave Eggers but none whatsoever about 'Toph'. If that is a work of genius, then perhaps we ought to think of a new word for great writing.
George Bancroft
Blackpool

I read a combination of detective novels, classic car magazines, and architectural books. I think Father Ted is a work of genius. I wouldn't be caught dead with The Hobbit. JK Rowling 'has never had much time for fantasy, and certainly isn't a buff' (Harry, Jessie and Me, July 8). She reads Q and watches Father Ted. Now I know a little bit more about why I am becoming addicted to the Harry Potter books.
M A Richardson
MarqueR@talk21.com

JK Rowling seems like a really nice person, and good luck to her. But the Harry Potter books are to children's literature what your other unlikely heroine, Julie Burchill, is to feminism: derivative and second rate. There are some real writers out there who could do with your support.
Les Barker
Cardiff

'I'm not Mick Jagger!' says the author of the Harry Potter books. But if she were, would her band be called the Rowling Stones?
James Norton
London W2

As a 14-year-old, I am constantly astonished by the lack of self-esteem of my peers. All of my friends are convinced that they are un-pretty and overweight, encouraged by inane journalists who write that to be successful in life you must be a size 6 (but have 'curves', so you cannot be labelled anorexic), have a beautiful face, a demanding but high-paying job and still have time to be a family woman.

If only impressionable young women read Julie Burchill's heartening words (July 8) instead of the aged rubbish churned out by other papers.
Natalie Boddy
Dumfries, Scotland

Any regular viewer of The Bill knows that police officers no longer have beer guts, bad ties or shiny suits (Little Boy Blue, July 8). You will be telling us that they wear Brycleem next.
Martin Edwards
Birmingham

Further to Gemma Thwaite's view (Dear Weekend, July 8) that 'no longer do only the fittest survive, as nature intended', she might like to reflect that a major means of survival for all species has been via co-operation, pooling resources and assisting the greatest numbers possible to live.

The result is to optimise the gene pool not 'dilute' it, as Gemma asserts.
Joy Wood
London E1

We Rotarians are too often dismissed by the media as harmless do-gooders, leading smug, comfortable lives and doing a little fund-raising. We do not, however, murder our wives before rushing off to a Rotary dinner, as Julie Burchill suggests (July 8).

Now, if Julie's partner is interested in joining Rotary, we might think of changing our habits.
Derek Sowell
Chester-le-Street, Co Durham

webTitle: Internet investors really dig the mines

fields.headline: Internet investors really dig the mines
fields.standfirst: 'There's gold in them there hills' is the cry that has set online chatrooms abuzz. Tony Levene checks out the prospects
fields.trailText: Burnt out by the dot.com shake-out? If the chatrooms are any guide, the new breed of internet-based share traders are now plunging down often murky mineshafts or punting on dubious derricks in far distant oil fields.
fields.body:
Burnt out by the dot.com shake-out? If the chatrooms are any guide, the new breed of internet-based share traders are now plunging down often murky mineshafts or punting on dubious derricks in far distant oil fields.

Natural resources - gold, diamonds, oil and gas - are the new dot.coms as the punters look for the next "tenbacker", a share that multiplies 10 times in double quick time. But investors lured in by potential huge gains could be literally pouring their cash into a bottomless hole in the ground.

Only a minority of "junior" mining and oil exploration companies - the small fry quoted on the alternative investment market, or in overseas markets such as Ireland or Australia - ever find what they are looking for. And even fewer make economically viable discoveries. Many just keep raising money from hapless investors to finance yet more exploration.

But that doesn't stop chat room devotees in their search for a quick route to riches - or for an escape route from a poor performer - by convincing others to buy.

Take Bula Resources, a Dublin based "black gold" play. It has been around for years, looking for oil in both Siberia and Libya. Earlier this week one investor, 'Jupiter's Lover' posted on iii: "I bought more today as I'm hearing that the announcement is now about to come - the offices in Libya have been moved into and the ceremony is either this week or next. Get into these as there is a lot of interest brewing."

But 'Sospanfawr' is a bit more down to earth. "Do you have any ideas what they are likely to go up to? I've been holding them for seven years (after a hot tip!!!)."

Bula predates the internet. Back in 1994, an anonymous Bula investor (who came from Guildford) faxed newspapers with fanciful stories about directors pretending to fly to see interests in Siberia while changing planes in Frankfurt and heading to secret deals in Libya.

The shares have been as high as 7p and as low as 0.75p - the latter following Irish fraud squad action and a disappearing director in 1998. And while Bula's latest statement (the company has gone through a complete change of management) is full of bull points such as higher oil prices, a better political situation in Libya and the "enhancement of our asset acquisition strategy", there are no words about earning any money from oil.

Alternative investment market listed Pan Andean Resources is also a chat room favourite. The shares have multiplied five times to 50p so far this year. "BUY, BUY, BUY!" enthuses 'Tom Bear' on iii. "I have done a lot of research, emailed the company etc. The risks aren't as big as some people reckon. The upside is massive and the price is cheap."

The anonymous "Citytipsters" reckon it will go to 500p, based partly on enthusiastic quotes from a director who saw plenty of oil activity from a helicopter flight over the jungle.

Some online punters are backing MinMet, in the hope that unsubstantiated rumours on the net that some unidentified person may have found a diamond as big as a cricket ball in a terrain not too far away from the company's own concession, turn out to be true.

A year ago www.minesite.com, a free service paid for by exploration companies eager to post their latest statements, set up with only a few hits a day. Now it counts 5,000 .

Its co-owner Robert Tyerman says "interest is poised to be as big as dot.com mania. We could be at fever pitch by Christmas. There are literally hundreds of stocks for the punters but few are going to make it." But he warns against punters promising "target" share prices and advises finding out about promoters - some are serial fraudsters.

Jeremy Batstone at NatWest Stockbrokers pours cold water over mines mania. "The reality is that concern for interest rates and an economic slowdown is bad news for all natural resources shares. They are just geared plays on commodity prices and these could fall. Smaller companies will be hit hardest - they have nowhere to go."

And for those still getting overexcited, there is always the example of Bre-X, the Indonesian gold mine which was quoted in Vancouver. It attracted huge investor interest. But after a director fell out of a helicopter, it was revealed that its claimed biggest precious metal find ever was just a massive hole in the ground.

webTitle: Body fascists and salads get comeuppance

fields.headline: Body fascists and salads get comeuppance
fields.trailText: Obviously I'm delighted for the guy. Freddie Flintoff has answered the body fascists in the only way he knows how. I've never had too much luck with man of the match awards, but in other respects the Lancashire lad and Dave Podmore are identical.
fields.body:
Obviously I'm delighted for the guy. Freddie Flintoff has answered the body fascists in the only way he knows how. I've never had too much luck with man of the match awards, but in other respects the Lancashire lad and Dave Podmore are identical.

I too am sick and tired of having to explain to coaches that I'm just about the right weight for my build. If I had a deep-pan pizza for every time a fizz has told me I need to lose a few pounds I really would (go on a diet, that is).

Our society is obsessed with thinness. Everyone on the county circuit is now expected to look like Kate Moss and I'm convinced this is the main reason many cricketers are suffering at the moment from stress-related problems such as Low-Score Syndrome and Getting Stuffed In The One-Dayers Disorder.

What the Flintoff-knockers can't seem to get into their carbohydrate-starved brains is that Freddie has very sensibly realised he's in for the long haul. A playing weight of 17st-something not only opens up extra areas of advertising space on your upper body, it also gives you the stamina to get you through a career. My waistline, like my NatWest bowling average, has been around the 38 mark for 25 years and, far from thoughts of retirement, Dave Podmore's looking good for a record ninth benefit.

Dietwise, it all started to go pear-shaped (or vice-versa, actually) for England in the 70s. During my very brief spell with Middlesex, Mike Brearley, in his wisdom, told me at a team meeting that I needed to show more dedication. He'd taken us all to a scummy wine bar in Chalk Farm where, as he assured the lads, there was some "truly remarkable paté".

Personally I find it hard to take a guy seriously who bats with something that looks a birth control device on his head. But even if my face had fitted into the Middlesex regime, no way could I have stuck to the diet of bean sprouts and bulgar-wheat salad that was on offer. I was back up to Derby before the Beaujolais Nouveau was even in the shops.

Luckily Mike Gatting didn't pay much attention to his skipper either, and if we're comparing not just waistlines but test records, whose team beat the Aussies on their turf in the 1986-87 series, with an average weight of 16.5st?

If you're after someone to fill Gatt's trousers (and let's face it, we're desperate) then look no further than a trencherman like young Flintoff. From what I've seen of him the lad can do everything - sandwiches, pasties, saveloys - and he always hits the pitch very hard. In fact, like Pod in his pomp, he leaves a huge impression on any ground he walks on to.

Freddie's also copped a fair bit of stick for his limited strokeplay, that is to say his tendency either to block it or whack it at a thousand miles an hour straight down mid-off's throat.

Believe me, Pod's been there. Down the years, plenty of so-called experts voiced the opinion that Dave Podmore is a one-shot player. OK, maybe I am, but on the day I played the shot (August 10, 1989) it added a vital two runs to our total. It also briefly kept alive our hopes of Bain Clarkson glory and, what's more, it could have gone for four if Jack Simmons hadn't stuck his foot out.

Being a bit of a cricket historian, I've been having a look at the Lord's Canteen Archive and it throws up some very interesting stats indeed. They prove beyond question that letting yourself go in the tum-and-bum department can be directly related to success on the field.

This dates from the time of Gatt and Beefy, back through Colin Cowdrey and co in the 60s, and even as far as "Scrumpy Jack" Hobbs and some old geezer called JWHT Douglas, known to all and sundry as "Johnny Wants His Trifle". Sir WG Grace himself, who was a doctor, mark you, would never go in to bat without a couple of capons under his belt, washed down with a flagon or three of good porter.

In those days the chant was "Who's had all the oysters? Who's had all the oysters? Gracey, Gracey, you fat bastard . . ." And you never heard of the good doctor suffering from Ramps-style crises of confidence, did you? Funny, that. They also tell me that at Hove in the 50s, if the Reverend David Sheppard took the field after tea wearing his dog collar, it was a pretty safe bet it was to hide all traces of the arctic roll he'd been wolfing down.

The defence rests - preferably on the edge of the boundary, with a little lad on hand to offer me a few crisps.

If you're after someone to fill Gatt's trousers (and let's face it, we're desperate) then look no further than a trencherman like young Flintoff. From what I've seen of him the lad can do everything - sandwiches, pasties, saveloys - and he always hits the pitch very hard. In fact, like Pod in his pomp, he leaves a huge impression on any ground he walks on to. Freddie's also copped a fair bit of stick for his limited strokeplay, that is to say his tendency either to block it or whack it at a thousand miles an hour straight down mid-off's throat. Believe me, Pod's been there. Down the years, plenty of so-called experts voiced the opinion that Dave Podmore is a one-shot player. OK, maybe I am, but on the day I played the shot (August 10, 1989) it added a vital two runs to our total. It also briefly kept alive our hopes of Bain Clarkson glory and, what's more, it could have gone for four if Jack Simmons hadn't stuck his foot out. Being a bit of a cricket historian, I've been having a look at the Lord's Canteen Archive and it throws up some very interesting stats indeed. They prove beyond question that letting yourself go in the tum-and-bum department can be directly related to success on the field. This dates from the time of Gatt and Beefy, back through Colin Cowdrey and co in the 60s, and even as far as "Scrumpy Jack" Hobbs and some old geezer called JWHT Douglas, known to all and sundry as "Johnny Wants His Trifle". Sir WG Grace himself, who was a doctor, mark you, would never go in to bat without a couple of capons under his belt, washed down with a flagon or three of good porter. In those days the chant was "Who's had all the oysters? Who's had all the oysters? Gracey, Gracey, you fat bastard . . ." And you never heard of the good doctor suffering from Ramps-style crises of confidence, did you? Funny, that. They also tell me that at Hove in the 50s, if the Reverend David Sheppard took the field after tea wearing his dog collar, it was a pretty safe bet it was to hide all traces of the arctic roll he'd been wolfing down. The defence rests - preferably on the edge of the boundary, with a little lad on hand to offer me a few crisps.

webTitle: Resolute Munton hands Derbyshire a lifeline

fields.headline: Resolute Munton hands Derbyshire a lifeline
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 181 & 239-9
Kent 280
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 181 & 239-9
Kent 280
fields.body:
There were times yesterday when Derbyshire did not look all that bothered about avoiding relegation to the Second Division. It is just as well that Tim Munton had not given up.

With Kent sensing the possibility of victory inside three days, Munton shared an unbroken last-wicket partnership of 48 with Kasir Shah to give Kent's fragile batting line-up something to fret over on the final day.

Munton was joined by Shah after six wickets had gone down in 12 overs for 38 runs to the benefit primarily of Min Patel, whose arrival on the field was delayed by a stiff neck. He produced his best return of the season, five for 65, which included three wickets in four balls.

After Simon Lacey had walked for a catch to silly point and Dominic Cork had dabbed a catch to the wicketkeeper Paul Nixon, Trevor Smith narrowly avoided the hat-trick, the ball beating bat, stumps and keeper. No matter, Smith surrendered to the next delivery, driving tamely to mid-off.

Shah does not look like a No11 but judgments may have been distorted by some of what came before. Even so, on his championship debut against Lancashire last week he added 49 for the last wicket with Smith and here he has survived 65 balls, aided by experience at the other end.

Earlier, Munton had taken the last two wickets after Kent resumed on 257 for eight. He finished with six for 54, the 34th time he has taken five wickets or more in an innings in his 15-year career. He is the ideal pace bowler for this pitch and he has given himself something to bowl at in the fourth innings.

For Derbyshire to post a sizeable victory total, though, one of their batsmen needed to score a century. But as that has not happened since the first match of the season, Kent must have known they were on to a good thing. They were right. Soon after lunch Derbyshire were struggling at 65 for three.

Steve Stubbings was smartly taken to his left at second slip by Matthew Walker, Michael di Venuto was caught behind fencing at his second ball and Luke Sutton was caught at slip from Patel's second ball. Di Venuto's stroke was particularly poor and his exit was marked by a lone barracker from the small crowd. A few more might have had their say as well but on another cool, blustery day the sensible option was to watch from the car.

Steve Titchard, along with Lacey, then showed the patience required by this pitch in a partnership of 88 for the fourth wicket. Titchard, who has been short of runs since his move from Lancashire at the end of 1998, mixed determined defence with powerful strokeplay through the off side and he was seldom in trouble during his three hours at the crease.

He was finally undone by the break for tea. Dropped in the first over after the resumption by Rahul Dravid at first slip off Matthew Fleming, he was caught behind off the inside edge in Fleming's next over.

The dismissal at least provided some consolation for Dravid, who dislocated the little finger of his right hand in attempting the catch. He will bat today, if required, and there is every chance that he will be.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: There have surely been occasions this summer when the Durham bowlers have felt an irresistible urge to subject their batting brethren to the same fate that allegedly befell Edward II. On the other hand, they may well decide that a large order of red-hot pokers to go would be too lenient.
fields.body:
There have surely been occasions this summer when the Durham bowlers have felt an irresistible urge to subject their batting brethren to the same fate that allegedly befell Edward II. On the other hand, they may well decide that a large order of red-hot pokers to go would be too lenient.

Time and again Simon Brown and the rest of that vaunted seam squadron have put their side in all sorts of useful positions only to see them squandered. Yesterday's defeat at Grace Road, their fifth of term, followed a collapse for 93.

Brown's five for 70 in Leicestershire's second innings left him one behind his team-mate Melvyn Betts (37 wickets at 15.32 compared to 38 at 18.08) in their tussle for the title of leading homegrown wicket-taker, but a target of 311 became merely fanciful once James Ormond (five for 34) had struck three times in his opening spell. It was hard not to recall Archie McLaren's famous sneer: "Any fool can play forward."

In mitigation, mind, the pitch, reportedly flitting between the low and the subterranean, was not blameless. Which will presumably prompt much gnashing of molars at Middlesex, whose Southgate surface cost them eight points even though batting on it continues to resemble a pleasure.

Justin Langer's side ran up 374 to set Glamorgan 307, thanks in no small measure to a ninth-wicket stand of 75 between Richard Johnson and that renowned Sachin Tendulkar impersonator Angus Fraser, whereupon Matt Elliott and Steve James scooted to 69 in 19 overs.

Sadly, the rules state that pitches, unlike wine and the credibility of the platform sole, should deteriorate with age.

Last month's hurried replacement of Shoaib Akhtar by Paul Reiffel - at 34 the new elder statesman of the overseas contingent, not to mention the 13th Australian - doubtless struck many Nottinghamshire followers as the most anti-climactic acquisition since Clive Rice succeeded Gary Sobers. Yet Rice went on to do what the great Garfield could not, namely lead the club to a pot or two, and now that he, as manager, and Reiffel are in harness, a double promotion could be in the offing.

With the Victorian's unbeaten 45 off 56 balls capitalising on the revival begun by Usman Afzaal, run out 14 shy of his third century of the summer, Notts, leaders of the National League Second Division, led Worcestershire by 74, then whipped out half the side and trail by just 79.

Sussex were buoyed by Michael Bevan, Reiffel's World Cup final colleague, whose unbeaten century earned a 231-run advantage over Essex. Depending on events at New Road, there might well be Martlets chirping at the top of the Second Division tonight.

In the tussle for the wooden spoon, Jack Russell kept Gloucestershire afloat against Northamptonshire with a typically cussed 72 not out, a season's best. As it is, with 152 runs required to avoid an innings defeat and only two wickets standing, they are going down for the third time.

Graeme Swann, an England off-spinner in the winter but paying 40 runs per victim prior to this game, claimed his first "five-fer" since September.

Dropping Romesh Kaluwitharana, whose hell-for-leathering helped win the 1996 World Cup, has evidently done little to dim the spark at the top of the Sri Lanka order. In the Singer Cup final in Colombo, Sanath Jayasuriya and Avishka Gunawardene swatted 84 in 12 overs en route to setting South Africa 295.

They fell 30 short after Muthiah Muralitharan (five for 44) had done unto them much as Alastair Campbell has been doing unto the British public, albeit rather more successfully.

fields.headline: Brownian motion transports Surrey
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 226 & 320-7
Yorkshire 242
fields.trailText:
Surrey 226 & 320-7
Yorkshire 242
fields.body:
All around this ground, just about every form of transport known to man bustled with activity. Red double-decker buses bundled up Harleyford Road, helicopters and planes hastened overhead, the Millennium Eye wheeled slowly, and a hot-air balloon sailed into glowering skies.

It required quite an innings to rival such fuss and fluster, and Ally Brown provided it: the fastest century of the season, from 106 balls, which propelled Surrey towards another championship and made all rival forms of transport seem ponderous by comparison.

When Brown came in, Yorkshire still possessed designs upon a victory that would have restored their own championship credentials; two-and-a-bit hours later, they were going nowhere.

Brown entered with Surrey 85 for four, restlessly holding a lead of 69, and his captain, Adam Hollioake, stomping back with a single to his name. He was immediately at one with his frenetic surroundings, launching Yorkshire's off-spinner James Middlebrook over long-on for six, a significant gesture on a turning pitch. When David Byas turned to his pace bowlers, Chris Silverwood and Matthew Hoggard were swiftly repelled and Gary Fellows was struck into the pavilion.

On such dry, true surfaces, there are few more destructive county batsmen than Brown and, with 295 behind him against Leicestershire at Oakham School, he was in reasonable nick. He reached his hundred with another six off Middlebrook, this time over long-off, and on the Oval's arid acres every six is worthy of the name. Yorkshire's fielders clapped through gritted teeth.

Yorkshire's lack of a seasoned spin bowler could prove particularly costly here once Saqlain Mushtaq and Ian Salisbury get to work today.

Middlebrook persevered, and achieved his first four-wicket championship haul as the lead stretched to 304 by the close, but such is the paucity of spin bowling that Surrey can produce turning pitches against almost anyone without fearing retaliation.

Had Brown been caught on 21, with Surrey's lead 99, a different story might have unfolded. Michael Vaughan dropped the catch, diving a mite gingerly to his right at extra cover, his error possibly the consequence of a blundering moment involving his team-mate Hoggard.

Vaughan's England career is only just back on track after he broke his hand at Headingley in early season, so he was unamused when, hitting catches in practice, Hoggard flung one boisterously against his glove. He spent much of the morning off the field "feeling unwell" and when he returned, the man they call The Verger looked in need of several bottles of communion wine.

Nadeem Shahid found life sweeter. A forearm shattered by Devon Malcolm wrecked his 1999 season, as complications arose when he returned too early and a screw was displaced. His recovery began in Sydney last winter, and yesterday his 80, from 156 balls, shared in an afternoon stand of 144 in 31 overs with Brown that transformed the match.

Shahid fell leg-before to Middlebrook, flicking to leg, but Brown pushed on to be unbeaten on 130 at the close. All of it watched, incidentally, by an uncanny John Major lookalike on the ground the former premier frequents: the same grey hair and staid spectacles, and the same heavy overcoat.

That we saw the real Ally Brown, though, was undeniable.

webTitle: Burns bright on cold day as Somerset turn up heat

fields.headline: Burns bright on cold day as Somerset turn up heat
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 239 & 133-2
Somerset 565
fields.trailText:
Lancashire 239 & 133-2
Somerset 565
fields.body:
Much will be learned of these teams' championship credentials today. If Somerset can bowl Lancashire out a second time without Andy Caddick on what has become a shirt front, they will be considered genuine contenders. If Lancashire cannot bat all day to salvage the draw, it will be hard to take them seriously.

For much of a grey day in a cold wind, the odds were stacked too heavily against the bowlers for the cricket to hold the interest. A sprightly century from Michael Burns was a notable exception, but when a group of schoolchildren on the Coal Orchard side of the ground started a slow handclap with Somerset closing in on their highest-ever total against Lancashire, it was difficult not to sympathise.

Mike Atherton and John Crawley then put on 124 for Lancashire's first wicket without batting an eyelid, their lack of concern showing why Jamie Cox had extended the Somerset innings on, and on, to a lead of 326. Atherton's second century of the match was beginning to look inevitable when, 20 minutes before the close, Peter Trego produced the perfect leg-cutter to remove his off stump.

Ian Blackwell, the former Derbyshire left-armer who had been twirling into the gale from the eighth over, then had Neil Fairbrother acrobatically caught by Rob Turner off a ball which lifted nastily out of the rough, and suddenly an interesting last day was in prospect.

History favours Lancashire to survive, as already this season Somerset have had Hampshire and Kent on the ropes only to lack the penetration to finish them off. Crawley will also be anxious to convert his first championship fifty of a disappointing summer into a substantial match-saving innings.

The inventive Trego looks to be Somerset's best bet for further wickets, although there is some slow turn for Blackwell, and Keith Parsons, who took five for 13 in the first innings, has still to bowl.

Any hopes Lancashire had of restricting Somerset to a manageable lead by polishing off their remaining four wickets were emphatically shattered by Burns and Turner, who put on 176 in 40 overs - a record for Somerset's seventh wicket against Lancashire, beating the 167 between Parsons and Graham Rose here last September.

Burns is an interesting cricketer who had rugby league trials with his hometown Barrow as a teenager and joined Somerset from Warwickshire as a wicketkeeper in 1997 but has earned a regular place as a batsman who bowls. He reached his first championship century of the season from 150 balls with his 14th four, one of a number of glorious cover drives, shortly after Turner had been given lbw for 75.

Turner could not disguise his surprise and disappointment, having taken a lengthy stride forward to Sourav Ganguly, but this was still a huge improvement on a recent run of 102 runs from nine innings - a far cry from the consistency which earned him an England A tour last winter.

Chris Schofield, one of his team-mates in Bangladesh and New Zealand, was less impressive for his first 25 overs, but then illustrated the value of leg spin by picking up the last three wickets in short order. But by that stage Somerset had already passed their previous best against Lancashire, 561 at Bath 99 years ago - not that the shivering youngsters were overly impressed.
