webTitle: Praise the lard, pass the vitriol

fields.headline: Praise the lard, pass the vitriol
fields.standfirst: Back-biting England seek final place against West Indies today
fields.trailText: If Andrew Flintoff thought he had vanquished his critics, as well as Zimbabwe, at Old Trafford on Thursday he is a wiser man today. "Praise the lard" was one newspaper headline yesterday after his violent unbeaten 42 which carried England to victory with almost 30 overs to spare. Cricket can be a cruel business.
fields.body:
If Andrew Flintoff thought he had vanquished his critics, as well as Zimbabwe, at Old Trafford on Thursday he is a wiser man today. "Praise the lard" was one newspaper headline yesterday after his violent unbeaten 42 which carried England to victory with almost 30 overs to spare. Cricket can be a cruel business.

Generally, however, Flintoff awoke to the sort of column inches that are lovingly pasted into scrapbooks by family and fans. The truth is that no one cares whether he is as big as King Kong provided he punches his weight, which is what he did in his 45-ball innings at Old Trafford to bring England back into contention at the halfway stage of the triangular series.

Those who had watched him have a nightmare net on Wednesday morning feared the worst. The colour drained from the England coach Duncan Fletcher's face as he watched him.

"I was horrible and got so frustrated that I deliberately knocked over a set of stumps," Flintoff said. "Perhaps that helped relieve a bit of the tension.

"And then Duncan told me I would be batting at three and that made me feel a lot better. I've played in that position for Lancashire and enjoyed it. And this was on my home ground, so it felt great to get runs.

"Hopefully this will be the turning point, but whether I stay at three [against West Indies today] remains to be seen. It's a different game and different opposition.

"We will talk about my back in the next few days. We have all the information it's possible to get after all the scars I've had. Now it's a case of taking the correct course of action."

Referring to the sort of press coverage that might have driven some players into purdah, he added: "It's been a terrible week with all the headlines about my weight. I thought Monday was bad enough when they first appeared, but it just got worse. It was embarrassing for me but it was my family who suffered more. They were very upset.

"They could not understand why I was suddenly getting called all these names. I did feel harshly treated, but the only way to hit back was to go out there and get runs. I let my bat do the talking."

The only pity was that the always approachable Flintoff was dissuaded from sharing his pleasure with the world by one or two old lags in the side, whose strident voices are only heard when the more enlightened Nasser Hussain is not captaining. The Lancashire man's non-appearance after the match did not impress the sponsor. "It is a shame that something personal should overshadow what has been England's most emphatic performance in the NatWest series," said a spokesman.

Alec Stewart should have been celebrating too; he led the side well and took a record-equalling six catches. Instead he rounded on the media. "Most of [the press] have criticised him and most of it is rubbish. He's a talented cricketer. You built him up and now you are trying to knock him down."

This left everyone bewildered. Almost everything that has been published about Flintoff in the past week has come from the England management, either directly or in off-the-record briefings.

The management decided to shame Flintoff into bucking up and the press were only too happy to be used to that end. Stewart got it all wrong. Nor can England players who have nicknamed Flintoff "Fat Slogger" complain with any integrity about the headlines.

A win for England today when international cricket comes to Chester-le-Street, Durham's attractive ground, followed by another defeat for West Indies against Zimbabwe on the same ground tomorrow would put England through to next Saturday's final against Zimbabwe at Lord's.

Hussain will be missing again today. He is beginning to resemble one of those non-playing Davis Cup captains. In the circumstances there seems little point in trying to rush Nick Knight back into action either.

fields.bodyText: If Andrew Flintoff thought he had vanquished his critics, as well as Zimbabwe, at Old Trafford on Thursday he is a wiser man today. "Praise the lard" was one newspaper headline yesterday after his violent unbeaten 42 which carried England to victory with almost 30 overs to spare. Cricket can be a cruel business. Generally, however, Flintoff awoke to the sort of column inches that are lovingly pasted into scrapbooks by family and fans. The truth is that no one cares whether he is as big as King Kong provided he punches his weight, which is what he did in his 45-ball innings at Old Trafford to bring England back into contention at the halfway stage of the triangular series. Those who had watched him have a nightmare net on Wednesday morning feared the worst. The colour drained from the England coach Duncan Fletcher's face as he watched him. "I was horrible and got so frustrated that I deliberately knocked over a set of stumps," Flintoff said. "Perhaps that helped relieve a bit of the tension. "And then Duncan told me I would be batting at three and that made me feel a lot better. I've played in that position for Lancashire and enjoyed it. And this was on my home ground, so it felt great to get runs. "Hopefully this will be the turning point, but whether I stay at three [against West Indies today] remains to be seen. It's a different game and different opposition. "We will talk about my back in the next few days. We have all the information it's possible to get after all the scars I've had. Now it's a case of taking the correct course of action." Referring to the sort of press coverage that might have driven some players into purdah, he added: "It's been a terrible week with all the headlines about my weight. I thought Monday was bad enough when they first appeared, but it just got worse. It was embarrassing for me but it was my family who suffered more. They were very upset. "They could not understand why I was suddenly getting called all these names. I did feel harshly treated, but the only way to hit back was to go out there and get runs. I let my bat do the talking." The only pity was that the always approachable Flintoff was dissuaded from sharing his pleasure with the world by one or two old lags in the side, whose strident voices are only heard when the more enlightened Nasser Hussain is not captaining. The Lancashire man's non-appearance after the match did not impress the sponsor. "It is a shame that something personal should overshadow what has been England's most emphatic performance in the NatWest series," said a spokesman. Alec Stewart should have been celebrating too; he led the side well and took a record-equalling six catches. Instead he rounded on the media. "Most of [the press] have criticised him and most of it is rubbish. He's a talented cricketer. You built him up and now you are trying to knock him down." This left everyone bewildered. Almost everything that has been published about Flintoff in the past week has come from the England management, either directly or in off-the-record briefings. The management decided to shame Flintoff into bucking up and the press were only too happy to be used to that end. Stewart got it all wrong. But it worked so well that it might be considered again, even though the No3 position is hardly a problem area since it is here that Graeme Hick regularly displays his finest form in international cricket. webTitle: Fat Freddie finds silver lining as big role model

fields.headline: Fat Freddie finds silver lining as big role model
fields.standfirst: Jim White on waists, weight and women
fields.trailText: As Andrew "Freddie" Flintoff applied all 17st 12lb of heft to hoik the ball deep over long-on at Old Trafford on Thursday, there was one man watching events unfold with a keen personal interest.
fields.body:
As Andrew "Freddie" Flintoff applied all 17st 12lb of heft to hoik the ball deep over long-on at Old Trafford on Thursday, there was one man watching events unfold with a keen personal interest.

"There's 10,000 people in the stadium, and 3,000 of them will be overweight," said Andrew Chandler, as the ball eventually returned from orbit and landed somewhere in the stand. "Freddie's become a role model for them, proof of what you can do. They call me Chubby by the way. I'm 19 stone, so I should know what I'm talking about."

Chubby is no ordinary fat fan of the outsized Flintoff. He is the player's agent and has been at the Lancashire lad's sizeable side throughout the most traumatic week of his career, a week in which he became embroiled in the first recorded instance of kiss-and-tell involving bathroom scales, with intimate details of his weight all over the back pages.

"By the way, it's not fair," said Chandler of his client's substantial reputation. "He's not fat. He's heavy." Whatever the semantics, the implication of Flintoff's week has been the same: that his affection for fast food and ale are indicative of an ill-disciplined squandering of the enormous potential within him. It is a criticism that is stark, forthright and painful.

"Freddie's been embarrassed by it all to be honest, it's hurt," revealed Chandler. "I can assure you it is not nice to be ridiculed in the press every day."

But is the criticism not justified? After all, until Thursday, Flintoff had hardly put his sizeable shoulder to the England cause, failing frequently and succumbing to regular injury.

"I'd say the criticism was warranted, but not the way it was done," Chandler reckoned. "A couple of weeks ago I was approached by the England management and warned about Freddie's weight, told that if action wasn't taken he'd be getting a letter. I agreed he was a stone too heavy and we'd do something. We put him on the Hay diet - not mixing protein and carbohydrate.

"But before it had any chance to work, the management leaked the story to the press. You have to wonder why."

Well, why?

"It's always the way with England. When there's an inherent problem, find a scapegoat. It happened with Cork and Caddick, now it's Freddie. In Australia, they'd have taken a 22-year-old lad to one side, arm round the shoulder and sorted it out quietly. Here he's hung out to dry."

For an agent, the scandal represented a challenge somewhat different from the one faced by the unhappy sportsman at the centre of it.

"He needed support, to be shown that somebody does care," Chandler said. "But my heart didn't sink when I saw the story. Actually, now I come to think of it, it was the Guardian that started all this. But it wasn't 'Flintoff seen in brothel'. This was a human-interest story."

And a human-interest story with which this agent was well equipped to cope. As well as Flintoff, the comfortably contoured Chandler also represents the golfers Darren Clarke and Lee Westwood. Chandler only needs to sign up Gazza and the Quinnell brothers to corner the market in luxuriantly waisted sportsmen. Experience suggests when it comes to applying positive spin on a "too-tubby-to-play" story, Chandler is in the Max Clifford class.

"We also represent Neil Fairbrother and Chris Schofield," he said in defence of his client list. "And no one would describe them as overweight." Nevertheless, after Chandler had reassured Flintoff that he of all people could empathise with his predicament, the agent was quick to sense that the human-interest yarn might yield wider dividends. Within hours of the story breaking, his phone was ringing hot.

"We're in negotiations right now with three slimming companies looking to sponsor Freddie," he explained. "You can't deny a week like this raises a player's profile. There's girls in my office with no interest in cricket who now know all about Fat Freddie. The other England lads have been asking him what deals [he'd] signed on the back of this. But profile is only any good if it comes with delivery on the pitch. There's no long-term commercial future in just having a profile. So if he's had a good knock on Thursday and the papers are full of how successful he is, then it's an absolutely fantastic week."

And no doubt a copy of the back page of yesterday's Sun has already been sent to the framers ready to adorn Chandler's office wall, complete with the highly appropriate headline: Praise the lard.
